## UNITED GROUP B.V.
#### €300,000,000 % Senior Secured Notes due 2028


United Group B.V., a private limited liability company (besloten vennootschap met beperkte aansprakelijkheid) incorporated under the laws of the
Netherlands (the “Issuer”), is offering (the “Offering”) €300 million in aggregate principal amount of its % Senior Secured Notes due 2028 (the
“New Notes”). The New Notes will be issued under the indenture dated as of February 6, 2020, by and among, inter alios, the Issuer and U.S. Bank
Trustees Limited, as trustee (as amended and supplemented from time to time).
The Issuer will pay interest on the New Notes semi-annually in arrears on each and, commencing, 2022. The New Notes will
mature on, 2028. Interest on the New Notes will accrue at a rate per annum computed against the principal outstanding on the New Notes
equal to %.
Proceeds of the Offering will be used by the Issuer (i) to pay the purchase price for the Optima Telekom Acquisition (as defined herein), (ii) to repay
certain obligations outstanding under the Existing Revolving Credit Facility, (iii) for general corporate purposes, which may include potential future
acquisitions, working capital, capital expenditures and other purposes, and (iv) to pay transaction costs associated with the Offering. See “Use of
_Proceeds.”_
Prior to, 2024, the Issuer will be entitled, at its option, to redeem all or a portion of the New Notes by paying a “make-whole” premium, as
described in this offering memorandum. The New Notes may be redeemed at any time on or after, 2024, at the redemption prices set forth
in this offering memorandum. In addition, prior to, 2024, the Issuer may redeem at its option up to 40% of the New Notes with the net
proceeds from certain equity offerings at a redemption price of % of the aggregate principal amount thereof, plus accrued and unpaid interest
thereon and Additional Amounts, if any, to the applicable redemption date, provided that at least 50% of the original aggregate principal amount of the
New Notes (not including any additional notes) remains outstanding after the redemption (unless all of the New Notes are redeemed substantially
concurrently). Prior to, 2024, the Issuer may redeem during each calendar year up to 10% of the aggregate principal amount of the New
Notes at a redemption price equal to 103% of the principal amount thereof, plus accrued and unpaid interest and Additional Amounts, if any, to the
applicable redemption date.
In the event of certain developments affecting taxation, the Issuer may redeem all, but not less than all, of the New Notes. In addition, in connection with
certain tender offers for the New Notes, if holders of not less than 90% in aggregate principal amount of such outstanding New Notes validly tender and
do not withdraw such New Notes in such tender offer and the Issuer, or any third-party making such a tender offer in lieu of the Issuer, purchases all of
such New Notes validly tendered and not withdrawn by such holders, the Issuer or such third-party will have the right to redeem, in whole but not in part,
such New Notes that remain outstanding, following such purchase at a price equal to the price offered to other holders of such New Notes.
Upon certain events defined as constituting a change of control, the Issuer may be required to make an offer to purchase the New Notes at 101% of the
principal amount thereof, plus accrued and unpaid interest, to (but not including) the date of repurchase. However, a change of control will not be
deemed to have occurred if a specified consolidated net leverage ratio is not exceeded in connection with such event.
The New Notes will be senior secured obligations of the Issuer and will, subject to the Agreed Security Principles (as defined herein) and as further
described and at the times detailed herein, be guaranteed (the “Guarantees”) on a senior secured basis by Adria Midco B.V. (the “Company”) and certain
subsidiaries of the Issuer and be secured by the Collateral (as defined herein). The validity and enforceability of the Guarantees and the security interests
in respect of the Collateral will be subject to significant limitations, as described in “Limitations on Validity and Enforceability of the Guarantees and the
_Security Interests.”_
This offering memorandum includes information on the terms of the New Notes, including redemption and repurchase prices, security, covenants and
transfer restrictions. See “Description of the New Notes.”
There is currently no public market for the New Notes. Application will be made to The International Stock Exchange Authority Limited (the
“Authority”) for the listing of the New Notes on the Official List of The International Stock Exchange (the “Exchange”) and to be admitted for trading
on the Exchange. There is no assurance, however, that the New Notes will be listed and admitted for trading on the Exchange.
**Investing in the New Notes involves a high degree of risk. See “Risk Factors” beginning on page 47.**

**_Business Combinations_**

On July 31, 2018, Slovenia Broadband S.à r.l., a wholly-owned subsidiary of the Company, acquired Nova TV
d.d. from CME B.V. in the Nova TV Croatia Acquisition. The financial data of Nova TV d.d. has been
consolidated in the Company’s financial data as of and from July 31, 2018.

On September 4, 2018, United Media S.à r.l., a wholly-owned subsidiary of the Company, acquired Direct
Media d.o.o. Beograd from Ascanius Netherlands B.V. in the Direct Media/Pink Acquisition. The financial
data of Direct Media d.o.o. Beograd have been consolidated in the Company’s financial data as of and from
September 4, 2018.

On March 3, 2020, Slovenia Broadband S.à r.l., a wholly-owned subsidiary of the Company, acquired Tele2
d.o.o. za telekomunikacijske usluge in the Tele2 Croatia Acquisition. The financial data of Tele2 d.o.o. za
telekomunikacijske usluge (now trading as Telemach Hrvatska d.o.o. or “Telemach Croatia”) has been
consolidated in the Company’s financial data as of and from March 3, 2020.

On July 31, 2020, United Group Bulgaria EOOD, a wholly-owned subsidiary of the Company, acquired Viva
Telecom Bulgaria EOOD in the Vivacom Acquisition. The financial data of Bulgarian Telecommunications
Company EAD (trading as “Vivacom”) has been consolidated in the Company’s financial data as of and
from July 31, 2020.

On November 12, 2020, NewCo United Group Hellas S.à r.l., a wholly-owned indirect subsidiary of the
Company, acquired a controlling stake in Forthnet S.A. and its subsidiaries (“Forthnet”) (for details, refer to
Note 21.1 to the Company Unaudited Interim Financial Statements). The financial data of Forthnet has been
consolidated in the Company’s financial data as of and from November 12, 2020.

On January 22, 2021, United Group Bulgaria EOOD, a wholly-owned subsidiary of the Company, acquired
Nova BG in the Nova Broadcasting Group Acquisition. The financial data of Nova BG, including its
provisional purchase price allocation, has been consolidated in the Company’s financial data as of and from
January 22, 2021.

See Note 23 to the 2020 Company Audited Financial Statements and Note 21 to the Company Unaudited
Interim Financial Statements for additional information regarding business combinations.

We have adopted various accounting policies during the financial periods presented in this offering
memorandum. With effect as of January 1, 2019, we have adopted IFRS 16 (Leases) and IFRIC 23
(Uncertainty over Income Tax Treatments). For the impact of the adoption of IFRS 16 (Leases) on our
financial statements, see Note 4 to the 2019 Company Audited Financial Statements. See “The Company’s
_Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations—Key Factors_
_Affecting Our Business and Results of Operations—Implementation of New Accounting Policies and Accounting_
_Updates.”_

As permitted under IFRS, we did not apply a full retrospective approach when adopting these accounting
policies and as a result have not restated any historical financial data of the Company (including comparative
figures) prior to the date disclosed above. As a result of these changes in accounting policies, our results and
financial position may not be directly comparable from period to period.

_Company Segment Reporting_

We are a pan regional distribution platform of cable and satellite Pay-TV, broadband internet and telephony
services in Slovenia, Serbia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Montenegro, Bulgaria, Croatia, North Macedonia and
Greece. Our business has grown substantially in terms of scale, geographic reach and service
offering since 2018 through both organic growth and acquisitions. As a consequence of these changes, our
Group-level financial reporting has evolved during the last several years.

In order to provide a meaningful analysis of our results of operations during the period under review discussed
under “The Company’s Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of
_Operations”, in addition to a discussion of our Group-level consolidated results of operations based on IFRS_
measures, we also present a discussion of revenues, UG Adjusted EBITDA and UG Adjusted Capital
Expenditure of our Serbia Group, Slovenia Group, Bosnia Group, Montenegro Group and Media Group
segments for the years ended December 31, 2018, 2019 and 2020, and the three months ended March 31, 2020
and 2021. We also present a discussion of revenues, UG Adjusted EBITDA and UG Adjusted Capital


-----

Expenditure for the three months ended March 31, 2021 of: our Croatia Group, which we added following the
completion of the Tele2 Croatia Acquisition (as further described in this offering memorandum); our Bulgaria
Group, which we added following the completion of the Vivacom Acquisition (as further described in this
offering memorandum); and of our Greece Group, which we added following the completion of the Forthnet
Acquisition (as further described in this offering memorandum).

Under IFRS 8 “Operating Segments,” we present our segment data in the notes to the annual and interim
financial statements. In Note 5 to the Company Unaudited Interim Financial Statements, we disclose the
segment results for nine business segments, which are as follows:

- Serbia Group. This segment includes the results of cable services in Serbia and DTH operations in Serbia,
and North Macedonia, including the results of Ikom (acquired in April 2017). This segment also includes
the results of Absolut Solutions, (although these results are not reflected in the statutory consolidated
results of the SBB Serbia Group);

- Slovenia Group. This segment includes the results of our cable and mobile services and DTH operations in
Slovenia;

- Bosnia Group. This segment includes the results of our cable and DTH operations in Bosnia and
Herzegovina;

- Montenegro Group. This segment includes the results of our cable and DTH business in Montenegro;

- Bulgaria Group. This segment includes the results of our telecommunications operations in Bulgaria;

_Capital Expenditure and UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure_

Capital expenditure represents purchases of tangible and intangible assets, consisting primarily of set-top box
purchases and other customer capital expenditure, installations (including capitalized labor costs), cable and
mobile network build out, upgrades, maintenance and other investments, computer hardware and software.

In this offering memorandum, for the years ended December 31, 2018, 2019 and 2020, we have derived capital
expenditure (as recognized under IFRS) for the Company and for each of the Company’s business segments
from the Company Audited Financial Statements and, for the three months ended March 31, 2020 and 2021,
from the Company Unaudited Interim Financial Statements. See “Reconciliation of Certain Financial Data
_Presented Herein.”_

UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure represents capital expenditure, as adjusted by intragroup adjustments, the
application of IFRS 15 for acquisition costs in SBB Serbia, assets held for sale and overflow between periods.


-----

Intragroup adjustments relate to unrealized profit on the intragroup sale of end-user equipment by SBB
Serbia. When SBB Serbia sells this equipment to other Group companies in compliance with applicable
transfer pricing requirements, it makes an unrealized profit on the sale. These unrealized profits are eliminated
for the purposes of preparing our accounts in accordance with IFRS, but are not eliminated for the purpose
of our management accounts (which are not prepared in accordance with IFRS).

The application of IFRS 15 for acquisition costs in SBB Serbia reflects the additional effect of harmonizing
our accounting policy with respect to the capitalization of subscriber acquisition costs for rebinding, upselling
and cross-selling (which in the past were not eligible to be capitalized, but under IFRS 15 qualify for
capitalization), which were determined subsequent to the preparation of our management accounts.

Assets held for sale relate to programming rights acquired by our Media Group segment for other Group
segments which were recognized under IFRS as intangible assets and were invoiced to other Group segments
after March 31, 2021.

Overflow between periods relates to the fact that our management accounts are closed prior to the closing of
our accounts prepared in accordance with IFRS. Overflow between periods in any given period reflects the
additional capital expenditure incurred between the preparation of our management accounts and our
accounts prepared in accordance with IFRS for such period.

In this offering memorandum, we present UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure for the Company and for each of
the Company’s business segments for the years ended December 31, 2018, 2019 and 2020, and for the
three months ended March 31, 2020 and 2021. See “Summary of Company and Group Run-Rate, Vivacom,
_Unaudited Pro Forma and Certain Other Financial Data” and “Reconciliation of Certain Financial Data_
_Presented Herein.” A reconciliation between the Company’s capital expenditure and UG Adjusted Capital_
Expenditure for the years ended December 31, 2018, 2019 and 2020, and the three months ended March 31,
2021 is included elsewhere in this offering memorandum, under “Reconciliation of Certain Financial Data
_Presented Herein.” In addition, for informational purposes only, we describe our anticipated UG Adjusted_
Capital Expenditure for the year ended December 31, 2021 based on management estimates, which may vary
from our actual Group level capital expenditure data when it is prepared in accordance with IFRS.

UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure and our future UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure estimates are prepared
based on management accounts rather than IFRS. One example of a difference in methodology used in
preparing the management account financial data (as compared to IFRS financial data) is that when
determining capital expenditure relating to set-top boxes purchased by our group companies, the expenditure
is treated as inventory until such set-top box is activated by the end-user, at which time it is treated as a fixed
asset. Under IFRS, however, this expenditure is required to be accounted for as a fixed asset from the moment
such set-top box is purchased. As a result, when presenting our segment level UG Adjusted Capital
Expenditure and our anticipated UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure for the year ended December 31, 2021 in
this offering memorandum, we classify our expenditures relating to set-top boxes as inventory until such
set-top boxes are activated by the end-user.

PricewaterhouseCoopers d.o.o. Zagreb has not audited, reviewed or performed any procedures with respect
to UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure included in this offering memorandum, and, accordingly,
PricewaterhouseCoopers d.o.o. Zagreb does not express an opinion or any other form of assurance on such
information. PricewaterhouseCoopers d.o.o. assumes no responsibility for and denies any association with or
responsibility for the Company’s calculation of UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure.

accounting policies and, as a result, has not restated any historical financial data (including the relevant

operating income or any other performance measures derived in accordance with IFRS, and they may be

respective company or group, along with comparable IFRS measures, is useful to investors because it provides
a basis for measuring the operating performance in the periods presented. These measures are used in the
internal management of our business, along with the most directly comparable IFRS financial measures, in
evaluating operating performance.

The Non-IFRS Measures have limitations as analytical tools, and you should not consider them in isolation
or as a substitute for our or a relevant group’s results or any performance measures under IFRS as set forth in
our consolidated financial statements or the Unaudited Pro Forma Financial Statements. Some of these
limitations are:

- they do not reflect our cash expenditures or future requirements for capital commitments;

- they do not reflect changes in, or cash requirements for, our working capital needs;

- they do not reflect the interest expense or cash requirements necessary to service interest or principal
payments on our debt;

- they do not reflect any cash income taxes that we may be required to pay;

- they are not adjusted for all non-cash income or expense items that are reflected in our consolidated profit
and loss statement;

- they do not reflect the impact of earnings or charges resulting from certain matters we consider not to be
indicative of our ongoing operations;

- assets are depreciated or amortized over differing estimated useful lives and often have to be replaced in the
future, and these measures do not reflect any cash requirements for such replacements; and

- other companies in our industry may calculate these measures differently than we do, limiting their
usefulness as comparative measures.

Because of these limitations the Non-IFRS Measures should not be considered as measures of discretionary
cash available to us to invest in the growth of our business or as measures of cash that will be available to us
to meet our obligations. You should compensate for these limitations by relying primarily on our IFRS results
and using these Non-IFRS Measures only supplementally to evaluate our performance. Please see “Summary

**Overview**

We are the leading cable and media player in Southeastern Europe, providing services to approximately
3.7 million homes as of March 31, 2021. We are the leading distributor of Pay-TV in our core markets of
Slovenia, Serbia, Bosnia and Herzegovina and the number two distributor in Montenegro. As of March 31,
2021, we provided services to approximately 10.9 million RGUs and analog and digital cable Pay-TV services
to approximately 1.9 million unique subscribers. United Group’s revenue for the three months ended
March 31, 2021 was €439.4 million and UG Adjusted EBITDA was €179.2 million. The Group had Run-Rate
Revenue for the annualized last two quarters ended March 31, 2021 of €1,976.4 million and Run-Rate Last
Two Quarter Annualized Adjusted EBITDA on a pre-IFRS 16 basis for March 31, 2021 was €706.3 million.

The Combined Group is the clear multi-play leader in its footprint, with market leading positions in Pay-TV,
broadband internet and fixed-line and mobile-telephony in Slovenia, Serbia, Bosnia and Herzegovina,
Montenegro, North Macedonia, Bulgaria, Croatia and, following the Forthnet Acquisition, Greece. The
Combined Group’s addressable market comprised 13.4 million households as of December 31, 2020.

We have grown rapidly through both acquisitions and organic growth. In July 2020, we acquired Vivacom, the
market leading integrated telecommunications operator in Bulgaria, based on total revenue for the year ended
December 31, 2020, which is the leading operator in fixed-line telephony services and broadband services, the
number three provider of mobile-telephony services and the number three provider of Pay-TV, in each case,
by number of subscribers as of March 31, 2021. The Vivacom Acquisition increased our addressable market
by approximately 35% in terms of population, and the addition of Vivacom’s subscriber base more than
doubled our existing subscriber base. In March 2020, we also acquired Tele2 Croatia, the third largest
telecommunications operator in Croatia, based on mobile revenues as of March 31, 2021, through which we
offer mobile services in Croatia. In November 2020, we completed the acquisition of a controlling interest
(the “Forthnet Acquisition”) in Forthnet S.A. (“Forthnet”), a prominent telecom operator and Pay-TV
provider in Greece, which marked our entry into the Greek market and will strengthen our position as an
industry leader in Southeastern Europe. In January 2021, we acquired Bulgaria’s largest multi-platform media
company, Nova Broadcasting Group EOOD, from Advance Media Group EAD (the “Nova Broadcasting
Group Acquisition”), providing a strong base for our content offering in Bulgaria. In July 2021, we signed an
agreement to acquire a majority interest (the “Optima Telekom Acquisition”) in OT-Optima Telekom d.d.
(“Optima Telekom”), a Croatian telecom operator offering a broad range of fixed internet and pay-TV
services. Subject to its completion, the Optima Telekom Acquisition will allow us to further expand our
presence in the Croatian market and offer a full range of telecommunication services, including pay-TV,
through our existing infrastructure in the country.

We offer a diverse and differentiated line of products and services. We are the leading distributor of satellite
(“DTH”) Pay-TV across Southeastern Europe, with Pay-TV product and service offerings in each of Slovenia,
Serbia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, North Macedonia and Montenegro, where we use our Total TV platform to
serve subscribers both inside and outside of our cable footprint to deliver content across the entire region,
including rural areas. Following the Vivacom Acquisition, we also provide Pay-TV services in Bulgaria and
are the leading IPTV provider in Bulgaria, while the Nova Broadcasting Group Acquisition strengthened our
content offering in Bulgaria. Following the Forthnet Acquisition, we also provide cable and DTH services in
Greece. In addition to our cable-based and satellite-based services, we offer mobile-telephony services in
Slovenia, Bulgaria and Croatia. We provide 4G LTE coverage to almost the entire population in each of these
countries, and we are rolling out 5G networks across our mobile-telephony footprint. On September 21, 2020,
we announced the commercial launch of our 5G network in Bulgaria, and to that end in May 2021, we
secured a 20-year license for 100 MHz spectrum frequencies in the 3.6 GHz band. We also in April 2021
secured 15-year spectrum licenses in Slovenia for 5G frequencies, and commenced deployment and
commercial launch of 5G 3600 MHz in Slovenia in June 2021. We are participating in a 5G spectrum auction
in Croatia this year.


-----

Our core telecommunications business is also complemented by our two over-the-top (“OTT”) distribution
platforms that customers can access through internet based streaming: EON, our regional OTT platform,
which enables customers connected to our competitors’ broadband internet connections outside of our cable
footprint to access our attractive portfolio of Pay-TV channels, and NetTV Plus, our international OTT
platform, which delivers ethnic and local language content to the ex-Yugoslav diaspora around the world. In
July 2020, we launched Shoppster, our regional e-commerce online-shopping platform, which offers more
than 20 popular product categories, including electronics, home and gardening, tools, fashion, items for
children and kitchen appliances. Shoppster is available as an integrated online and TV shopping platform in
Serbia and Slovenia.

Through our in-house content business, we produce distinctive and attractive in-house media content for our
Pay-TV channels across multiple key genres that have historically driven Pay-TV subscriptions. These channels
include Southeastern Europe’s most popular family of branded Pay-TV sports channels, as well as popular
movie channels, children’s channels, a 24/7 news channel, music channels and other specialized channels,
which we continue to expand both organically and through acquisitions. We currently produce over 40% of
the total content in our national (terrestrial) and cable operations, and our programs typically receive ratings
of between 30% to 60% in the markets in which they are available. The Group also has in-house media and
content production in Greece. We believe that our market leading content portfolio differentiates us from our
competitors, has enabled strong growth in our business and provides us with predictable third-party carriage
fees.

As part of our media business, we also provide advertising services and digital production and distribution.
Our Nova TV Croatia channel has strong local content production and profitability, with an audience share
of 40% and market share by advertising revenue of 50%. Nova BH and Nova M have appealing content, such
as popular national team football events until 2022, such as the Euro Cup qualifiers, Euro Cup, World Cup
qualifiers and League of Nations. In March 2019, we launched Nova S in Serbia. Nova S is a channel offering
high-quality local production series, sports, talk shows with well-known national presenters and high-quality
international productions, fully exclusive to SBB, Total TV and EON. The Nova Broadcasting Group
Acquisition makes us a major content player in Bulgaria by adding Nova BG’s media platform comprising
ten television channels, including NOVA TV, which broadcasts throughout Bulgaria, Bulgaria’s largest online
platform, Net Info, which reaches on average 80% of the Bulgarian population each month, and four radio
stations.

In addition to our own content, as a result of our pan regional presence and well established distribution
network, we are a distribution partner of choice for premium regional and international content owners, such
as Discovery/Eurosport, Viacom, AXN, CNN, HBO, Fox and Universal, and sports rights owners, such as
the English Premier League, Spanish Football League LaLiga, 2020 UEFA European Championship
qualifiers, 2020 UEFA European Championship, 2022 FIFA World Cup qualifiers, UEFA League of Nations,
ATP, Formula 1, Euroleague, and Moto GP, which we believe allows us to consistently obtain high-quality
content and attractive payment terms. Nova BG holds licenses to offer compelling content in Bulgaria through
distributors such as CBS Intenrational, the Walt Disney Company, Columbia Pictures and Paramount
Pictures, as well as popular sports content such as the English Premier League football, Euro Cup qualifiers
and the Euro Cup and Formula One racing. We believe these providers partner with us because of our
well-known brands, large network and our focus on Southeastern Europe.

We operate most of our business across eight countries in Southeastern Europe: Slovenia, Serbia, Bosnia and
Herzegovina, Bulgaria, Croatia, North Macedonia, Montenegro and Greece. These countries have a
combined population of approximately 40 million, distributed across approximately 13.4 million households
as of December 31, 2020, and represent the second-largest Central and Eastern European (“CEE”) market
after Poland. Despite economic differences, many of these countries share a joint history and form a single
market in which small local differences are overshadowed by the influence of similarities in cultural preferences
and language across the region and are characterized by growing Pay-TV and broadband markets that are
currently underpenetrated relative to some other CEE and Western European markets.

We are the leading multi-play provider in Slovenia, Serbia, Bosnia and Herzegovina and Bulgaria, where we
combine our services into packages, or bundles, which offer subscribers the convenience of being able to
purchase television, broadband internet and telephony services from a single provider, and provides us with
significant opportunities to cross-sell our products.

We believe that we are well-positioned to maintain our market leading positions in the Pay-TV and cable
broadband internet markets in Slovenia, Serbia and Bosnia and Herzegovina, and to further increase our
market shares, as we differentiate our product offerings through one of the highest download speeds in our


-----

broadband markets, access to desirable media content, a well invested network and high-quality customer
service, which has led to relatively low churn rates which we believe demonstrate customer loyalty. We also
believe that we are well-positioned to continue to grow in our region, and build on our expansion into Bulgaria
and Greece. Our customers view the telecommunications products and services that we offer as part of their
everyday lives, which results in recurring, high demand for our products and makes our business more resilient
to macro-economic disruptions when compared to other discretionary products and services. For example,
during the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic our products and services have been instrumental in providing
connectivity and entertainment, as an increasing number of people began to work or study remotely and
spent significant amounts of time at home, which resulted in a significant increase in our voice and data
traffic between March and May 2020. In particular, over this period, our fixed data traffic increased at rates
between 50% and 70%, while fixed voice traffic increased at rates between 50% and 85%, depending on the
country. In addition, our mobile data and voice traffic increased at rates between 30% and 40%, depending on
the country. Traffic levels decreased during the summer months and started increasing again as new lockdowns
were implemented in various countries. To accommodate such higher customer demand, we increased capacity
on network elements and interconnections. In this recurring, high demand environment, we believe we offer
superior products, faster broadband speeds and higher quality content than many of our competitors.

**Competitive Strengths**

We believe a number of key factors give us a competitive advantage, including:

**_We are the leading multi-play service provider with a pan regional platform across Southeastern Europe._**

We are the leading multi-play telecommunications and media provider in Southeastern Europe, a position
which we have strengthened significantly through the Vivacom Acquisition. Specifically, we are the leading
provider of Pay-TV in our three core markets of Slovenia, Serbia and Bosnia and Herzegovina, and the
leading provider of broadband in Slovenia and Bosnia and Herzegovina, in each case, based on market share
by number of subscribers. We are also the leading provider of broadband and the number three provider of
Pay-TV in Bulgaria based on market share by number of subscribers for the year ended December 31, 2020,
and the second-largest Pay-TV operator in Greece. In addition to our cable-based and satellite-based services,
we offer mobile-telephony services in Slovenia, in Bulgaria and in Croatia. The acquisitions we have made
have delivered significant geographic expansion and diversification of our business into Bulgaria and Greece.
The Vivacom Acquisition, for example, increased our addressable market by 35% in terms of population, and
doubled our existing customer base. Furthermore, our scale and presence across Southeastern Europe and
across our product portfolios allows us to cross-sell our services and expand the number of multi-play
packages we provide, creating opportunities to expand our customer base.

**_We are a recognized media leader benefitting from content ownership, own production and strategic partnerships_**
**_with international and regional broadcasters providing a differentiated Pay-TV offering._**

We believe that we are the recognized media leader in Southeastern Europe, offering fully integrated
production and distribution of attractive and distinctive local content that caters to the whole family. As of
March 31, 2021, we produced 45% of our content locally. Our content seeks to address the entire Southeastern
European region, which has a large population with similar languages, cultures and entertainment preferences
and which we believe forms a single media market. The Vivacom Acquisition and Forthnet Acquisition added
an additional seventeen million people in the region to our addressable market. Our focus on the entire
Southeastern European region allows us to maintain and serve some of the smaller markets where providers
with a smaller scale in comparison to us are less able to provide first rate localized content on an economically
efficient basis. We believe international players would find it difficult and costly to expand into the region, due
to language and cultural barriers. Furthermore, our pan regional operations make it possible for us to enter
into contracts on attractive terms with major sporting leagues and other third-party contract providers to
distribute their content to the entire region with a population, including Bulgaria, of approximately 40 million,


CroatiaCroatia


-----

whereas competitors operating in a single country within the region cannot offer similarly broad coverage. We
are also able to offer our content partners value added services such as providing subtitles for television shows
and can spread the costs across our operations in the entire region, whereas we believe such costs would not be
economically justifiable for a competitor operating within a single country in the region.

Media activities at United Media fall into four categories: channel production, distribution, advertising and
digital. We believe that several factors make us an attractive partner to third-party content owners: our pan
regional presence, large subscriber base, advanced network, cable and DTH platforms and leading market
positions. We also offer attractive advertising services with desirable advertising slots, which we sell to both
local advertisers and high-profile clients from around the world. We work with advertisers to tailor
advertisements to their target audiences, and we have begun to generate revenue from the sale of advertising
across our platforms, particularly in our television stations and on our broadcast and cable networks. We have
also established a digital music production and content distribution business. Following the Nova TV Croatia
Acquisition and Direct Media/Pink Acquisition, we significantly developed our media business by adding
leading full format TV stations in Croatia, Bosnia and Herzegovina and Montenegro. Nova TV Croatia has
strong local content production and profitability, with an audience share of 40% and market share by
advertising revenue of 50% as of December 31, 2020. Nova BH and Nova M have appealing content, such as
popular national team football events until 2022 (Euro Cup qualifiers, Euro Cup, World Cup qualifiers and
League of Nations). In March 2019, we launched Nova S in Serbia. Nova S is a channel offering high-quality
local production series, sports, talk shows with well-known national presenters and high-quality international
productions, fully exclusive to SBB, Total TV and EON. The Nova Broadcasting Group Acquisition makes us
a major content player in Bulgaria.

With our own content, we can control the end-to-end creation process, produce a wide range of attractive
local and genre specific content and maintain a structural hedge on content costs. Our in-house production
has significantly increased over recent years, and the content offered has continually improved, including by
way of the leading Sport Klub channel by adding popular sporting events to our content portfolio, which
includes some of the most popular sports offerings in the region, some of which have been temporarily
suspended and/or postponed during the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. In addition, we have sold distribution
rights for this channel to all major third-party distribution platforms in the region, who pay a recurring
carriage fee. Due to our own distribution platforms and our relationships with all major third-party
distribution platforms in the region, we are able to immediately distribute new channels throughout the region,
including Bulgaria following completion of the Vivacom Acquisition.

**_Low churn rates despite regular price increases demonstrate our loyal customer base and differentiated_**
**_proposition._**

Our business model is attractive and resilient. We believe our portfolio of must have products and our superior
offering have resulted in a growing and loyal customer base with relatively low churn rates, combined with the


**Most importantsports events**


-----

ability to up sell and cross-sell products. Our customers view the telecommunications products and services
that we offer as part of their everyday lives, which results in recurring, high demand for our products and
makes our business more resilient to macro-economic disruptions when compared to other discretionary
products and services. For example, during the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic our products and services have
been instrumental in providing connectivity and entertainment, as an increasing number of people began to
work or study remotely and spend significant amounts of time at home, which resulted in a significant increase
in our voice and data traffic between March and May 2020. In particular, over this period, our fixed data
traffic increased at rates between 50% and 70%, while fixed voice traffic increased at rates between 50% and
85%, depending on the country. In addition, our mobile data and voice traffic increased at rates between 30%
and 40%, depending on the country. To accommodate such higher customer demand, we increased capacity
on network elements and interconnections. In this recurring, high demand environment, we believe we offer
superior products, faster broadband speeds and higher quality content than our competitors. Customer loyalty
is evidenced by our relatively low historical churn rates. Churn rate is defined as the percentage of customers
that no longer subscribe for a certain service compared to the average number of customers in a particular
month. Churn rates for a period of one year or longer are an average of the monthly average churn rate. For
the three months ended March 31, 2021, our unique cable subscriber churn rate annualized was 10%, which is
below recent reported cable subscriber churn rates of certain Western European peers. We believe our relatively
low churn rates provide, among other benefits, recurring cash flows and visibility with respect to future
revenue. Moreover, these churn rates have persisted notwithstanding regular price increases. From 2017, our
Blended Cable ARPU excluding Vivacom has grown from €20.5 for the nine months ended September 30,
2017 to €23.2 for the three months ended March 31, 2021, representing a CAGR of 3.6%. Average triple play
monthly fees have also increased across geographies, from €28 in 2013 to €33 for legacy packages (21% of
triple play base) and €34 for current EON packages (78% of triple play base) in Serbia, from €41 in 2015 to
€46 for legacy packages (28% of triple play base) and €48 for current EON packages (72% of triple play base)
in Slovenia, and from €27 in 2013 to €31 for legacy packages (21% of triple play base) and €32 for current
EON packages (78% of triple play base) in Bosnia and Herzegovina, each for the three months ended
March 31, 2021. In addition, Vivacom’s declining churn rates, together with our experience in driving customer
loyalty, present significant upside potential. For the three months ended March 31, 2021, Vivacom’s mobile
subscriber churn rate was 18% annualized compared to 25% for the year ended December 31, 2017, and its
IPTV subscriber churn rate was 11% annualized compared to 15% for the year ended December 31, 2017.

**_Our business and market positioning benefit from a well invested, advanced cable network infrastructure with a_**
**_broad reach across the region and from national mobile networks in Slovenia, Bulgaria and Croatia._**

We strive to be the most advanced media and telecommunications company in Southeastern Europe. We
operate an advanced proprietary hybrid fiber coaxial (“HFC”) network which is fully bi-directional and
EuroDOCSIS 3.0 enabled, covering all of our homes passed in Serbia, Bosnia and Herzegovina and
Montenegro, and approximately 98% of homes passed in our HFC network in Slovenia as of November 1,
2020 are fully bi-directional. We operate the largest fiber network in the region, comprised of 8,966 kilometers
of backbone and extending 10,119 kilometers across metropolitan regions in Slovenia (approximately 3,506
kilometers), Serbia (approximately 4,907 kilometers), Bosnia and Herzegovina (approximately 1,080
kilometers) and Montenegro (approximately 626 kilometers). We also operate one of the largest fiber networks
in Bulgaria, with 1.7 million (or 58%) of households in the country covered and a fully owned fiber connecting
to major points of presence across Europe. As of March 31, 2021, 91% of our core network was DOCSIS 3.1
ready. With the addition of Vivacom’s cable network, our cable network covers approximately 3.7 million
homes passed, as of March 31, 2021. Our network has an average homes passed per fiber optics node ratio in
the range of approximately 274, 213 and 234 across Slovenia, Serbia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, respectively,
which we believe is unrivalled in Southeastern Europe and compares favorably to other European cable
operators, which average 562 homes passed per node on the basis of comparable peers operating in UK,
Sweden, Spain, Germany and Belgium.

We believe that our cable TV infrastructure allows us to provide higher quality digital TV, high-speed
broadband and fixed-line telephony than other cable operators in our markets. Our EuroDOCSIS 3.0 network
allows us to compete effectively in Slovenia, where fiber to the home (“FttH”) constituted approximately 44%
of the broadband market share as of December 31, 2020. We can match FttH speeds in overlapping markets
and have a service speed advantage in non-FttH areas. In Serbia, our broadband internet speed gives us an
advantage over most of our broadband internet competitors, and we provide broadband speeds of 75-1000
Mbps for the majority of our subscribers in Serbia. We also provide internet download speeds which we
believe compare favorably to the national average in Serbia with our average recorded download speed being
1.8x faster than that of one of our main competitors. Additionally, we also believe that we provide superior
internet download speeds in Slovenia with our average recorded download speed being 2.9x faster than that


-----

of one of our main competitors (which the competitor is only able to offer in certain geographic areas). In
Bosnia and Herzegovina, we are well-positioned to compete with incumbents that primarily use DSL, as well
as with smaller regional cable operators. In Bosnia and Herzegovina, we believe that our average recorded
download speed is 4.5x faster than that of one our main competitors. In Montenegro, we have developed
FttH Gigabit capable Passive Optical Networks (“GPON”) with over 25,438 homes passed and over 5,742
homes connected to this network. Following the Vivacom Acquisition, we operate the largest fiber network in
Bulgaria, providing VDSL with speeds of more than 70 Mbps for more than 50% of our network and more
than 50 Mbps for 74% of our network, with full redundancy capability and high service reliability.

Our mobile network covers the majority of Slovenia’s population through our extensive 2G/3G/4G networks,
and at present we have the capability to provide 4G (LTE) and 4G+ (LTE-A) coverage to approximately 99%
and 98%, respectively, of the Slovenian population. We are also the third largest mobile operator in Bulgaria
by market share, with approximately three million subscribers as of March 31, 2021, and provide LTE mobile
network coverage to 99.94% of the Bulgarian population. We believe Vivacom’s mobile strategy, which
includes attractive tariff plans, flexible service bundles, integrated IT systems and the fastest 4G/LTE mobile
network in Europe, has allowed it to differentiate itself from competitors and consistently gain market share
in recent years. In addition, we are the third largest telecommunications operator in Croatia based on mobile
revenues as of March 31, 2021, with a highly competitive 4G service, a signal covering all major cities and
important roads in Croatia and a growing customer base of nearly one million as of March 31, 2021. To
further develop our networks, we have successfully tested and are rolling out next generation 5G networks
across our mobile-telephony footprint. On September 21, 2020, we announced the commercial launch of our
5G network in Bulgaria, and to that end in May 2021, we secured a 20-year license for 100 MHz spectrum
frequencies in the 3.6 GHz band. We also in April 2021 secured 15-year spectrum licenses in Slovenia for 5G
frequencies, and commenced deployment and commercial launch of 5G 3600 MHz in Slovenia in June 2021.
We are participating in a 5G spectrum auction in Croatia this year.

We believe that our cable network is well invested and benefits from low maintenance UG Adjusted Capital
Expenditure requirements. We believe that this will allow us to manage our UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure
in the near to medium term, with expenditures largely being success and capacity based as our business
expands, while making targeted improvements to our network. We believe that Vivacom has a similarly well
invested network and profile. UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure was €91.3 million for the three months ended
March 31, 2021, and we estimate that UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure for the year ended December 31,
2021 will be between €371 million and €373 million (excluding mobile frequencies and any amounts for
Forthnet, Nova BG or Optima Telekom ).

**_Strong track record of profitable growth driven by low penetration rates and cross-selling opportunities, as well_**
**_as successful integration of acquisitions._**

We have a strong track record of profitable growth, underpinned by low penetration rates in the markets in
which we operate and cross-selling opportunities due to our scale, as well as a record of successfully integrating
acquisitions. We operate most of our business across the following eight countries in Southeastern Europe:
Slovenia, Serbia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Bulgaria, Croatia, Greece, North Macedonia and Montenegro.
These countries are characterized by growing Pay-TV and broadband markets that are currently
underpenetrated relative to some other CEE and Western European markets. Following the Forthnet
Acquisition we also operate in Greece. As of March 31, 2021, in Slovenia, our Pay-TV penetration of homes
passed and broadband internet penetration were 61% and 89%, respectively; in Serbia, Pay-TV penetration
and broadband internet penetration were 65% and 73%, respectively; and in Bosnia and Herzegovina, Pay-TV
penetration and broadband internet penetration were 61% and 81%, respectively. Additionally, due to
historically strong regulatory constraints on bundling Pay-TV, broadband internet and telephony services,
RGUs per cable subscriber in our key markets in Serbia, Slovenia and Bosnia and Herzegovina have lagged
behind CEE and Western European cable markets. Markets in Bulgaria have similar characteristics. Our cable
RGUs per subscriber ratios of 2.3x for Serbia, 2.7x for Slovenia and 2.3x for Bosnia and Herzegovina, in each
case as of March 31, 2021, demonstrate that there are strong opportunities to continue to utilize up selling
and cross-selling opportunities to grow our cable RGUs per subscriber ratio in Slovenia.

At the same time, Pay-TV penetration in all of our markets has been growing, driven by increasingly attractive
content and bundled offers. Service penetration in our markets has increased as multi-play packages have
expanded but is still below the levels of some Western European cable markets (except in Slovenia). Leveraging
our extensive cable infrastructure, we use our high-quality Pay-TV content as a basis to cross and up sell our
broadband internet and telephony products to existing cable Pay-TV customers and offer multi-play packages
to new customers, which we expect will allow us to continue to improve penetration rates as customers
increasingly focus on the convenience of receiving their multimedia and communications services in a bundled
offer from one provider. For example, while penetration rates in Slovenia are more comparable to those of
Western European operators, a substantial number of our subscribers in Slovenia are subscribed to a single
service, which we believe offers significant cross-selling opportunities. Our number of quad-play subscribers
in Slovenia has grown since we began offering mobile services in late 2012 as an MVNO, and, since the
acquisition of Tušmobil in April 2015, we have increased the number of quad-play subscribers in Slovenia,
from 1% in April 2015 to 38% as of March 31, 2021.

In addition to organic growth, we have made targeted and value accretive investments and acquisitions of
attractive cable and mobile assets, and we have been successful at integrating these acquisitions and realizing
synergies related to a number of these acquisitions, providing lessons learned and significant know-how for
integrating Vivacom, Forthnet, Nova BG and Tele2 Croatia. For example, our acquisition of Telemach
Slovenia from Liberty Global in 2009, a foray into a new market with a different language and culture, proved
to be a successful cross border acquisition story. Within a decade, we tripled blended cable ARPU of Telemach
Slovenia (from €13 in 2008, to €35 in 2018) and adjusted EBITDA (from €24 million in 2008, to €71 million in
2018), while revenue grew from €46 million in 2008 to €1.2 billion in the year ended December 31, 2020. This
was achieved through both organic growth and the acquisition of Tušmobil in April 2015 which provided us
with an opportunity to create a fully convergent cable, internet, fixed-line and mobile-telephony operator in
Slovenia, and allowed Slovenian customers to benefit from a convenient bundled product offering consisting
of cable Pay-TV, internet, fixed-line and mobile-telephony services from a single provider.

**_We have a track record of delivering revenue and UG Adjusted EBITDA growth and realizing cost synergies_**
**_related to our acquisitions while generating strong UG Adjusted EBITDA margins._**

Our revenues have historically proven to be resilient, even during periods of challenging economic conditions.
During the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, almost all of our revenue streams have proven resilient and stable,
particularly those generated by our telecommunication business segments, such as broadband internet and
mobile-telephony. Since 2018, we have increased RGUs from 3.8 million as of December 31, 2018, to
10.9 million as of March 31, 2021, and we have delivered strong organic growth in both revenue and UG
Adjusted EBITDA during such period, significantly outperforming GDP growth in the countries in which we
operate. In addition to organic growth, we have benefitted from targeted and value accretive investments and
acquisitions of attractive cable and mobile assets, and have been successful in integrating these acquisitions


-----

and realizing synergies related to them. Our revenue increased to €439 million for the three months ended
March 31, 2021, compared to €194 million for the three months ended March 31, 2020, and UG Adjusted
EBITDA increased to €179 million for the three months ended March 31, 2021, compared to €85 million for
the three months ended March 31, 2020. We have also proven our ability to generate strong adjusted EBITDA
margins. Despite investments in new ventures, we had operating profit margin of 11% and 7% for the
three months ended March 31, 2020 and 2021, respectively, and maintained UG Adjusted EBITDA margins
of 44% and 41% for the three months ended March 31, 2020 and 2021, respectively, highlighting our successful
approach to integrating new businesses and driving profitability.

**_A highly experienced management team with a proven track record of supporting and growing our business_**
**_and successfully integrating accretive, cross border acquisitions, with a highly committed Sponsor._**

Many of our key management members have been with the business since its inception, including our founder
and chairman of the advisory board, Dragan Šolak; chief executive officer and group vice president of
marketing and media, Victoriya Boklag; and group vice president of operations, Violeta Vasilijević. Our
senior management team also includes Janez Živko, group vice president of finance, who joined in March 2015
and had previously served as the chief financial officer of the Petrol Group, one of the largest companies in
Slovenia; Vladislav Ratajac, group vice president of corporate development, joined management in 2011,
having previously held positions at Mid Europa Partners and Deutsche Bank; Željko Batistić, group vice
president of technology who joined the group in 2012 as CEO of Telemach Bosnia and prior to that held a
number of technical and operational management positions in the industry; and Dragica Pilipović Chaffey,
group vice president of corporate affairs, joined the management team in 2009 and had previously held a
number of senior posts in the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development. Other members of our
senior management team also have substantial experience in the telecommunications, media and technology
industry, as well as in banking, private equity and corporate finance firms. Many members of our senior
management team, including our founder, have each held different positions within our business and have
shaped the direction of our development and growth within Southeastern Europe. As our operations have
become more mature, the senior management team has been positioned to leverage its significant industry
experience and corporate background and to successfully expand our business through bolt on acquisitions
and integration of cable assets and content companies. Furthermore, certain members of management hold
significant equity stakes in the business, which amount to approximately 42%. See “Principal Shareholders.”
Due in part to the significant international experience of most members of the senior management team, who
either attended university abroad or worked internationally for a prolonged period of time, we have
successfully grown our business from being a single country Pay-TV operator to being the telecommunications
and media services leader in Southeastern Europe.

We also intend to draw from the market expertise, business relationships, knowledge and experience of our
sponsor, BC Partners. BC Partners has strong telecommunications expertise and an extensive and successful
track record of investing in companies in Europe and in the telecommunications and information sectors
through portfolio companies that include:

- Advanced Computer Software Group, which is a leading UK provider of critical software to mid-sized
companies and public sector organizations;

- NAVEX Global, which is the global leader in ethics and compliance software as a service provider;

- Suddenlink Communications, which was the seventh largest cable operator by subscribers in the United
States prior to its acquisition by Altice USA in 2015, and which BC Partners fully exited in 2020;

- Com Hem, Sweden’s leading cable TV and broadband operator, which was successfully floated on the
Nasdaq Stockholm exchange in 2014 and which BC Partners fully exited in 2017; and

- Unitymedia, an integrated telecoms service provider and the second-largest cable company in Germany,
which BC Partners sold to Liberty Global in 2009 after growing the business through acquisitions and
operational improvements.

BC Partners has a strong track record of driving cost savings and improvements in margin, while at the same
time growing its portfolio companies both organically and through targeted acquisitions.

**Strategy**

Our goal is to strengthen our telecommunications and media leadership position in Southeastern Europe and
to continue our strong growth momentum by successfully integrating Vivacom, Tele2 Croatia, Forthnet,
Nova BG, Optima Telekom and other acquisitions and by leveraging our competitive strengths: well invested


-----

fixed and mobile networks, differentiated content offerings and local production capabilities and a loyal
customer base. Our focus is on continuing to provide our customers the best products and services in each of
our segments and markets, including more innovative products and features, a superior customer experience
and better value compared to competitors. In parallel, our goals are to continue to deliver exceptional revenue
growth across segments (both organically and through strategic acquisitions) and capitalize on operating
leverage and continued operating efficiencies to deliver strong profitability and cash flow growth.

In order to achieve these goals, we have identified the following strategic pillars:

**_Continued focus on our competitive market position by leveraging our advanced network, differentiated_**
**_content offerings and loyal customer base._**

We have differentiated ourselves with our customers by having superior next generation infrastructure in our
footprint. Where we believe the return on investment is appropriate, we will continue to expand the coverage
and capacity of those networks, including 5G capability. Our strategy is to continue to offer the most attractive
products in Southeastern Europe with better content choice, speed, functionality and service quality than
those of our competitors, at prices that provide a compelling value. We will continue to deliver value to our
customers based on a consistent and effective strategy that is underpinned by simplicity, value for money and
innovation. We believe that our acquisitions of Vivacom, Tele2 Croatia, Forthnet, Nova BG and Optima
Telekom are in line with a strategy of expanding coverage in Southeastern Europe and will enable the
development of our business in attractive markets.

**_Increase service penetration across the region by cross-selling products and services and up selling value adding_**
**_products to existing customers._**

We intend to continue to focus on subscriber growth opportunities in our relatively under penetrated markets.
Over time, we expect our businesses in Serbia and Bosnia and Herzegovina to converge with Slovenia in terms
of broadband and Pay-TV penetration as well as in service penetration (measured by RGU per subscriber).

We aim to achieve an increase in triple play (and in the case of Slovenia and Bulgaria, quad-play) penetration
by continuing to shift focus in marketing and subscriber interactions from single services to bundled services
and utilizing next generation digital television services, attractive local content and high-speed broadband
services to continue to promote bundled services. We have significantly grown our mobile business and
developed our multi-play (including quad-play) offering in Slovenia, and we intend to continue to build on
that success in Bulgaria, where the Vivacom Acquisition has significantly expanded our addressable market,
and provide further opportunities for cross-selling and multi-play bundling. In particular, we intend to leverage
Vivacom’s high-quality 4G/LTE network to expand its leadership in mobile data and build on its track record
of subscriber growth. In addition, we aim to retain and grow Vivacom’s existing customer base by competing
on value, for example, by offering more add on products, incentivizing longer term contracts by offering
better pricing and subsidies for certain products, offering bundled services to decrease churn, including
premium Pay-TV services and providing FTTx solutions in larger cities to satisfy customer demand for high
broadband speeds.

We also intend to capitalize on our superior high-speed broadband capabilities to increase revenue. Specifically,
we intend to migrate our existing high-speed broadband subscribers to higher speeds, which we believe will
continue to support broadband ARPU growth and further reduce residential subscriber churn rates. In
addition, recent acquisitions have enhanced our ability to monetize premium content, cross promote and
generate compelling cost synergies.

**_Consolidate United Media as the leading media company in Southeastern Europe._**

Since inception, our strategy has been centered on differentiating our offering by producing superior and/or
exclusive Pay-TV channels for our customers. We have applied this philosophy to all of our Group companies
with great success, and we have created an attractive portfolio of full format national as well as specialized,
thematic Pay-TV channels that we believe are a must have on all regional distribution platforms. Following the
Vivacom Acquisition, with the integration of Vivacom and Nova BG into our operations, we are applying
this philosophy in Bulgaria. We intend to continue to grow our content offering by further developing our
portfolio of owned content, entering into strategic partnerships with third-party content owners and acquiring
content owners, as in the past with the acquisition of Nova TV Croatia and Direct Media/Pink.

**_Further expand our addressable market by utilizing our OTT platform and attractive content._**

Leveraging our strong brands and our attractive content, we intend to continue to develop our two OTT
content platforms, our regional OTT platform, EON, and our international OTT platform, NetTV Plus, to


-----

further expand our addressable market to areas outside our cable footprint. While our DTH Pay-TV platform
aims to deliver our content to subscribers in rural areas in our markets without cable infrastructure, our
regional OTT platform enables customers in metropolitan areas outside of our cable footprint, who have
subscribed to the broadband internet services of our competitors, to access our attractive portfolio of Pay-TV
channels and unique user interface and customer experience. Additionally, NetTV Plus allows us to provide
over 200 local language channels showing ethnic content to the entire ex-Yugoslav diaspora around the world.
By expanding our geographic reach outside of Southeastern Europe to customers in countries in Western
Europe and North America, we believe that we are positioned to further increase our RGU base and earnings
potential. We also plan to further invest in our in-house development of customer premises equipment,
including OTT TV boxes for EON, which enables video streaming to customers’ TVs and allows us to offer
services on competitors’ broadband networks.

**_Continued focus on innovation._**

We seek to continue innovating and enhancing our product offering to further strengthen our leading position
in Southeastern Europe. Our in-house technology innovation and software development center, United.Cloud,
enables us to focus on leading the introduction of next generation television and broadband internet services
by delivering to subscribers services such as EON (our next generation video delivery platform that includes
linear and non-linear digital broadcasting, over 22,000 VoD assets, CatchUp TV, a Smart TV application for
Samsung and LG and a multiscreen service for mobile, tablet and personal computer/laptop devices),
UNIFON (our proprietary VoIP application connecting customers’ fixed-line telephones outside of their
homes), our self-help application, enhanced TV features such as VoD and CatchUp TV services and many
others. We will also continue to promote the digitalization of internal and external processes to improve
customer satisfaction and profitability. In July 2020, we leveraged our position in both the broadband and
Pay-TV markets to launch Shoppster, our regional e-commerce online-shopping platform, which will initially
offer more than 20 popular product categories, including electronics, home and gardening, tools, fashion,
items for children and kitchen appliances. We intend for Shoppster to deliver the simple, reliable and secure
e-shopping experience that modern consumers expect.

**_Continue to grow customer base and operations through value accretive acquisitions._**

We have a successful track record of making acquisitions on attractive terms and successfully integrating
those acquisitions. Between 2011 and March 31, 2021, we have acquired and integrated (or are in the process
of integrating) approximately 50 cable TV operators, content platforms, media companies, mobile service
providers, B2B service providers and internet service providers (“ISPs”) in Slovenia, Serbia, Bosnia and
Herzegovina, Bulgaria, Greece, Croatia and Montenegro. We have also expanded our addressable market
through the Vivacom Acquisition and Nova Broadcasting Group Acquisition (in Bulgaria), the Forthnet
Acquisition (in Greece) and the Optima Telekom Acquisition (in Croatia), as well as various other recent
acquisitions. Our acquisition strategy consists of expanding our scale in a value accretive manner, enhancing
our content offering, expanding our fixed-line and mobile-telephony operations and leveraging our experience
and successful acquisition history to continue to make acquisitions that allow us to generate additional value
for our operations through increasing scale and product offerings.

We plan to continue to make value accretive acquisitions at attractive multiples to integrate regional service
providers, cable assets and fixed-line and mobile-telephony operators into the business, and we intend to
continue taking a disciplined approach to acquisitions by assessing individual opportunities on the basis of
merit, ability to integrate assets into our existing business plans and potential for value creation.

**_Continue to Focus on Environmental, Social and Corporate Governance (“ESG”) Matters_**

We and our shareholders recognize that achieving a sustainable and responsible business that has a positive
social impact will be key to our future success. As we have grown our Group, we have increased our emphasis
on integrating ESG considerations into our decision-making and reporting processes. In 2020, we established
a dedicated ESG coordinator role within the Group and finalized a detailed ESG action plan and
implementation roadmap in consultation with external advisors.

To promote environmental sustainability in our operations, we are taking active steps to minimize our
environmental footprint, while also collecting and analyzing Group historical data to set future KPI targets
for reductions in carbon emissions, climate change policy, energy use and energy sourcing. We have committed
to the Science Based Targets initiative which helps to drive climate action in the private sector by enabling
companies to set emissions reduction targets with scientific data. We are committed to reducing greenhouse
gas emissions across our offices and infrastructure and we established a solar power plant in Slovenia in 2019


-----

with an annual production capacity of 254 kWh and have leveraged our experience in this project to look for
additional green energy projects which could cover a significant part of our carbon emission footprint. In
addition, we use electric vehicles in our operations where feasible, and we work to exchange old, less-energy
efficient equipment for more energy-efficient devices. In 2020, we generated approximately 128.1 thousand
tons of CO2 emissions (9.3 thousand tons of scope 1 emissions and 118.8 thousand tons of scope 2 and
3 emissions), including the contribution of acquired companies, and we intend to reduce these to
approximately 50.6 thousand tons by 2030. In 2020, we recycled 1,539 tons of network telecom equipment,
batteries, cables, paper and cardboard. We are also committed to minimizing waste and we repurpose, reuse or
recycle 100% of returned customer devices and accessories.

We actively support the communities in which we operate, and in 2020, we named a Group-level director for
corporate social responsibility to coordinate efforts in this regard among our operating companies. We have
as a Group donated €4.5 million in 2020 and €2.0 million for the twelve months ended March 31, 2021, to
groups and activities dedicated to protecting the environment, education and the socially vulnerable, as well
as other donations, such as donating personal protective equipment to help fight COVID-19. We have also
engaged in multiple community engagement activities in the past few years, with a focus on using our platform
to deliver knowledge to children (including programs for online safety), students, the general public and
disadvantaged groups, by leveraging our core competencies in broadband internet and other
telecommunications. For 2021, we aim to increase the percentage of staff participating in a community
engagement activity (e.g., volunteering time or knowledge), which in 2020 stood at 7%.

We focus on building a safe, fair and inclusive working environment for our employees. To inform our diversity,
inclusion and safety targets, we collect data on our workforce, such as gender mix (55% male, 45% female),
percentage of women in management positions (30%, including our Chief Executive Officer) and percentage
of disabled employees (1%), in each case as of March 31, 2021. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2021,
staff total turnover is 12% and we have experienced 50 workplace injury incidents. We also have mandated
diversity and inclusion rules, and have documented these in employee manuals at our Group companies,
which include, among others, statutory requirements related to workers’ rights and human rights (e.g., antidiscrimination and anti-mobbing) and annual employee Net Promoter Score (“eNPS”) measurements. To
facilitate further transparency and accountability, we plan to expand our anonymous suggestion boxes already
present in certain of our Group companies and establish whistle-blowing programs as a distinct transparency
function. We also offer training programs to employees which are focused on improving job-related technical
and management skills, as well as on compliance with our internal policies.

**Sponsor**

BC Partners is a leading global investment firm that is currently investing its eleventh flagship private equity
fund. BC Partners has continually operated for over three decades, with beginnings in Europe and expanding
to North America as a core focus more than a decade ago. They have invested from 11 successive funds
totaling over €30 billion of committed capital, with 122 private equity investments representing €160 billion
of transaction value completed across 18 countries. BC Partners operates across five core sectors including
business & financial services, consumer & retail, industrials, healthcare and TMT and employs 66 private
equity professionals operating from four offices: New York, London, Paris and Hamburg.

**Recent Developments**

**_COVID-19 Impact on Revenues and Adjusted EBITDA_**

Based on our analysis, we estimate that the COVID-19 pandemic had a minimal impact of approximately 1-2%
to organic consolidated revenues during 2020 as compared to 2019 and during the three months ended
March 31, 2021 compared to the three months ended March 31, 2020. The revenue streams most negatively
affected include advertising, media selling and mobile handsets sales. Following the COVID-19 outbreak in
March 2020, we implemented cost optimization initiatives and managed our capital expenditure plans in
response to the pandemic, but we did so in a way that would not hinder our ability for future growth and
quality of services provided.

Our telecommunications segments have continued to meet customers’ expectations on service level and our
network operating centers have maintained normal service levels. Based on this, no significant change in our
customer base occurred. As customers were unlikely or unable to easily migrate during the crisis, in 2020 we
experienced somewhat lower gross adds and churn rates, with our operations normalizing during 2021.
Organic revenues and UG Adjusted EBITDA in our telecommunications segment remained stable during
2020 compared to the previous year.


-----

During the first waves of lockdowns imposed in response to the COVID-19 pandemic between March and
May 2020, as an increasing number of people began to work or study remotely and spend significant amounts
of time at home, we saw a significant increase in our voice and data traffic. In particular, over this period, our
fixed data traffic increased at rates between 50% and 70%, while fixed voice traffic increased at rates between
50% and 85%, depending on the country. In addition, our mobile data and voice traffic increased at rates
between 30% and 40%, depending on the country. To accommodate such higher customer demand, we
increased capacity on network elements and interconnections.

In our Media segment, we estimate that organic revenue in the segment declined by approximately 5-6% for
the year ended December 31, 2020 compared to the previous year. This decline was due in part to the
postponement of certain sporting events and a decline in advertising revenue, partially offset by a decline in
relevant costs. Overall, supported by cost optimization efforts, UG Adjusted EBITDA in the Media segment
remained broadly stable year on year prior to giving effect to the Nova Broadcasting Group Acquisition.
During the three months ended March 31, 2021, we have seen levels of organic advertising increasing and
surpassing pre-COVID levels.

Throughout the pandemic, we have continued to grow the Group through acquisitions, completing the
acquisitions of Tele2 Croatia (completed in March 2020), Vivacom (completed in July 2020), Forthnet
(completed in November 2020) and Nova BG (completed in January 2021). The impact of COVID-19 on
these acquired companies is similar to that of the Group’s existing telecommunications operations. The
expected contribution of the acquired companies has not materially changed given the crisis and all such
acquired companies are performing in line with or above our expectations.

**_Acquisition of Optima Telekom_**

On July 9, 2021, we announced that we signed an agreement to acquire a majority interest of 54.31% in
Croatian telecom operation Optima Telekom, for an estimated purchase price of €85 million based on an
enterprise value of HRK 639 million, from Hrvatski Telekom and Zagrebacka Banka. Optima Telekom offers
a broad range of fixed broadband internet services to approximately 117 thousand subscribers and pay-TV
services to approximately 57 thousand subscribers in Croatia. Completion of the Optima Telekom Acquisition
is expected for the end of 2021 and is subject to customary conditions as well as the implementation of certain
changes in the current Croatian telecommunication legislation relating to vertical integration between pay-TV
broadcasters and distributors, and thus there can be no assurance that the acquisition will be completed by
such expected date or at all. Once completed, the acquisition of Optima Telekomwill allow us to further
expand our presence in the Croatian market enabling Telemach Croatia to offer a full range of
telecommunication services, including pay-TV, through its existing infrastructure. Optima Telekom had
estimated last two quarters annualized adjusted EBITDA for March 31, 2021 of €16.8 million. Following
completion of the Optima TelekomAcquisition, we expect to be required to undertake a tender offer for the
remaining shares of Optima Telekom not yet acquired.

**_Existing Revolving Credit Facility 2021 Increase_**

On or about the Issue Date, the Company expects to receive additional commitments from certain lenders in
respect of the Existing Revolving Credit Facility in an aggregate amount up to €75 million, increasing the
total commitments under the Existing Revolving Credit Facility from €250 million up to €325 million.

**_Recent Trading_**

Based on preliminary results from our unaudited management accounts for the two-month period ended
May 31, 2021, and other information currently available, we estimate that our revenue for the two months
ended May 31, 2021 will be between €309.2 million and €313.2 million, compared to €144.1 million for the
corresponding period of 2020. Estimated revenue of United Group increased compared to the prior-year
period due to the significant impacts of the Vivacom Acquisition, the Forthnet Acquisition and the Nova
Broadcasting Group Acquisition, none of which were included in such prior-year period. We estimate that
EBITDA for United Group for the two-month period ended May 31, 2021 (excluding any adjustments), will
be between €131.7 million and €135.7 million compared to €62.0 million for the two-month period ended
May 31, 2020.
