**Our Business Overview**

We are the leading cable and media player in Southeastern Europe, providing services to approximately
3.7 million homes as of March 31, 2021. We are the leading distributor of Pay-TV in our core markets of
Slovenia, Serbia, Bosnia and Herzegovina and the number two distributor in Montenegro. As of March 31,
2021, we provided services to approximately 10.9 million RGUs and analog and digital cable Pay-TV services
to approximately 1.9 million unique subscribers. United Group’s revenue for the three months ended
March 31, 2021 was €439.4 million and UG Adjusted EBITDA was €179.2 million. The Group had Run-Rate
Revenue for the annualized last two quarters ended March 31, 2021 of €1,916.4 million and Run-Rate Last
Two Quarter Annualized Adjusted EBITDA for March 31, 2021 was €706.3 million.

The Combined Group is the clear multi-play leader in its footprint, with market leading positions in Pay-TV,
broadband internet and fixed-line and mobile-telephony in Slovenia, Serbia, Bosnia and Herzegovina,
Montenegro, North Macedonia, Bulgaria, Croatia and, following the Forthnet Acquisition, Greece. The
Combined Group’s addressable market comprised 13.4 million households as of December 31, 2020.

We have grown rapidly through both acquisitions and organic growth. In July 2020, we acquired Vivacom, the
market leading integrated telecommunications operator in Bulgaria, based on total revenue for the year ended
December 31, 2020, which is the leading operator in fixed-line telephony services and broadband services, the
number three provider of mobile-telephony services and the number three provider of Pay-TV, in each case,
by number of subscribers as of March 31, 2021. The Vivacom Acquisition increased our addressable market
by approximately 35% in terms of population, and the addition of Vivacom’s subscriber base more than
doubled our existing subscriber base. In March 2020, we also acquired Tele2 Croatia, the third largest
telecommunications operator in Croatia, based on mobile revenues as of March 31, 2021, through which we
offer mobile services in Croatia. In November 2020, we completed the acquisition of a controlling interest in
Forthnet S.A., a prominent telecom operator and Pay-TV provider in Greece, which marked our entry into
the Greek market and will strengthen our position as an industry leader in Southeastern Europe. In
January 2021, we acquired Bulgaria’s largest multi-platform media company, Nova Broadcasting Group
EOOD, from Advance Media Group EAD, providing a strong base for our content offering in Bulgaria. In
July 2021, we signed an agreement to acquire a majority interest in Optima Telekom, a Croatian telecom
operator offering a broad range of fixed internet and pay-TV services. Subject to its completion, the Optima
Telekom Acquisition will allow us to further expand our presence in the Croatian market and offer a full range
of telecommunication services, including pay-TV, through our existing infrastructure in the country.

We offer a diverse and differentiated line of products and services. We are the leading distributor of satellite
(“DTH”) Pay-TV across Southeastern Europe, with Pay-TV product and service offerings in each of Slovenia,
Serbia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, North Macedonia and Montenegro, where we use our Total TV platform to
serve subscribers both inside and outside of our cable footprint to deliver content across the entire region,
including rural areas. Following the Vivacom Acquisition, we also provide Pay-TV services in Bulgaria and
are the leading IPTV provider in Bulgaria, while the Nova Broadcasting Group Acquisition strengthened our
content offering in Bulgaria. Following the Forthnet Acquisition, we also provide cable and DTH services in
Greece. In addition to our cable-based and satellite-based services, we offer mobile-telephony services in
Slovenia, Bulgaria and Croatia. We provide 4G LTE coverage to almost the entire population in each of these
countries, and we are rolling out 5G networks across our mobile-telephony footprint. On September 21, 2020,
we announced the commercial launch of our 5G network in Bulgaria, and to that end in May 2021, we
secured a 20-year license for 100 MHz spectrum frequencies in the 3.6 GHz band. We also in April 2021


-----

secured 15-year spectrum licenses in Slovenia for 5G frequencies, and commenced deployment and
commercial launch of 5G 3600 MHz in Slovenia in June 2021. We are participating in a 5G spectrum auction
in Croatia this year.

Our core telecommunications business is also complemented by our two OTT distribution platforms that
customers can access through internet based streaming: EON, our regional OTT platform, which enables
customers connected to our competitors’ broadband internet connections outside of our cable footprint to
access our attractive portfolio of Pay-TV channels, and NetTV Plus, our international OTT platform, which
delivers ethnic and local language content to the ex-Yugoslav diaspora around the world. In July 2020, we
launched Shoppster, our regional e-commerce online-shopping platform, which offers more than 20 popular
product categories, including electronics, home and gardening, tools, fashion, items for children and kitchen
appliances. Shoppster is available as an integrated online and TV shopping platform in Serbia and Slovenia.

Through our in-house content business, we produce distinctive and attractive in-house media content for our
Pay-TV channels across multiple key genres that have historically driven Pay-TV subscriptions. These channels
include Southeastern Europe’s most popular family of branded Pay-TV sports channels, as well as popular
movie channels, children’s channels, a 24/7 news channel, music channels and other specialized channels,
which we continue to expand both organically and through acquisitions. We currently produce over 40% of
the total content in our national (terrestrial) and cable operations, and our programs typically receive ratings
of between 30% to 60% in the markets in which they are available. The Group also has in-house media and
content production in Greece. We believe that our market leading content portfolio differentiates us from our
competitors, has enabled strong growth in our business and provides us with predictable third-party carriage
fees.

As part of our media business, we also provide advertising services and digital production and distribution.
Our Nova TV Croatia channel has strong local content production and profitability, with an audience share
of 40% and market share by advertising revenue of 50%. Nova BH and Nova M have appealing content, such
as popular national team football events until 2022, such as the Euro Cup qualifiers, Euro Cup, World Cup
qualifiers and League of Nations. In March 2019, we launched Nova S in Serbia. Nova S is a channel offering
high-quality local production series, sports, talk shows with well-known national presenters and high-quality
international productions, fully exclusive to SBB, Total TV and EON. The Nova Broadcasting Group
Acquisition makes us a major content player in Bulgaria by adding Nova BG’s media platform comprising
ten television channels, including NOVA TV, which broadcasts throughout Bulgaria, Bulgaria’s largest online
platform, Net Info, which reaches on average 80% of the Bulgarian population each month, and four radio
stations.

In addition to our own content, as a result of our pan regional presence and well established distribution
network, we are a distribution partner of choice for premium regional and international content owners, such
as Discovery/Eurosport, Viacom, AXN, CNN, HBO, Fox and Universal, and sports rights owners, such as
the English Premier League, Spanish Football League LaLiga, 2020 UEFA European Championship
qualifiers, 2020 UEFA European Championship, 2022 FIFA World Cup qualifiers, UEFA League of Nations,
ATP, Formula 1, Euroleague, and Moto GP, which we believe allows us to consistently obtain high-quality
content and attractive payment terms. Nova BG holds licenses to offer compelling content in Bulgaria through
distributors such as CBS Intenrational, the Walt Disney Company, Columbia Pictures and Paramount
Pictures, as well as popular sports content such as the English Premier League football, Euro Cup qualifiers
and the Euro Cup and Formula One racing. We believe these providers partner with us because of our
well-known brands, large network and our focus on Southeastern Europe.

We operate most of our business across eight countries in Southeastern Europe: Slovenia, Serbia, Bosnia and
Herzegovina, Bulgaria, Croatia, North Macedonia, Montenegro and Greece. These countries have a
combined population of approximately 40 million, distributed across approximately 13.4 million households
as of December 31, 2020, and represent the second-largest CEE market after Poland. Despite economic
differences, many of these countries share a joint history and form a single market in which small local
differences are overshadowed by the influence of similarities in cultural preferences and language across the
region and are characterized by growing Pay-TV and broadband markets that are currently underpenetrated
relative to some other CEE and Western European markets.

We are the leading multi-play provider in Slovenia, Serbia, Bosnia and Herzegovina and Bulgaria, where we
combine our services into packages, or bundles, which offer subscribers the convenience of being able to
purchase television, broadband internet and telephony services from a single provider, and provides us with
significant opportunities to cross-sell our products.


-----

We believe that we are well-positioned to maintain our market leading positions in the Pay-TV and cable
broadband internet markets in Slovenia, Serbia and Bosnia and Herzegovina, and to further increase our
market shares, as we differentiate our product offerings through one of the highest download speeds in our
broadband markets, access to desirable media content, a well invested network and high-quality customer
service, which has led to relatively low churn rates which we believe demonstrate customer loyalty. We also
believe that we are well-positioned to continue to grow in our region, and build on our expansion into Bulgaria
and Greece. Our customers view the telecommunications products and services that we offer as part of their
everyday lives, which results in recurring, high demand for our products and makes our business more resilient
to macro-economic disruptions when compared to other discretionary products and services. For example,
during the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic our products and services have been instrumental in providing
connectivity and entertainment, as an increasing number of people began to work or study remotely and
spent significant amounts of time at home, which resulted in a significant increase in our voice and data
traffic between March and May 2020. In particular, over this period, our fixed data traffic increased at rates
between 50% and 70%, while fixed voice traffic increased at rates between 50% and 85%, depending on the
country. In addition, our mobile data and voice traffic increased at rates between 30% and 40%, depending on
the country. Traffic levels decreased during the summer months and started increasing again as new lockdowns
were implemented in various countries. To accommodate such higher customer demand, we increased capacity
on network elements and interconnections. In this recurring, high demand environment, we believe we offer
superior products, faster broadband speeds and higher quality content than many of our competitors.

**Key Factors Affecting Our Business and Results of Operations**

The performance of our businesses, our results of operations and the key operating measures discussed below
have been, and will continue to be, affected by a variety of factors. Certain of these factors are discussed
below.

**_Products, Services and Content_**

Our results are impacted by our product mix as well as our ability to introduce new products and upgrades
and successfully sell those products and upgrades to increase our RGUs and ARPUs. We continually evaluate
the suite of products and services we provide to our subscribers to ensure that we remain competitive with
other providers in our markets and have an opportunity to increase our subscriber base and the number of
products we sell to our subscribers. We accomplish this through product innovation, investments in technology
and acquisitions of complementary businesses. For example, we have expanded our product offering by
introducing fixed-line services to offer multi-play packages in Slovenia, Serbia, Bosnia and Herzegovina and
Montenegro, including pay television, broadband internet access, fixed-line telephony, as well as mobiletelephony services in Slovenia and following the completion of the acquisition of Tele2 Croatia in March 2020,
in Croatia. Following completion of the Vivacom Acquisition in July 2020, we also offer pay television,
broadband internet access, fixed-line telephony, and mobile-telephony services in Bulgaria. Following the
Forthnet Acquisition in November 2020, we also offer telecommunications and Pay-TV services in Greece.

We believe that media and communications services customers will increasingly choose bundled products
because of the convenience and enhanced value resulting from obtaining TV, broadband internet and
telephony services from a single provider for one price. As of March 31, 2021, 85% of our customer base in
Slovenia, 79% of our customer base in Serbia, 87% of our customer base in Bosnia and Herzegovina and 54%
of our customer base in Bulgaria subscribed for one of our multi-play packages (our customer base is
calculated based on unique cable subscribers by bundle).

We seek to be the leader in our markets in pay television content and have entered into long-term strategic
partnerships with key international and regional content owners. We have also acquired leading regional
content owners in key television sub-segments (sports, lifestyle, children and films), such as providers of the
Sport Klub family of channels (which includes Sport Klub, Golf Klub and our fishing and hunting channels),
N1, Fight Channel, Pikaboo and Cinemania. Our ability to maintain the quality of our content impacts our
ability to sell our pay television offerings, as well as bundled packages.

Our product mix can also impact our margins. For example, our mobile-telephony business and our content
business generally have lower margins compared to our cable-based business. Our success in growing these
businesses may impact our product mix and therefore may affect UG Adjusted EBITDA margins.

**_Pricing of Our Products and Services_**

Increasing demand for attractive content and higher broadband speeds allows us to increase the prices at
which we provide these services while maintaining relatively low churn rates. We regularly review the prices of


-----

our products and services, however, and in the past have adjusted our subscription fees as necessary in line
with inflation, changes in foreign exchange rates or in response to market conditions and content costs.
Changes in the pricing of our products and services will impact the revenues and margins that we generate
from these products and services and impact our ability to attract new customers. For example, our multi-play
bundles offer subscribers higher value in terms of channels, speeds functionality and add on features. The
pricing of all our services, including our multi-play bundles, is dependent on market conditions, pricing by
competitors with similar offerings and the perceived quality of our products versus other products. In relation
to our Basic TV package, we were also subject to price regulation in Serbia until January 2017. From
January 2017, the price of our Basic TV package in Serbia is no longer subject to price regulation. However,
such price regulation might be reinstated in the future, and we regularly monitor the media market in Serbia
to stay aware of market conditions which may lead to price regulation.

**_Subscriber Churn_**

The television, broadband internet and telephony industries exhibit churn as a result of high levels of
competition. In addition to competitive alternatives, churn levels may be affected by changes in our prices or
our competitors’ prices, our level of subscriber satisfaction, subscriber mortality and the relocation of
subscribers, as well as from the termination of agreements. An increase in churn may lead to increased costs
and reduced revenues when subscribers cancel our services as we incur additional marketing and advertising
costs to find new subscribers.

Increasing demand for attractive content and higher broadband speeds allows us to increase the prices at
which we provide these services while maintaining relatively low churn rates. We believe our relatively low
churn rates provide us with recurring cash flows and visibility with respect to future revenues. We have
historically experienced low churn rates in our television, broadband internet and fixed-line telephony
businesses, and the churn we have experienced in these businesses has primarily been driven by customers
moving outside of our current geographic area of services as well as termination of services due to their
inability to pay, with only a limited amount of churn driven by competition. We believe that launching
telephony in our markets, further driving digitization, providing our subscribers with multi-play packages
(including quad-play in Slovenia, as described in more detail below), expanding our cable footprint to broaden
our geographic reach and benefiting from increasing disposable incomes in the region (reducing the likelihood
of customers’ bad debt), will allow us to maintain low churn rates for cable Pay-TV. In addition, we believe
that as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic, our churn rates will likely decrease as customers are unlikely or
unable to easily migrate to another provider during the pandemic.

The churn rates for our mobile post-paid subscribers are higher than the churn rates for our fixed-line
telephony services, as it is easier for mobile subscribers to switch to our competitors as there are no
infrastructure limitations. Similarly, the churn rate of mobile prepaid subscribers is relatively higher because
of the non-contractual nature of the relationship with such subscribers. We believe, however, that we have
developed an attractive suite of fixed mobile convergence services in Slovenia which, among other things, has
had the effect of reducing the churn of our mobile post-paid subscribers in Slovenia. Following the
consummation of the acquisition of Tele2 Croatia in March 2020, we are leveraging on our experience and
the lessons learned from integrating Tušmobil to guide our integration of Tele2 Croatia. Since our acquisition
of Tušmobil, our number of quad-play subscribers in Slovenia has increased to 38% of our subscribers in
Slovenia as of March 31, 2021, from 1% of our subscribers in Slovenia prior to the acquisition. The blended
annual churn rate of Telemach Slovenia’s mobile post-paid subscribers as of March 31, 2021, was 11.5%,
compared to 11.2% as of January 31, 2017. We define blended annual churn as net lost subscribers (the
number of customers that either on a voluntary or involuntary basis no longer subscribe for a certain service)
divided by the number of all unique cable subscribers at the beginning of period, which result is then
annualized. We have been using the principles learned through our acquisition of Tušmobil and our experience
providing mobile services in Slovenia to inform the operation of our mobile-telephony business in Bulgaria
following the completion of the Vivacom Acquisition in July 2020 and in Croatia following the Tele2 Croatia
Acquisition completed in March 2021.

**_Cost of Services Provided_**

Our most significant costs include (i) carriage fees which we pay to international and regional broadcasters
such as Fox, Discovery and Pink, in order to carry their programs on our distribution network, (ii) licensing
fees payable to sports rights owners such as UEFA, the English Premier League, Spanish Primera League,
ATP and Formula 1, in order to develop content for our own channels, (iii) satellite capacity costs, (iv) payroll
costs, (v) internet and interconnection fees, (vi) costs of materials used to connect subscribers to our network


-----

and (vii) costs for marketing and sales. Most of our costs, such as a portion of our network operations,
customer care, billing and administration costs, are relatively fixed, while a portion of our marketing and
customer services cost is variable. Our content acquisition costs are mostly fixed and a decreasing portion of
these costs are subscriber based. Where possible, we aim to negotiate fixed rate content costs. This approach
allows us to anticipate the input price of our content and price our products accordingly. The costs associated
with the growth of our business, such as RGU acquisition costs, which are primarily comprised of campaign
costs and sales costs for attracting new subscribers, are variable costs.

A large portion of our costs is content costs, accounting for 18% of our operating expenses (not including
depreciation and amortization of intangible assets) for the three months ended March 31, 2021. While we
own a portion of our content, we are dependent on broadcasters and other content owners for most of our
programming. We pay license fees to several regional and international broadcasters in order to broadcast
their programs. For on demand content purchased by our subscribers, we generally pay a revenue share of the
retail price, subject, for certain on demand content, to fixed minimum guarantees. For packaged on demand
content (subscription video on demand), we pay on a per subscriber basis, sometimes with minimum
guarantees. We generally expect that our content costs (above the minimum amounts) will increase in line with
increased revenues from digital Pay-TV and on demand content. In the past we have successfully obtained
rebates and discounts for our content, but these may not continue in the future.

We pay fees to satellite operators to uplink and transmit our content to our DTH subscribers, and we also use
other network operators to connect telephone calls of our customers to customers of their respective networks
(interconnection). Generally, the amount we pay in interconnection fees in any period will depend on the level
of usage of our services.

Our staff cost is impacted by the number of personnel we employ, the experience levels at which such persons
are employed and increases in salaries and bonuses due to performance factors. Labor costs of technicians,
spent on the construction and upgrade of our network and acquisition of subscribers, are capitalized as
tangible and intangible assets.

RGU acquisition costs include campaign costs and sales costs. We aim to recover RGU acquisition costs over
the duration of the service contract. Factors that contribute to successful recovery of RGU acquisition costs
include our operational efficiency, the density of our subscriber base and our direct relationships with our
subscribers, which enables us not to rely on intermediaries to interact with our customers.

**_Network and Technological Advances_**

Our ability to provide new high definition and on demand digital TV services, broadband internet access at
higher speeds and telephony services to subscribers depends, in part, on our ability to upgrade and maintain
our network. We incur capital expenditure charges in periods over which these upgrades are made, with the
aim of recouping these investments through increased revenues and profitability.

In particular, we expect certain communications technologies that are currently under development, 5G
technology in particular, to become increasingly important in our markets. We successfully tested and are
rolling out our next generation 5G networks across our mobile-telephony footprint. In Slovenia,
5G 3600 MHz deployment and commercial launch began in June 2021, following a successful frequency
auction result in April 2021. In Bulgaria, 5G has been launched commercially using 4G 1900 MHz spectrum
in September 2020, which was the first available 5G service in the market, and in May 2021, Vivacom has
secured a 20-year license for 100 MHz spectrum frequencies in the 3.6 GHz band. In Croatia, the first
deployment of the 5G C-Band is expected during the third or fourth quarters of 2021, and Telemach Croatia
is participating in the 5G spectrum auction in Croatia. We believe that significant investments in 5G
technology will be critical to remain competitive in the mobile market and meet our customers’ needs.

Our ability to compete effectively and maintain or increase our customer base depends on our ability to
anticipate and react quickly to technological developments and evolving industry standards and develop
successful new and enhanced products and services to adapt to changes in our market. We invest in new or
enhanced technologies, products or services in periods over which industry standards change, or to upgrade
our technologies proactively. Additionally, we incur capital expenditure costs relating to the replacement of
existing equipment. We expect to incur substantial capital expenditure costs in the future relating to new 4G
and 5G frequencies and the installation of new equipment.

**_Foreign Currency Exchange Rates_**

We operate across Southeastern Europe, generating revenues in many local currencies, which fluctuate from
time to time in relation to the euro. Our revenues in Slovenia, Montenegro and Greece are generated in euro.


-----

SBB Serbia and Telemach BH record their financial results in the Serbian dinar and the Bosnian and
Herzegovinian mark, respectively, which are then translated into euros in preparing our consolidated financial
statements. In the three months ended March 31, 2021, 72% of our revenue was generated in euros or
currencies pegged to the euro, with 15% of our revenue generated in Serbian dinars and 13% of revenue
generated in Croatian kuna. While the Bosnian and Herzegovinian mark is pegged against the euro at a fixed
exchange rate of BAM 1.9558 per €1.00 and the Bulgarian lev is pegged against the euro at a fixed exchange
rate of BGN 1.9558 per €1.00, the Serbian dinar freely fluctuates against the euro. For the three months ended
March 31, 2021, the value of the Serbian dinar remained stable relative to the euro. However, due to the
historic indexation of the Serbian dinar against the German mark, which was replaced by the euro in 2002, we
believe the Serbian consumer price index closely tracks the depreciation of the Serbian dinar against the euro
which has historically allowed us to “pass through”a portion of the impact of the depreciation of the dinar to
our customers. We believe that our pricing strategy reflects this “pass through” principle. In the three months
ended March 31, 2021, the value of the Croatian kuna increased approximately 1% relative to the euro
compared to the three months ended March 31, 2020.

We present our consolidated financial statements in euro. As a result, we must translate the assets, liabilities,
revenue and expenses of all of our operations with a functional currency other than the euro into euros at then
applicable exchange rates. Consequently, increases or decreases in the value of these currencies against the
euro may affect the value of our assets, liabilities, revenue and expenses with respect to our non-euro businesses
in our consolidated financial statements, even if their value has not changed in their original currency. These
translations could significantly affect the comparability of our results between financial periods and result in
significant changes to the carrying value of our assets, liabilities and stockholders’ equity.

Additionally, certain of our expenses, primarily content and satellite costs, are denominated in euros and U.S.
dollars. Where we are unable to match sales received in foreign currencies with costs paid in the same currency,
our results of operations are impacted by currency exchange rate fluctuations. A substantial portion of our
indebtedness is denominated in euros. Based on our lack of any material change in exposure to the U.S. dollar
in the three months ended March 31, 2021, we did not enter into any additional currency hedge agreements
during the three months ended March 31, 2021.

**_Growth in Our Markets_**

Three of our key markets—Serbia, Bosnia and Herzegovina and Montenegro—are generally characterized
by lower internet broadband household penetration rates compared to elsewhere in Western Europe and the
CEE region and both Serbia and Bosnia and Herzegovina have lower pay television household penetration
rates compared to elsewhere in Western Europe and the CEE region. As a result, growth in our markets has
been higher than in certain CEE and Western Europe jurisdictions. We believe this is primarily due to the
increasing importance of high-quality broadband internet and an increasing convergence of our regions with
the EU. Slovenia is a more mature market, with subscriber rates similar to the CEE region, and as a result,
growth in that market will depend more on our ability to effectively compete with other market participants
and to continue to offer high-quality customer propositions. Following the completion of the Tele2 Croatia
Acquisition in March 2020, we also have operations in Croatia. As a member of the EU with relatively high
GDP per capita and growth rates, Croatia is an attractive market for our continued expansion. The Croatian
mobile market is characterized by high market stability, as it has a low level of fragmentation and disruption,
with only three MNOs in the market (including Telemach Croatia), and the country’s telecommunications
infrastructure is highly dependent on mobile access, with one of the highest mobile ARPU among CEE
countries. We believe that our growth in this market will depend on several factors, such as the ability to
expand our territorial coverage as well as improve the quality of our network and customer support services,
including through investments to increase our capacity and quality levels and through the continued
development of our digital and sales channels. In addition, following the completion of the Vivacom
Acquisition in July 2020, we also have operations in Bulgaria. Bulgaria experienced relatively strong GDP
growth at an average rate of 3.3% per year between 2017 and 2019 (according to the BNSI), but faces economic
and political challenges in sustaining this growth.

Following the Forthnet Acquisition, we also have operations in Greece. The Greek telecommunications market
is characterized by intense competition. The market is concentrated among four main operators with a focus
on fixed-mobile convergent offerings. The total fixed-line market, comprised of approximately 4.8 million
subscribers, has stable with limited fixed-to-mobile substitution, while the broadband market, comprised of
approximately 4.2 million subscribers continues to grow at the expense of voice-only lines. NGA subscribers
(those with broadband speeds of greater than 30 Mbps) comprise approximately one-third of total broadband
subscribers, but this level remains low compared with the EU average of over 60%. Pay-TV penetration is also


-----

low compared to EU averages, with 26% of Greek households subscribing to Pay-TV. In Greece, the majority
of Pay-TV subscribers are served through DTH technology, while the remainder is served through IPTV.

In each of the aforementioned markets, a number of factors will impact the rate of growth of pay television,
broadband internet and telephony industries, including economic conditions, political stability, increases in
infrastructure and an increased distribution of wealth. Furthermore, these industries may not grow at the
same rate as they have in the past.

**_Regulation_**

Our operations are subject to various regulations in Europe and in our regional markets. We are generally free
from retail price regulation other than, prior to January 2017, with respect to our Basic TV package in Serbia,
due to SBB Serbia’s prior SMP in the Serbian Pay-TV market. Since January 2017, we are no longer considered
a significant market participant in the Pay-TV market in Serbia, thus our Basic TV package is no longer
subject to price regulation, although this may change in the future, and we regularly monitor the market to
stay aware of market conditions which may lead to price regulation. In Croatia, we are currently subject to
price regulation only with respect to fixed and mobile termination rates charged by operators to each other
for interconnection services, which are regulated in the whole European Union. In addition, in Serbia we are
subject to price regulation only to the extent we are required to provide access to our wholesale network.

SBB Serbia is, however, currently deemed to have SMP on the wholesale market for call termination in public
telephone networks and the wholesale market of central access at a fixed location for mass market products,
which imposes certain regulatory obligations. See “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our Business and
_Industry—We may become subject to more extensive regulation due to our scale.” We also implemented price_
increases in January 2018, which the Serbian Commission for Protection of Competition investigated, but
ultimately accepted. In addition, we may be subject to conditions imposed in connection with competition
authority clearances as we continue to expand our business through bolt on, value accretive acquisitions and
we may be subject to market power analysis from the relevant regulators, which could force us to adjust our
prices or sell various parts of our businesses. See also “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our Business and
_Industry—We may become subject to more extensive regulation due to our scale” and “Our Business—_
_Regulatory Framework.”_

**_Tax Treatment in Local Jurisdictions_**

The results of our operations depend on our tax treatment under the tax laws and regulations of local
jurisdictions. For instance, in Serbia, taxable income can be reduced in the same proportion as capital
expenditure for the year in Serbia divided by the carrying amount of assets in Serbia. Due to our significant
capital expenditure in Serbia in 2016, we believe we have satisfied the requirements to be granted a ten year tax
beneficial status, expiring in 2025, and we recorded beneficial tax treatment for our SBB Serbia segment for
the years ending December 31, 2018, 2019 and 2020 and the three months ended March 31, 2021. Additionally,
under thin capitalization rules in Serbia, interest and related costs under intercompany loans are recognized
as deductible expenses to the extent the intercompany loans do not exceed four times the borrower’s equity. In
2017 and 2018, SBB Serbia did not capitalize any intercompany loans. On December 27, 2018, the Serbian
Tax Authority notified United Group that it had begun a tax investigation of SBB Serbia for the year ended
December 31, 2012. The Serbian Tax Authority issued a decision in March 2019 that it had recharacterized
interest payments made by SBB Serbia under an intragroup loan agreement (and certain debt and equity
conversions) as dividends, which would have been subject to a 5% withholding tax, and found a total
contingent liability in respect of this decision amounting to €21 million, including late interest. On October 12,
2020, the Serbian Ministry of Finance annulled the Serbian Tax Authority’s decision and instructed the
Serbian Tax Authority to restart the procedure, taking into account the arguments provided in SSB Serbia’s
appeal. The Serbian Tax Authority has also informed SBB Serbia that it is opening a tax review for the years
2013 through 2016. SBB Serbia intends to continue contesting the Serbian Tax Authority’s findings. For more
information, see “Our Business—Legal Proceedings—Investigation by the Serbian Tax Authority.”

Furthermore, in Slovenia, Telemach Slovenia may use a tax allowance for investment in equipment and
intangible assets (available for investments made after January 1, 2008), whereby the tax allowance is limited
to 40% of the value of the assets, up to the amount of the tax base. In 2018, 2019 and 2020, Telemach Slovenia
used the tax allowance for investments in the amount of €11.5 million, €10.5 million and €9.3 million,
respectively.

In Bosnia and Herzegovina, a taxpayer who invests more than BAM 20.0 million (€10.2 million) in production
assets (property, plant and equipment) within the territory of Bosnia and Herzegovina for five


-----

consecutive years is relieved from 50% of taxation on such investments for a period of five years, starting from
the first year in which it has invested at least BAM 4 million (€2.0 million). Pursuant to this provision, in 2018,
2019 and 2020, Telemach BH received a tax allowance for investments in the amount of BAM 6.1 million
(€3.1 million), BAM 6.8 million (€3.5 million) and BAM 2.7 million (€1.4 million), respectively. In Bosnia and
Herzegovina, a taxpayer receives a tax allowance when it employs certain types of employees, and in 2018,
2019 and 2020, Telemach BH received a tax allowance for certain new employees in the amount of
BAM 1.3 million (€0.7 million), BAM 2.0 million (€1.0 million) and BAM 2.9 million (€1.5 million),
respectively.

In Greece, the corporate income tax rate was set at 24% in 2019. From January 1, 2020, withholding taxes on
dividends were reduced from 10% to 5%, and on July 1, 2020, Greece implemented a participation exemption
for capital gains from the sale of Greek and EU subsidiaries. For internet services, customers are charged a 5%
tax on top of internet subscriptions (in addition to VAT of 24%). In addition, a 10% tax on top of Pay-TV
subscriptions for Greek operators (in addition to VAT of 24%) has been imposed, although this has been
suspended until September 2021.

**_Implementation of Accounting Policies and Accounting Updates_**

_IFRS 15 Revenue from Contracts with Customers_

IFRS 15 establishes a comprehensive framework for determining whether, how much and when revenue is
recognized. While IFRS 15 became effective for annual reporting periods beginning on or after January 1,
2018, with early adoption permitted, we commenced the recognition of revenue broadly in line with IFRS 15
for periods starting January 1, 2016 as debundling of services was applied beginning on January 1, 2016.
Other standards in compliance with IFRS 15 were applied from January 1, 2018. There were two primary
changes that we implemented in accordance with IFRS 15.

First, with respect to handset sales that are subsidized by ongoing service fees, we used to recognize revenue
only in the amount of cash received for such mobile phones. However, under the new standard, we allocate a
contract’s transaction price based on the relative stand-alone selling price of the mobile phone. More revenue
is recognized upfront as a result. As a result of implementing this policy in 2016, we have not seen a material
impact on our reported financial results for periods that commenced after January 1, 2018 when IFRS 15 was
fully implemented.

Concurrently, we corrected an accounting policy regarding discounts to contracts. Contracts where a customer
pays for equipment, such as handsets, in installments over a period of more than one year (in addition to
ongoing services) may be deemed to have a significant financing component, particularly in the case of
discounts during the first few months of a contract. The majority of new or renewed contracts provide for
discounts during the first few months of a contract. Under IFRS, such a discount during the first few months
is ignored, and the total price of the contract is spread out over the entire contract period. Furthermore,
revenue is adjusted to reflect the time value of money.

Second, we charge non-refundable service activation fees to all new customers at the beginning of their
contract. These fees do not transfer goods or services to the customer, but are more administrative in nature
and do not render a service or provide a benefit to the customer. Under IFRS 15, such fees should be spread
over the entire contract period as they are related to the performance obligation of providing a mobile service,
which results in a contractual liability at the beginning of the contract on the balance sheet.

_IFRS 9 Financial Instruments_

IFRS 9 replaces the existing guidance in IAS 39 (Financial Instruments: Recognition and Measurement) that
relates to the recognition, classification and measurement of financial assets and financial liabilities,
derecognition of financial instruments, impairment of financial assets and hedge accounting. IFRS 9 also
includes revised guidance on the classification and measurement of financial instruments, including a new
expected credit loss model for calculating impairment on financial assets and the new general hedge accounting
requirements. Most IAS 39 requirements concerning classification and measurement of financial liabilities
and de recognition of financial instruments were transferred to IFRS 9 unchanged.

The standard introduces the following categories of financial assets: measured at amortized cost, measured at
fair value through profit and loss and measured at fair value through other comprehensive income.
Classification is performed on initial recognition and depends on the business model for managing of financial
assets adopted by the Group and on the characteristics of the contractual cash flows from such instruments.


-----

The adoption of IFRS 9 from January 1, 2018 resulted in changes in accounting policies and adjustments to
the amounts recognized in our accumulated loss.

_IFRS 16 Leases_

IFRS 16 introduced for annual reporting periods beginning on or after January 1, 2019 a single, on balance
sheet lease accounting model for lessees. A lessee recognizes a right-of-use asset representing its right to use
the underlying asset and a lease liability representing its obligation to make lease payments. There are
recognition exemptions for short-term leases and leases of low value items available on a voluntary basis.
Lessor accounting remains similar to the previous standard—i.e., lessors continue to classify leases as finance
or operating leases.

Under IFRS 16, we recognize new assets and liabilities for our operating leases of satellite capacity, office
facilities, parts of our infrastructure and base stations and the right-of-use of water and land. The nature of
expenses related to those leases changed because we recognized a depreciation charge for right-of-use assets
and interest expense on lease liabilities. Previously, we recognized operating lease expense on a straight-line
basis over the term of the lease, and recognized assets and liabilities only to the extent that there was a timing
difference between actual lease payments and the expense recognized. There has been no significant impact
for our finance leases in which we are the lessor.

We applied the simplified transition approach and did not restate comparative amounts for the year prior to
first adoption. Right-of-use assets for property leases were measured on transition as if the new rules had
always been applied. All other right-of-use assets have been measured at the amount of the lease liability on
adoption (adjusted for any prepaid or accrued lease expenses).

_IFRIC 23_

In June 2017, the IFRS Interpretation Committee issued IFRIC 23, which clarifies the accounting treatment
of uncertainties in income taxes, specifically in relation to taxable profit or loss, tax bases, unused tax losses,
unused tax credits and tax rates, when there is uncertainty over income tax treatments under IAS 12.

IFRIC 23 states that an entity should assume that the applicable taxation authority will have full knowledge
of all relevant information when examining amounts reported to it. An entity therefore has to consider
whether it is probable that the applicable authority will accept a certain tax treatment in the entity’s income
tax filing and either adopt an approach consistent with the tax treatment in its income tax filings or use the
expected value of the tax treatment when determining taxable profit or loss, tax bases, unused tax losses,
unused tax credits and tax rates.

IFRIC 23 is applicable for annual reporting periods beginning on or after January 1, 2019 with early adoption
permitted. In adopting IFRIC 23, we applied a modified retrospective approach whereby the cumulative
effect of initially applying IFRIC 23, if any, should be recognized in opening equity at the date of initial
application. As part of our adoption of IFRIC 23, we have not identified any additional material income tax
uncertainties for which we would be required to recognize a related tax liability.

In the three months ended March 31, 2021, we have also applied certain other amendments to existing
accounting standards that did not have any impact on the amounts recognized in prior periods and that are
not expected to significantly affect current or future periods.

Acquisitions affect our results of operations in a variety of ways. Our results for the period during which an

the date of their acquisition and disposed of entities are no longer consolidated from the date of their
disposition, the full impact of an acquisition or disposition is only reflected in our financial statements in the
subsequent periods. As a result, the historical results of operations for the periods presented in this offering
memorandum may not be comparable with each other. See “Our Business—History” for a discussion of these
acquisitions.

**_UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure_**

UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure represents capital expenditure, as adjusted by intragroup adjustments, the
application of IFRS 15 for acquisition costs in SBB Serbia, assets held for sale and overflow between periods.
UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure is prepared based on management accounts and not IFRS.

Intragroup adjustments relate to unrealized profit on the intragroup sale of end-user equipment by SBB
Serbia. When SBB Serbia sells this equipment to other Group companies in compliance with applicable
transfer pricing requirements, it makes an unrealized profit on the sale. These unrealized profits are eliminated
for the purposes of preparing our accounts in accordance with IFRS, but are not eliminated for the purpose
of our management accounts.

The application of IFRS 15 for acquisition costs in SBB Serbia reflects the additional effect of harmonizing
our accounting policy with respect to the capitalization of subscriber acquisition costs for rebinding, upselling
and cross-selling (which in the past were not eligible to be capitalized, but under IFRS 15 qualify for
capitalization), which were determined subsequent to the preparation of our management accounts.

Assets held for sale relate to programming rights acquired by Media Group for other Group Segments which
were recognized under IFRS as intangible assets and were invoiced to other Group segments after March 31,
2021.

Overflow between periods relates to the fact that our management accounts are closed prior to the closing of
our accounts prepared in accordance with IFRS. Overflow between periods in any given period reflects the
additional capital expenditure incurred between the preparation of our management accounts and our
accounts prepared in accordance with IFRS for such period.

In this offering memorandum, we present UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure for the Company and for each of
the Company’s business segments for the years ended December 31, 2018, 2019 and 2020, and for the
three months ended March 31, 2020 and 2021. See “Summary of Company and Group Run-Rate, Vivacom,
_Unaudited Pro Forma and Certain Other Financial Data” and “Reconciliation of Certain Financial Data_
_Presented Herein.” A reconciliation between the Company’s capital expenditure and UG Adjusted Capital_
Expenditure for the years ended December 31, 2018, 2019 and 2020, and the three months ended March 31,
2021 is included elsewhere in this offering memorandum, under “Reconciliation of Certain Financial Data
_Presented Herein.” In addition, for informational purposes only, we describe our anticipated UG Adjusted_
Capital Expenditure for the year ended December 31, 2021 based on management estimates, which may vary
from our actual Group level capital expenditure data when it is prepared in accordance with IFRS.

UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure and future UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure estimates are prepared based
on management accounts rather than IFRS. One example of a difference in methodology used in preparing
the management account financial data (as compared to IFRS financial data) is that when determining UG
Adjusted Capital Expenditure relating to set-top boxes purchased by group companies, the expenditure is
treated as inventory until such set-top box is activated by the end-user, at which time it is treated as a fixed
asset. Under IFRS, however, this expenditure is required to be accounted for as a fixed asset from the moment
such set-top box is purchased. As a result, when presenting our segment level UG Adjusted Capital
Expenditure and our anticipated UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure for the periods presented in this offering
memorandum, we classify our expenditures relating to set-top boxes as inventory until such set-top boxes are
activated by the end-user.

**Key Operating Measures**

We use several key operating measures, including homes passed, unique subscribers, RGUs and ARPU, to
track the performance of our business. None of these terms are measures of financial performance under
IFRS, nor have these measures been reviewed by an outside auditor, consultant or expert. These measures are
derived from management information systems. As these terms are defined by our management, they may not
be comparable to similar terms used by other companies.

**_Unique Subscribers, RGUs and ARPU_**

Unique cable subscribers represent the number of individual end-users who have subscribed to one or more of
our cable-based services. In all of our cable markets, cable Pay-TV is the basic service that a cable unique
subscriber is typically required to subscribe to in order to receive the Group’s other services such as broadband
internet access and telephony, with the exception of Bulgaria. A unique cable subscriber may subscribe to
several different services, thereby accounting for only one unique cable subscriber, but several RGUs.

DTH subscribers represent the number of individuals across the six Southeastern European markets
(Slovenia, Serbia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Bulgaria, Montenegro and North Macedonia) who have
subscribed to our DTH Pay-TV services. We believe that most of these subscribers are outside of our cable
footprint. Typically, DTH subscribers are only able to subscribe to DTH based Pay-TV services and represent
a single RGU. However, we are re selling ADSL services purchased from our competitors in the respective
markets to DTH subscribers.

Average monthly revenue per user, or ARPU, is a measure we use to evaluate how effectively we are realizing
potential revenues from subscribers. ARPU is calculated by adding together, for each month in a given period,
the total subscription related revenues for that particular month divided by the average number of subscribers
for that month and then dividing that sum by the total number of months in the period.

(1) Homes passed represents all homes (households) ready to be connected directly to our fixed-line network.

(2) Unique cable subscribers represent the number of individual end-users who have subscribed to one or more of our cable-based
services. In all of our cable markets, cable Pay-TV is the basic service that a cable unique subscriber is typically required to subscribe
to in order to receive the Group’s other services such as broadband internet access and telephony, with the exception of Bulgaria.
A unique cable subscriber may subscribe to several different services, thereby accounting for only one unique cable subscriber, but
several RGUs.

(3) Cable Pay-TV RGUs includes (i) the sum of our analog and digital cable Pay-TV RGUs in Slovenia, (ii) our total analog cable
Pay-TV RGUs (without separately counting analog cable RGUs that have purchased digital top ups) in Serbia, Bosnia and
Herzegovina and Montenegro and (iii) our analog and digital cable Pay-TV RGUs in Bulgaria.

(4) OTT consists of our NetTV Plus and out of footprint EON subscribers.

(5) Broadband internet RGUs represents residential broadband internet provided within our network footprint.

(6) Fixed-line telephony RGUs represents residential fixed-line telephony provided within our network footprint.

(7) Mobile RGUs represents mobile-telephony services provided to customers in Slovenia, where we have operated as an MNO since
our acquisition of Tušmobil in April 2015. Following completion of the acquisition of Tele2 Croatia in March 2020, we also
provide mobile-telephony services in Croatia, and following the completion of the acquisition of Vivacom in July 2020, we also
provide mobile-telephony services in Bulgaria.

(8) Other services include multichannel multipoint distribution service-based services, ADSL internet services and B2B services.

(9) RGU Penetration represents for cable Pay-TV the number of unique cable subscribers at the end of the relevant period as
a percentage of the number of homes passed by our network, and for broadband internet the number of RGUs at the end of the
relevant period as a percentage of the number of unique cable subscribers.

(10) Blended Cable ARPU is calculated by adding together, for each month in a given period, the total cable Pay-TV, broadband
internet and fixed-line telephony revenues (including fixed-line telephony usage revenues and excluding minor installation fees) for
that particular month divided by the average number of unique cable subscribers for that month and then dividing that sum by the
total number of months in the period. Blended Cable ARPU does not include mobile ARPU, which was €10.9 for the year ended
December 31, 2018, €10.8 for the year ended December 31, 2019, €9.5 for the year ended December 31, 2020 and €8.8 for the
three months ended March 31, 2021. We calculate mobile ARPU by adding together, for each month in a given period, the total
mobile-telephony revenues (excluding revenues generated by customers of other networks roaming on our network and excluding
wholesale revenues) for that particular month divided by the average number of mobile RGUs for that month and then dividing
that sum by the total number of months in the period. In addition, following the Vivacom Acquisition, we amended the definition
of certain key operating measures (Homes Passed, Unique Cable Subscribers and Blended Cable ARPU) in order to align the
calculation methodology across the Group. As a result, Bended Cable ARPU figures were restated for the periods starting from
January 1, 2018 onwards.

(11) As of January 1, 2019, we changed our reporting methodology in regards to certain key operating measures, which has resulted in
immaterial differences as compared to previous periods. For the year ended December 31, 2018, OTT users on our network have
been reclassified to Cable and Cable services users on other networks have been reclassified to Other Services from Cable. This
change has an immaterial effect on all subscriber, RGU, ARPU and churn data for the year ended December 31, 2018, and such key
operating measures have been restated for such periods in line with this new reporting methodology.

_Group—Three Months Ended March 31, 2021 Compared to the Three Months Ended March 31, 2020_

Homes passed increased by 1,858 thousand, or 100%, from 1,866 thousand as of March 31, 2020, to
3,724 thousand as of March 31, 2021, primarily due to the acquisition of Vivacom and organic network
expansion.

As of March 31, 2020, we had 1,479 thousand cable Pay-TV RGUs, an increase of 307 thousand compared to
1,172 thousand as of March 31, 2020, primarily due to the acquisition of Vivacom and organic growth.

The total number of DTH Pay-TV RGUs amounted to 991 thousand as of March 31, 2021, a 121% increase
year-on-year, primarily due to the acquisitions of Vivacom and Forthnet.

As of March 31, 2021, we had 1,396 thousand broadband internet RGUs, representing an increase of 60%,
compared to 871 thousand as of March 31, 2020. This is primarily attributable to the acquisition of Vivacom,
an increase in multi-play subscriptions over this period and organic subscriber growth.

The total number of fixed-telephony RGUs increased to 1,269 thousand as of March 31, 2021, an increase of
80% compared to 704 thousand as of March 31, 2020. This positive trend is primarily due to the acquisition
of Vivacom, an increase in multi-play subscriptions over this period and organic subscriber growth.


-----

Our OTT RGUs as of March 31, 2021 decreased by 1% to 127 thousand, compared to 128 thousand as of
March 31, 2020.

Our mobile service RGUs increased from 1,495 thousand as of March 31, 2020 to 4,473 thousand as of
March 31, 2021. This is an increase of 2,977 thousand, or 199%, which was due to the acquisition of Vivacom
(2,938 thousand mobile RGUs) and organic growth.

Our total RGUs increased by 122%, from 4,902 thousand as of March 31, 2020 to 10,890 thousand as of
March 31, 2021. RGUs added over this period were mainly the result of the acquisition of Vivacom
(4,461 thousand total RGUs) and Forthnet (1,375 thousand RGUs), as well as organic growth of cable Pay-TV
and mobile services and a growing proportion of multi-play subscribers.

_Group—Year Ended December 31, 2020 Compared to the Year Ended December 31, 2019_

Homes passed increased by 1,834 thousand, or 99%, from 1,852 thousand as of December 31, 2019 to
3,686 thousand as of December 31, 2020, primarily due to the acquisition of Vivacom (1,750 thousand) and
organic network expansion.

As of December 31, 2020, we had 1,476 thousand cable Pay-TV RGUs, an increase of 308 thousand compared
to 1,168 thousand as of December 31, 2019, as a result of the acquisition of Vivacom and organic growth.

The total number of DTH Pay-TV RGUs amounted to 999 thousand as of December 31, 2020, a 124%
decrease as compared to December 31, 2019, primarily due to the acquisitions of Vivacom and Forthnet.

As of December 31, 2020, we had 1,389 thousand broadband internet RGUs, representing an increase of
62%, compared to 856 thousand at December 31, 2019. This is primarily attributable to the acquisition of
Vivacom, an increase in multi-play subscriptions and organic subscriber growth.

The total number of fixed-telephony RGUs increased to 1,270 thousand as of December 31, 2020, an increase
of 83%, compared to 695 thousand as of December 31, 2019. This is primarily the result of the acquisition of
Vivacom, as well as an increase in multi-play subscriptions over this period and organic subscriber growth.

Our OTT RGUs as of December 31, 2020 increased by 4% to 129 thousand, compared to 124 thousand as of
December 31, 2018.

Our mobile service RGUs increased from 550 thousand as of December 31, 2019 to 4,483 thousand as of
December 31, 2020. This is an increase of 3,933 thousand, or 715%, driven by the acquisition of Vivacom and
Telemach Croatia (2,938 thousand and 937 thousand mobile RGUs, respectively) and organic growth in
Slovenia.

Our total RGUs increased by 178%, from 3,917 thousand as of December 31, 2019 to 10,897 thousand as of
December 31, 2020. RGUs added over this period were mainly the result of the acquisitions of Vivacom
(4,461 thousand RGUs), Telemach Croatia (937 thousand mobile RGUs) and Forthnet (1,375 thousand
RGUs), as well as organic growth of cable Pay-TV and mobile services and a growing proportion of multiplay subscribers.

_Group—Year Ended December 31, 2019 Compared to the Year Ended December 31, 2018_

Homes passed increased by 19 thousand, or 1%, from 1,833 thousand as of December 31, 2018 to
1,852 thousand as of December 31, 2019, primarily due to organic network expansion.

As of December 31, 2019, we had 1,168 thousand cable Pay-TV RGUs, an increase of 3 thousand compared
to 1,166 thousand as of December 31, 2018, primarily due to organic growth.

The total number of DTH Pay-TV RGUs amounted to 446 thousand as of December 31, 2019, a 4% decrease
as compared to 463 as of December 31, 2018, primarily due to increased competition, migration from DTH
to our cable services (due to expansion of our network) and subscriber base cleaning.

As of December 31, 2019, we had 856 thousand broadband internet RGUs, representing an increase of 4%,
compared to 822 thousand at December 31, 2018. This is primarily attributable to an increase in multi-play
subscriptions and organic subscriber growth.

The total number of fixed-telephony RGUs increased to 695 thousand as of December 31, 2019, an increase
of 8%, compared to 644 thousand as of December 31, 2018. This positive trend is primarily due to an increase
in multi-play subscriptions and organic subscriber growth. Our fixed-line telephony RGUs as of December 31,
2018 have been restated by 17 thousand RGUs, from 661 thousand RGUs to 644 thousand RGUs, due to the

Our mobile service RGUs increased from 512 thousand as of December 31, 2018 to 550 thousand as of

content and additional sports channels.

Greece segment. DTH ARPU for Forthnet decreased to €17.8 in the three months ended March 31, 2021,
compared to €20.2 in the three months ended March 31, 2020 mainly due to the closure of B2B businesses
(mainly Bar/ Café) as a result of the implementation of COVID-19 lockdowns as of mid-January. During the
lockdown period, these businesses were not charged while remaining in the active base. The ARPU impact
due to the lockdown of small and medium enterprises is estimated at €(2.59) million.

**Description of Key Line Items**

**_Revenue._** Revenues are generated from the following services: cable television, broadband internet, DTHTV, value added services (such as OTT), telephony subscriptions and telephony usage, content and other
sources (primarily related to the sale of end-user equipment). Revenues generated from our bundle
subscriptions are allocated to the individual products of standard cable, broadband internet and telephony
subscriptions based on the individual product prices for each product as a percentage of the sum of the
individual product prices. Revenue for these services is charged and recognized in the period in which these
services are provided. We recognize revenues for connection fees upon delivery of installation and we defer
and amortize connection fees over the average remaining useful life of the customer relationship.

**_Other income._** Other income arises mainly from subventions, reversal of provision for legal cases, charged
legal cases and other activities nor related to the ordinary course of business.

**_Content costs._** Content costs include author rights and royalties we pay to procure our content, and include
fees paid to channel providers, primarily related to foreign television channels. Our content fees are
predominantly determined on a flat monthly amount and to a lesser extent on a per subscriber basis.

**_Satellite capacity costs._** Satellite capacity costs relate to the lease of satellite capacity from third-party
providers, which currently is EUTELSAT. These costs are impacted by the type and amount of commercial
discounts obtained from satellite providers. With effect from January 1, 2019, satellite capacity costs are
presented under depreciation (right-of-use assets) and finance costs due to the adoption of IFRS 16.

**_Link and interconnection costs._** These costs relate to fees payable in order to transfer data over third-party
networks. Internet connection links are leased from various parties.

**_Cost of end-user equipment and other material costs._** Cost of end-user equipment and other material costs
includes costs to procure set-top boxes, other products, such as telephones and routers, and materials used to
connect subscribers to our network. Prior to January 1, 2020, these costs were recorded under the line item
“Material costs.”

**_Staff cost._** Staff cost includes wages and salaries, social security costs, pension costs and other postemployment benefits and the cost of temporary and external personnel, adjusted for own work capitalized
based on direct labor hours spent on projects which are capitalized.


-----

**_Media buying._** Media buying includes expenses incurred by Direct Media in the territories of Serbia,
Montenegro, Albania and North Macedonia. As a leading media network in Southeastern Europe, Direct
Media provides international and local partners with integrated communication, advertising and media
services.

**_Depreciation cost._** Depreciation cost relates to the depreciation and impairment of our property, plant and
equipment over their useful lives.

**_Amortization of intangible assets._** Amortization of intangible assets relates to the amortization and
impairment of our intangible assets over their useful lives. Our intangible assets include our customer base
and direct subscriber acquisition costs, which, for our cable and DTH customers, are capitalized and
amortized over the estimated useful life of the customer relationship. For our mobile customers, subscriber
acquisition costs are capitalized and amortized over a twenty four month period (the estimated life of the
post-paid customer contract), while our mobile customer base is capitalized and amortized over its estimated
useful life. Intangible assets also include goodwill, computer software, licenses and content such as sport
rights.

**_Amortization of right-of-use assets._** Amortization of right-of-use assets relates to depreciation of right-ofuse assets over the shorter of the asset’s useful life and the lease term on a straight-line basis.

**_Other operating expenses._** Other operating expenses include rent of premises, poles and ducts, marketing
and promotion expenses, legal and administrative fees and maintenance costs and other costs. With effect
from January 1, 2019, other operating expenses excludes media buying expenses, which are included under the
separate line item “Media buying.”

**_Operating income._** Operating income represents the amount of profit from business operations, and includes
total revenues less total operating expenses (which contains cost of goods sold, personnel expenses, contracted
work, materials and logistics, marketing and sales, office expenses, other operating expenses, amortization,
depreciation and impairments).

**_Finance income._** Finance income includes interest income on funds invested (including short-term bank
deposits) and foreign currency gains.

**_Finance costs._** Finance costs include interest expense on borrowings and foreign currency losses.

**_Income tax credit/(expense)._** Income tax credit/(expense) comprises current and deferred income tax and is
recognized in our statement of comprehensive income, except to the extent that such expense or benefit relates
to an item that is recognized as equity in our balance sheet or in our statement of other comprehensive
income.

_Serbia Group segment._ Revenue for our Serbia Group segment decreased by €689 thousand, or 1%, to

_Bosnia Group segment._ Revenue for our Bosnia Group segment decreased by €736 thousand, or 4%, to
€18,052 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2021, from €18,788 thousand for the three months
ended March 31, 2020. This decrease was primarily due to the negative accounting impact from the
implementation of IFRS 15 on video and internet services of €989 thousand, partially offset by higher DTH
video and internet subscription revenues.

_Montenegro Group segment._ Revenue for our Montenegro Group segment decreased by €171 thousand, or
5%, to €3,194 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2021, from €3,365 thousand for the
three months ended March 31, 2020. This decrease was primarily due to a continued decline in the number
DTH subscribers.

_Croatia Group segment._ Revenue for our Croatia Group segment was €43,770 thousand for the three months
ended March 31, 2021. Tele2 Croatia was acquired and consolidated into United Group as of March 2020.

_Bulgaria Group segment. Revenue for our Bulgaria Group segment was €129,604 thousand for the_
three months ended March 31, 2021. Vivacom was acquired and consolidated into United Group as of
July 2020.

_Greece Group segment._ Revenue for our Greece Group segment was €62,122 thousand for the three months
ended March 31, 2021. Forthnet was acquired and consolidated into United Group as of November 2020.

_Media Group segment._ External revenue for our Media Group segment increased by 53% to
€56,769 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2021, compared to €37,169 thousand in the
three months ended March 31, 2020, mainly due to the Nova Broadcasting Group Acquisition, which was
completed in January 2021. Total revenues of the Media Group segment (including intercompany revenues)
increased by 36% year-on-year, to €84,646 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2021.

_Other._ Revenue from our Other segment increased €4,024 thousand, or 88%, to €8,603 thousand for the
three months ended March 31, 2021, from €4,579 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2020. This
increase was primarily due to the launch of the Shoppster e-commerce platform during 2020.

_Other income._ Other income increased by €73 thousand, or 4%, to €1,796 thousand for the three months
ended March 31, 2021, from €1,723 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2020.

_Content costs._ Content costs increased by €19,615 thousand, or 69%, to €48,166 thousand for the
three months ended March 31, 2021, from €28,551 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2020. This
increase was primarily due to the content costs of newly acquired channels.

_Link and interconnection costs._ Link and interconnection costs increased by €33,226 thousand, or 291%, to
€44,660 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2021, from €11,434 thousand for the three months
ended March 31, 2020. This increase was primarily due to the acquisitions of Vivacom, Forthnet and Tele2
Croatia.

_Cost of end-user equipment and other material costs._ Cost of end-user equipment and other material costs
increased by €31,010 thousand, or 183%, to €47,974 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2021,
from €16,964 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2020. This increase was primarily due to higher
cost of sales for mobile handsets (mainly due to the acquisitions of Vivacom and Tele2 Croatia), the higher
cost of end-user equipment, higher energy and fuel costs mainly as a result of acquisitions, as well as higher
costs of goods sold (mainly relating to goods sold by Shoppster, which started operations in 2020).

_Staff cost._ Staff cost increased by €33,805 thousand, or 157%, to €55,342 thousand for the three months
ended March 31, 2021, from €21,537 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2020. This increase was
mainly the result of the increase in staff cost due to the higher number of employees resulting from
acquisitions in 2020 and 2021.


-----

_Media buying._ Media buying costs increased by €473 thousand, or 6%, to €8,417 thousand for the
three months ended March 31, 2021, from €7,944 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2020. This
increase was mainly a result of the Nova Broadcasting Group Acquisition, which offset the effects of the
COVID-19 pandemic (that is, which led to lower media buying volumes by Direct Media due to decreased
overall advertising spend).

_Depreciation._ Depreciation increased by €30,448 thousand, or 112%, to €57,574 thousand for the
three months ended March 31, 2021, from €27,126 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2020. This
increase was primarily due to the addition of tangible assets as a result of the acquisitions in 2020 and 2021.

_Depreciation (right-of-use assets)._ Depreciation (rights of use assets) increased by €10,249 thousand, or
185%, to €15,799 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2021, from €5,550 thousand for the
three months ended March 31, 2020. This increase was due to the acquisitions completed in 2020 and 2021.

_Amortization of intangible assets._ Amortization of intangible assets increased by €43,893 thousand, or 197%,
to €66,147 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2021, from €22,254 thousand for the three months
ended March 31, 2020. This increase was primarily due to the addition of intangible assets through the
acquisitions completed in 2020 and 2021.

_Other operating expenses._ Other operating expenses increased by €32,480 thousand, or 106%, to
€63,110 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2021, from €30,630 thousand for the three months
ended March 31, 2020. While all cost categories saw an increase, the largest increases were in maintenance,
license fee and marketing and promotion costs.

_Net finance costs._ Net finance costs increased by €4,189 thousand, or 13%, to €37,562 thousand for the
three months ended March 31, 2021, from €33,373 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2020. This
increase was primarily due to higher interest expense related to new bond issuances.

_Loss before tax._ Loss before tax decreased by €4,712 thousand, or 39%, to €7,233 thousand for the
three months ended March 31, 2021, from €11,945 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2020. This
change was primarily due to increased operating profit, which partially offset the higher net finance costs.

_Income tax expense._ Income tax expense increased by €1,254 thousand, or 88%, to €2,687 thousand for the
three months ended March 31, 2021, from €1,433 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2020.

_UG Adjusted EBITDA and UG Adjusted EBITDA Margin._ UG Adjusted EBITDA increased by
€94,570 thousand, or 112%, to €179,164 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2021, from
€84,594 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2020. This increase was primarily due to the impact
of the acquisitions of Tele2 Croatia, Vivacom and Forthnet, which were completed in March 2020, July 2020
and November 2020, respectively, as well as due to the organic growth of our subscriber base, price increases,
continued successful cross-selling, migration of subscribers to multiplay packages and effective cost discipline.

UG Adjusted EBITDA Margin decreased to 41% for the three months ended March 31, 2021, from 44% for
the three months ended March 31, 2020. This decrease was primarily due to the contribution of Telemach
Croatia and Vivacom which had lower UG Adjusted EBITDA Margin as compared to our other segments, as
well as the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic.
