_Slovenia Group segment._ Revenue for our Slovenia Group segment increased by €7,567 thousand, or 3%, to
€237,129 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2020, from €229,562 thousand for the year ended
December 31, 2019. This increase was primarily due to an increase in internet revenues (a result of successful
upselling and migration from legacy to EON packages with higher internet ARPU), higher mobile revenues
as a result of an increased number of subscribers and price increases in March and October 2020 and higher
mobile handset and other revenues (taking into account the effects of IFRS 15 and COVID-19-related
government subsidies).

_Serbia Group segment._ Revenue for our Serbia Group segment increased by €3,698 thousand, or 2%, to
€223,697 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2020, from €219,999 thousand for the year ended
December 31, 2019. This increase was primarily due to growth in the number of subscribers and and multiplay packages (particularly through successful cross-selling).

_Bosnia Group segment._ Revenue for our Bosnia Group segment decreased by €115 thousand, to
€72,537 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2020, from €72,652 thousand for the year ended
December 31, 2019. This decrease was primarily due to the accounting impact from the implementation of
IFRS 15 (primarily in relation to video and internet services).

_Montenegro Group segment._ Revenue for our Montenegro Group segment decreased by €992 thousand, or
7%, to €13,307 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2020, from €14,299 thousand for the year ended
December 31, 2019. This decrease was mainly due to a lower number of DTH subscribers in 2020.

_Media Group segment._ External revenue for our Media Group decreased by €26,206 thousand, or 14%, to
€158,886 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2020, from €185,092 thousand for the year ended
December 31, 2019. This decrease was due to the COVID-19 pandemic, primarily in the advertising and
media selling businesses. Total revenues of the Media Group segment (including intercompany revenues)
decreased by 5.3% year-on-year to €267,187 thousand in the year ended December 31, 2020.

_Other income._ Other income decreased by €1,508 thousand, or 17%, to €7,406 thousand for the year ended
December 31, 2020, from €8,914 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2019.

_Content costs._ Content costs increased by €6,321 thousand, or 5%, to €130,533 thousand for the year ended
December 31, 2020, from €124,212 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2019. This increase was
primarily due to the content costs of newly acquired channels.

_Link and interconnection costs._ Link and interconnection costs increased by €53,406 thousand, or 140%, to
€91,557 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2020, from €38,151 thousand for the year ended
December 31, 2019. This increase was primarily due to higher mobile link and interconnection costs due to
acquisitions in the period.

_Cost of end-user equipment and other material cost._ Material costs increased by €95,512 thousand, or 190%,
to €145,781 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2020, from €50,269 thousand for the year ended


-----

December 31, 2019. This increase was primarily due to the higher cost of sales for mobile handsets (mainly
due to the acquisitions of Vivacom and Tele2 Croatia), higher cost of goods sold (mainly in relation to goods
sold by Shoppster, which started operations in 2020) and higher energy and fuel costs mainly as a result of
acquisitions.

_Staff cost._ Staff cost increased by €32,712 thousand, or 32%, to €134,820 thousand for the year ended
December 31, 2020, from €102,108 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2019. This increase was
primarily due to the impact of additional staff costs from acquired companies. Staff costs in 2019 were
impacted by a one-time non-charge of €21,659 thousand resulting from the application of IFRS 2 in relation
to a long-term incentive scheme (LTIS).

_Media buying._ Media buying costs decreased by €1,513 thousand, or 4%, to €38,168 thousand for the year
ended December 31, 2020, from €39,681 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2019. This increase was
primarily due to generally lower advertising expenditures as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic.

_Depreciation._ Depreciation increased by €54,891 thousand, or 51%, to €161,719 thousand for the year ended
December 31, 2020, from €106,828 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2019. This increase was
primarily due to the acquisition of new tangible assets as a result of the acquisitions of Vivacom, Forthnet
and Tele2 Croatia.

_Depreciation (right-of-use assets)._ Depreciation (right-of-use assets) was €42,793 thousand for the year
ended December 31, 2020, compared to €17,972 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2019, an increase
of €24,821, or 138%. This increase was primarily due to the acquisitions of Vivacom, Forthnet and Tele2
Croatia.

_Amortization of intangible assets. Amortization of intangible assets increased by €60,998 thousand, or 74%,_
to €143,278 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2020, from €82,280 thousand for the year ended
December 31, 2019. This increase was primarily due to the addition of intangible assets of acquired
companies.

_Other operating expenses._ Other operating expenses increased by €79,819 thousand, or 67%, to
€199,221 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2020, from €119,402 thousand for the year ended
December 31, 2019. This decrease was primarily due to higher legal and advisory fees (including related to
acquisition-related activities) and higher maintenance and license fee costs which mainly resulted from the
acquisitions of Vivacom, Forthnet and Tele2 Croatia.

_Net finance costs._ Net finance costs increased by €28,736 thousand, or 28%, to €133,005 thousand for the
year ended December 31, 2020, from €104,269 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2019. This increase
was primarily due to higher interest expense related to new bond issuances .

_Loss before tax._ Loss before tax increased by €11,914 thousand, or 23%, to €64,536 thousand for the year
ended December 31, 2020, from €52,622 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2019. This increase was
primarily due to increased net finance costs, which more than offset the operating profit increase of
€16,822 thousand.

_Income tax expense._ Income tax expense increased by €476 thousand, or 6%, to €7,890 thousand for the
year ended December 31, 2020, from €7,414 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2019.

_UG Adjusted EBITDA and UG Adjusted EBITDA Margin._ UG Adjusted EBITDA increased by
€185,944 thousand, or 63%, to €481,338 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2020, from
€295,394 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2019. This increase was primarily due to an increase in
revenues as a result of acquisitions completed in 2020, the organic growth of our subscribers, price increases,
continued cross-selling as well as effective cost discipline.

UG Adjusted EBITDA Margin increased to 41% for the year ended December 31, 2020, from 40% for the
year ended December 31, 2019, primarily due to the impact of the Media Group segment which had lower
UG Adjusted EBITDA Margin in 2019 as compared to 2018, largely as a result of Telemach Croatia and
Vivacom which had lower UG Adjusted EBITDA Margin as compared to our other segments, as well as the
negative impact of the COVID-19 pandemic.

We discuss below UG Adjusted EBITDA by segment for the year ended December 31, 2020, compared to the
year ended December 31, 2019.

_Slovenia Group segment._ UG Adjusted EBITDA increased by €15,295 thousand, or 21%, to
€89,399 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2020, from €74,104 thousand for the year ended


-----

December 31, 2019, primarily due to the organic growth of fixed and mobile RGUs and the price increase of
mobile services in March and October 2020 and fixed services in October 2020.

_Serbia Group segment._ UG Adjusted EBITDA increased by €10,064 thousand, or 9%, to €127,007 thousand
for the year ended December 31, 2020, from €116,943 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2019,
primarily due to higher revenues from the organic growth of our subscriber base through cross-selling and
strict cost control, which was partially offset by increased programming costs.

_Bosnia Group segment._ UG Adjusted EBITDA decreased by €2,420 thousand, or 9%, to €23,993 thousand
for the year ended December 31, 2020, from €26,413 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2019. This
decrease was primarily due to higher programming costs resulting from the introduction of the new channel
Nova BH, with an annual cost of €2,474 thousand and increased costs for our Sportklub channels. The
increase in programming costs was partly offset by savings achieved on other operating expenses.

_Montenegro Group segment._ UG Adjusted EBITDA decreased by €487 thousand, or 15%, to
€2,732 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2020, from €3,219 thousand for the year ended
December 31, 2019, primarily due to a 7% decrease in revenues, which was only partially offset by decreased
costs and operating expenses.

_Media Group segment._ UG Adjusted EBITDA decreased by €2,255 thousand, or 3%, to €77,874 thousand
for the year ended December 31, 2020, from €80,129 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2019,
primarily due to the decrease in total revenues as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic, primarily in the
advertising and media selling businesses.

_Slovenia Group segment._ Revenue for our Slovenia Group segment increased by €10,093 thousand, or 5%, to
€229,562 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2019, from €219,469 thousand for the year ended
December 31, 2018. This increase was primarily due to an increased number of mobile-telephony subscribers,
increased mobile handset sales and price increases in February 2019 in fixed-telephony.

_Serbia Group segment._ Revenue for our Serbia Group segment increased by €14,865 thousand, or 7%, to
€219,999 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2019, from €205,134 thousand for the year ended
December 31, 2018. This increase was primarily due to growth in the number of subscribers and RGUs
(particularly through cross-selling) and the implementation of a price increase in January 2019.

_Bosnia Group segment._ Revenue for our Bosnia Group segment increased by €4,911 thousand, or 7%, to
€72,652 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2019, from €67,741 thousand for the year ended
December 31, 2018. This increase was primarily due to organic growth, an increase in the number of
subscribers for our multi-play offering (digital TV, broadband internet and fixed-line telephony), and price
increases in April 2019.

_Montenegro Group segment._ Revenue for our Montenegro Group segment increased by €597 thousand, or
4%, to €14,299 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2019, from €13,702 thousand for the year ended
December 31, 2018. This increase was primarily due to an increase in the number of multi-play subscribers.

_Media Group segment._ Revenue for our Media Group increased by €76,083 thousand, or 70%, to
€185,092 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2019, from €109,009 thousand for the year ended
December 31, 2018. This increase was primarily due to an increase in the number of multi-play subscribers
and organic growth in both carriage fees and advertising, and the contribution from the acquisitions of Direct
Media in September 2018 and Nova TV.

_Other income._ Other income decreased by €6,415 thousand, or 42%, to €8,914 thousand for the year ended
December 31, 2019, from €15,329 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2018. This decrease was
primarily due to the divestment of Totalna TV Croatia in the first quarter of 2018.

_Content costs._ Content costs increased by €20,938 thousand, or 20%, to €124,212 thousand for the year
ended December 31, 2019, from €103,274 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2018. This increase was
primarily due to United Media’s acquisitions of TV channels (Nova TV in Croatia, Bosnia & Herzegovina
and Montenegro) and increased sports rights costs.

_Satellite capacity costs._ With effect from January 1, 2019, satellite capacity costs are presented under
depreciation and finance costs due to the adoption of IFRS 16.


-----

_Link and interconnection costs._ Link and interconnection costs decreased by €2,903 thousand, or 7%, to
€38,151 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2019, from €41,054 thousand for the year ended
December 31, 2018. This decrease was primarily due to lower mobile link and interconnection costs.

_Cost of end-user equipment and other material cost._ Material costs increased by €4,646 thousand, or 10%, to
€50,269 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2019, from €45,623 thousand for the year ended
December 31, 2018. This increase was primarily due to the higher cost of sales for mobile handsets as a result
of increased sales volumes and higher energy and fuel costs.

_Staff cost._ Staff cost increased by €3,097 thousand, or 3%, to €102,108 thousand for the year ended
December 31, 2019, from €99,011 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2018. This increase was primarily
due to the impact of additional staff costs from acquired companies. Out of the total amount of staff cost in
the year ended December 31, 2019, €21,659 thousand related to the non-cash impact of the application of
IFRS 2 in relation to an LTIS and was the main driver of increased staff costs, as compared to
€32,809 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2018. On May 16, 2018, the shareholders of our former
ultimate holding company, Adria LuxCo S.à r.l. entered into the LTIS for the benefit of certain members of
our current and future management team. The LTIS consisted of a payment by the shareholders of Adria
LuxCo S.à r.l. following completion of an initial public offering or a sale of the Group. The amount of the
payment was calculated as a percentage of the proceeds received by the shareholders of Adria LuxCo S.à r.l.
and is based on the accumulated return on investment achieved by such shareholders. In addition, the increase
was due in part to our continued expansion, both organic and through acquisitions, of the Group during
2018.

_Media buying._ Media buying costs increased by €19,661 thousand, or 98%, to €39,681 thousand for the year
ended December 31, 2019, from €20,020 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2018. This increase was
primarily due to the full-year effect of the acquisition of Direct Media in September 2018.

_Depreciation._ Depreciation increased by €7,186 thousand, or 7%, to €106,828 thousand for the year ended
December 31, 2019, from €99,642 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2018. This increase was primarily
due to the expansion of our cable and mobile networks, increased investment in own produced content and
new assets from acquisitions.

_Depreciation (right-of-use assets)._ Depreciation (right-of-use assets) was €17,972 thousand for the year
ended December 31, 2019, compared to nil for the year ended December 31, 2018. This was due to the result
of the implementation of IFRS 16 on January 1, 2019.

_Amortization of intangible assets._ Amortization of intangible assets increased by €13,797 thousand, or 20%,
to €82,280 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2019, from €68,483 thousand for the year ended
December 31, 2018. This increase was primarily due to increased investments in programming rights and own
production, as well as the addition of intangible assets of acquired companies.

_Other operating expenses._ Other operating expenses decreased by €4,639 thousand, or 4%, to
€119,402 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2019, from €124,041 thousand for the year ended
December 31, 2018. This decrease was primarily due to the implementation of IFRS 16 and lower legal and
advisory fees related to M&A activities.

_Net finance costs._ Net finance costs increased by €40,607 thousand, or 64%, to €104,269 thousand for the
year ended December 31, 2019, from €63,662 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2018. This increase
was primarily due to higher interest expenses and costs of an early redemption option that was exercised in
the January 2020.

_Loss before tax._ Loss before tax increased by €9,669 thousand, or 23%, to €52,622 thousand for the year
ended December 31, 2019, from €42,953 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2018. This increase was
primarily due to increased finance costs.

_Income tax expense._ Income tax expense increased by €4,368 thousand, or 143%, to €7,414 thousand for the
year ended December 31, 2019, from €3,046 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2018. This increase
was primarily due to a decrease in deferred tax as a consequence of the merger of SBB with IKOM and a
higher level of income tax expense.

_UG Adjusted EBITDA and UG Adjusted EBITDA Margin._ UG Adjusted EBITDA increased by
€34,768 thousand, or 13%, to €295,394 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2019, from
€260,626 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2018. This increase was primarily due to an increase in
revenues as a result of the organic growth of our subscribers, price increases, continued cross-selling, effective


-----

cost discipline, and the impact of acquisitions of Nova TV (Croatia, Bosnia and Montenegro) and media
selling companies (Serbia) in the second half of 2018.

UG Adjusted EBITDA Margin decreased to 40% for the year ended December 31, 2019, from 41% for the
year ended December 31, 2018, primarily due to the impact of the Media Group segment which had lower
UG Adjusted EBITDA Margin in 2019 as compared to 2018, largely as a result of acquisitions.

We discuss below UG Adjusted EBITDA by segment for the year ended December 31, 2019, compared to the
year ended December 31, 2018.

_Slovenia Group segment._ UG Adjusted EBITDA increased by €2,674 thousand, or 4%, to €74,104 thousand
for the year ended December 31, 2019, from €71,430 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2018,
primarily due to the organic growth of mobile RGUs and the price increase of mobile services in
December 2018 and fixed services in February 2019.

_Serbia Group segment._ UG Adjusted EBITDA increased by €3,919 thousand, or 3%, to €116,943 thousand
for the year ended December 31, 2019, from €113,024 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2018,
primarily due to higher revenues from the organic growth of our subscriber base and a price increase in
January 2019, which was partially offset by increased programming costs and strict cost control.

_Bosnia Group segment._ UG Adjusted EBITDA increased by €2,982 thousand, or 13%, to €26,413 thousand
for the year ended December 31, 2019, from €23,431 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2018,
primarily due to a revenue increase driven by price increases for subscriptions for the Bosnia Group’s cable
platform in April 2018 and April 2019 and satellite platform in January 2019, and an increase in the number
of subscribers with higher priced subscriptions.

_Montenegro Group segment._ UG Adjusted EBITDA decreased by €107 thousand, or 3%, to €3,219 thousand
for the year ended December 31, 2019, from €3,326 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2018, primarily
due to an increase in direct costs and operational expenses which offset the revenue increase resulting from the
organic growth of the subscriber base and the increase in the number of multi-play subscribers.

_Media Group segment._ UG Adjusted EBITDA increased by €28,710 thousand, or 56%, to €80,129 thousand
for the year ended December 31, 2019, from €51,419 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2018,
primarily due to the contribution of the acquisitions of Nova TV (Croatia, Bosnia, and Montenegro) and
media selling companies in Serbia in the second half of 2018, offset by organic growth in 2019 due to increased
carriage revenues.

**Liquidity and Capital Resources**

Our primary sources of liquidity and funds for UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure, acquisitions and other
investments are operating cash flow, the Existing Revolving Credit Facility, potential additional issuances of
debt securities, ancillary and bilateral lending facilities and finance leases. Our ability to generate cash from
our operations will depend on our future operating performance, which is in turn dependent, to some extent,
on general economic, financial, competitive, market, regulatory and other factors, many of which are beyond
our control.

We maintain cash and cash equivalents to fund the day-to-day requirements of our business. We hold cash
primarily in euros as well as Serbian dinars, Bosnian marks, Bulgarian levs and Croatian kuna.

Historically, we have relied primarily on our the Existing Revolving Credit Facility and bilateral bank facilities,
other debt facilities and cash flow from operations to provide funds required for investments in UG Adjusted
Capital Expenditure and operations.

As of March 31, 2021, we had €166.0 million of cash and cash equivalents.

As of March 31, 2021, we had €3,388 million of outstanding indebtedness (excluding lease liabilities) on a
historical basis. This included, as of March 31, 2021, €3,300.0 million in aggregate principal amount of
Existing Notes (excluding transactions costs and fees related to the issuance thereof) along with the partially
drawn Existing Revolving Credit Facility of €73.0 million, a €10.0 million unsecured bilateral revolving credit
facility in Serbia, other financial liabilities related to bank secured loans of €2.9 million and finance leases of
€2.0 million. This amount excludes €289.7 million of lease liabilities and €287.6 million of lease liabilities that
would have been considered operating leases prior to the adoption of IFRS 16. After giving effect to the
Existing Revolving Credit Facility 2021 Increase, we expect to have up to €325 million of commitments under
the Existing Revolving Credit Facility.

**UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure**

UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure relates primarily to the purchase of property and equipment, including
expansion of our network in terms of capacity and new homes connected, purchase of modems and set-top
boxes to be installed in customer premises, growth in RGUs and maintenance of our cable and mobile
networks and infrastructure, purchase of intangible assets such as content, software, investments in our core
infrastructure and systems to facilitate the addition of new services and acquisitions. Therefore, UG Adjusted
Capital Expenditure is primarily driven by extending, upgrading and maintaining our cable and mobile
networks, the installation and in home wiring for new subscribers, the cost of cable modems, including highspeed modems for subscribers to our high-speed broadband internet, and the acquisition of content. UG
Adjusted Capital Expenditure has also historically included certain investments of a non-recurring nature, as
well as costs to integrate acquired businesses.

UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure also includes increases in intangible assets (except our customer list and
brand names) and does not include financial assets. As part of our strategy to focus on UG Adjusted Capital
Expenditure improving returns, we implemented measures to ensure a more efficient usage of capital
investment. We intend to manage UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure to maintain our well invested asset base.
The members of our board of directors review all material UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure programs.

For a further description of UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure, see “—Key Factors Affecting Comparability
_of Our Results of Operations—UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure.”_

Over the next several years, we expect that UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure will be largely success and
capacity based. Success and capacity based UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure includes UG Adjusted Capital
Expenditure related to the expansion of our network footprint to additional homes and existing subscribers,
the replacement of set-top boxes, expanding network capacity, new product and service development and
expenditure incurred when connecting business subscribers to our network. Success based UG Adjusted
Capital Expenditure does not include UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure for maintenance, upgrade and
replacement of our systems and infrastructure.

For the three months ended March 31, 2021, UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure amounted to €91 million,
compared to €58 million for the three months ended March 31, 2020 and included mainly investments in

network expansion, customer premise equipment, as well as the purchase of new programming rights and
investments in mobile infrastructure.

**Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures About Market Risk**

**_Interest Rate Risk_**

Our income and cash flow from operations are affected by changes in market interest rates. Some items on our
balance sheet, such as cash and bank balances, interest bearing investments and borrowings, are exposed to
interest rate risk.

Borrowings under the Existing Revolving Credit Facility and the Existing Floating Rate Notes bear interest at
varying rates, and as a result we will have interest risk with respect to this debt. Interest rate hedging
arrangements are not in place as of the Issue Date with respect to the debt under our Existing Revolving


-----

Credit Facility or the Existing Floating Rate Notes. For fixed rate debt, interest rate changes affect the fair
market value of such debt, but do not impact earnings or cash flow.

**_Currency Risk_**

Currency risk arises when future commercial transactions or recognized assets or liabilities are denominated
in a currency that is not the functional currency of the Group entity holding the asset or obligation. As a
result of our operations in various countries, we generate a significant portion of our sales and incur a
significant portion of our expenses in currencies other than the euro. Our primary exposure is to the Serbian
dinar. For the three months ended March 31, 2021, 15% of our revenue was denominated in Serbian dinars.
The Bosnia and Herzegovinian mark is pegged to the euro, while the Croatian kuna and North Macedonian
dinar are relatively stable. In March 2015, we entered into a EUR/USD currency hedge agreement, pursuant
to which we hedge our exposure to the U.S. dollar. We entered into an additional EUR/USD currency hedge
agreement in May 2016 pursuant to which we hedged the remaining portion of our exposure to the U.S.
dollar for 2016. In February 2017, we entered into an additional EUR/USD currency hedge, which hedged
most of our 2017 U.S. dollar exposure. Based on our lack of any material change in exposure to the U.S.
dollar in the three months ended March 31, 2021, we did not enter into any additional currency hedge
agreements during the three months ended March 31, 2021.

As the Bulgarian lev is pegged to the euro, we do not expect to hedge against exposure to the Bulgarian lev.

**_Translation Risk_**

Translation risk is the risk that the value in euro of the consolidated profit and loss statement and balance
sheet will fluctuate due to changes in foreign exchange rates connected with the translation of our subsidiaries
that do not have the euro as their functional currency. Since January 1, 2016, almost all our indebtedness has
been denominated in euros.

**_Transaction Risk_**

Transaction risk is the risk of exchange losses incurred by us through purchases and sales in currencies other
than the local currency of the relevant subsidiaries.

**Vivacom’s Business Overview**

We acquired Vivacom in the Vivacom Acquisition on July 31, 2020. Since the completion of the Vivacom
Acquisition, Vivacom’s results have been consolidated with ours as part of our Bulgaria Group segment.

Vivacom is the market leading integrated telecommunications operator in Bulgaria (based on revenue for the
year ended December 31, 2020) offering both fixed and mobile telecommunications services, as well as
broadcasting and satellite services, with a market share of 30% in Bulgaria by revenue as of December 31,
2020, according to the CRC.

Vivacom provides mobile, broadband, fixed-telephony, and Pay-TV (both DTH and IPTV) services in
Bulgaria to residential and business customers. Vivacom is the leading operator of fixed-line telephony services
in Bulgaria (60% market share), the leading provider of broadband in Bulgaria (27% market share), the
number three provider of mobile-telephony services in Bulgaria (29% market share in the three player mobile
market) and the number three provider of Pay-TV in Bulgaria (26% market share), in each case, as of
December 31, 2020, based on the number of subscribers, according to the CRC. Vivacom has consistently
taken market share across most of its segments in recent years. Vivacom as of March 31, 2021, had
2,961 million mobile subscribers, 573 thousand fixed-line telephony subscribers, 464 thousand fixed
broadband subscribers and 489 thousand Pay-TV subscribers. Vivacom operates a well invested, fully owned
and integrated fiber backbone network and has an extensive fiber to the home / fiber to the business network
in Bulgaria. It also operates the fastest mobile network in Bulgaria, with an award-winning LTE network,
covering 99% of the population. The quality of Vivacom’s network, implementation of operational efficiencies
and consolidation of services under one brand have led to high customer satisfaction and decreasing churn
rates.

Bulgaria is a relatively large, economically stable and mostly urban nation of seven million people and three
million households. Bulgaria presents an attractive market, with rational and growing mobile markets, with a
high and growing share of the market consisting mostly of post-paid mobile subscriptions, with increasing
broadband penetration and migration to IPTV. Bulgaria presents a favorable business environment with
average real GDP growth of 3.3% each year between 2017 and 2019 (according to the BNSI), compared to the
euro area average of 1.9% during the same period, according to the IMF, a flat corporate income tax and low
public debt compared to the EU average. The Bulgarian lev is pegged to the euro.

Vivacom has historically been consistently profitable, with Vivacom Adjusted EBITDA having increased by a
CAGR of 9% between 2018 and 2020 and Vivacom Adjusted EBITDA margin (calculated as Vivacom
Adjusted EBITDA divided by revenue) was 45% for the year ended December 31, 2020, and cash generative,
with an attractive adjusted capital expenditure and adjusted operating free cash flow profile, with Vivacom
Operating Free Cash Flow having increased by a CAGR of 24% between 2018 and 2020.

Vivacom generates most of its revenue from the provision of mobile services and fixed-line voice telephony
and data services (including Pay-TV). Vivacom also provides TV and radio broadcasting services through its
NURTS business segment. Vivacom believes that its ability to provide nationwide bundled offerings (“dual
play, “triple play” or “quadruple play”) provides an important competitive advantage.

_Mobile_

Vivacom’s mobile segment comprises its mobile services, both voice and data, and its other mobile business,
which includes among other things, the sale of mobile handsets. Vivacom’s mobile revenue is principally
driven by its average number of subscribers and ARPU. For the year ended December 31, 2020, revenue
generated by Vivacom’s mobile segment comprised 63% of its total revenue.

The Bulgarian mobile market is characterized by high penetration rates and high levels of competition. As a
result, Vivacom’s mobile subscriber base depends on a number of factors, including pricing, quality of service,
availability of new services, overall market growth, the level of competition to obtain new subscribers,
retaining existing subscribers, its ability to cause existing subscribers to use their Vivacom SIM card as their
primary SIM card (rather than as an alternate SIM card) and general economic conditions in Bulgaria. As a
result of more customer favorable tariffs, including minutes to other operators and high data consumption
limits, Vivacom believes that mobile subscribers will gradually cease using multiple SIM cards but rather
choose one mobile operator.

Mobile services ARPU is driven primarily by recurring charges from post-paid subscribers, traffic volume,
data services utilization, revenue from interconnection rates and its prices. Vivacom’s prices, in turn, are mainly
driven by the level of competition and the increasing demand for mobile data. Ultimately, Vivacom
management believes that the increasing demand for mobile data is leading to increasing ARPU due to the
higher contributions from data ARPU.

_Fixed-line_

Vivacom’s fixed-line segment comprises its fixed voice services, fixed data services, fixed Pay-TV services and
other fixed business, which includes its wholesale duct rental business. For the year ended December 31, 2020,
revenue generated by Vivacom’s fixed-line segment comprised 36% of its total revenue.

Fixed-Voice: Fixed-telephony and Other

Vivacom’s fixed voice services include fixed-telephony and other fixed voice services. For the year ended
December 31, 2020, revenues generated by Vivacom’s fixed voice services comprised 7% of its total revenue.

Fixed-telephony subscriber levels depend on a number of factors, including pricing, the availability of new
services and technologies, Vivacom’s ability to retain existing subscribers and win subscribers from
competitors as well as general economic conditions in Bulgaria. Vivacom’s fixed-telephony subscriber numbers
are gradually declining due to fixed-to-mobile substitution by customers and mobile operators’ fixedtelephony offerings, which undercut its prices and attract price sensitive customers.

Wholesale traffic consists primarily of international transit traffic passing through Vivacom’s network to
other national or international operators. Vivacom’s wholesale traffic business has low margins and is
susceptible to volume volatility depending on the transit prices it sets, which transit prices change based on its
wholesale interconnect expenses.


-----

Fixed-Data: Fixed Broadband and Other

Fixed data revenue, which includes revenue from fixed broadband and other data services is principally
affected by the average number of subscribers and ARPU, which in turn depend on Vivacom’s prices and the
speed and quality of connections that it is able to provide to its customers. For the year ended December 31,
2020, revenue generated by Vivacom’s fixed data services comprised 9% of its total revenue.

Vivacom’s fixed data services comprises its fixed broadband services provided over ADSL, VDSL and FTTx
connections to both residential and business customers and other data services, which include complex IP
based data solutions for large business customers (including VPN and MAN services) as well as its “legacy”
leased lines services that are mainly used by its security conscious business customers, such as financial
institutions, who are looking for dedicated data capacity. If the enforcement of regulations against “grey
market” operators increases as expected, the penetration rate of fixed data services is likely to grow.
Additionally, subscribers are seeking higher broadband speeds and better connection quality, which are priced
at a premium.

Revenue from other fixed data services is generated from Vivacom’s professional internet, IP VPN and MAN
services and complex corporate data solutions offered to business customers, as well as the sale of CPEs. The
provision of additional services, nationwide offerings and quality backed service level agreements contribute
to Vivacom’s ARPU.

Fixed pay-TV

Vivacom launched its DTH television service in 2010 and IPTV service in 2012, and is currently positioned as
a fully integrated “quadruple play”operator offering nationwide coverage in Bulgaria. Vivacom’s DTH service
delivers television content directly to its customers’ homes via satellite while its IPTV service is a fully
digitalized platform delivering television content via Internet connectivity, which provides a variety of
television channels, video on demand and a range of interactive features, including its over-the-top TV
solution, TV GO.

Vivacom’s Pay-TV revenue is principally driven by the number of subscribers and the services that they select.
Vivacom offers a variety of services through both DTH and IPTV, including packages with over 240 channels
that include more than 75 HD channels, exclusive content and other interactive services on its IPTV platform.
For the year ended December 31, 2020, revenue generated by Vivacom’s fixed Pay-TV services comprised 10%
of its total revenue.

Fixed-Other

Vivacom’s other fixed businesses are comprised of various services. For the year ended December 31, 2020,
revenues generated by Vivacom’s other fixed business accounted for 11% of its total revenue. These include
wholesale services to other licensed telecommunications operations, such as duct rental and collocation of
equipment. Various digital and cloud services, including cloud IaaS, managed cloud VPS, shared web and
e-mail hosting, SSL certificates, collocation, fleet management platform and others are also offered to business
customers. Vivacom’s specific projects under the “VIVA Smart” brand, including smart city, Internet of
Things (“IoT”), video surveillance, electronic education and other innovative solutions are also areas of
potential expansion.

**_Termination Rates_**

Vivacom generates revenue from access and interconnection fees received from other network operators for
calls terminated on its network, and it is required to pay access and interconnection fees to other network
operators for calls terminated on their networks, in each case both domestic and international. These access
and interconnection fees are based on set termination rates for both fixed-line calls (“FTRs”) and mobile
calls, which affect both mobile and fixed-telephony revenues and costs. Termination rates are regulated by the
Communications Regulation Commission (“CRC”) in Bulgaria.

**_General Economic Conditions in Bulgaria_**

Many European countries have faced or are facing an economic slowdown or low rates of GDP growth,
including as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic, which may include a general contraction in consumer
spending resulting from, among other factors, reduced consumer confidence, falling gross domestic product,
declining populations, rising or stagnating unemployment rates and uncertainty in the macroeconomic
environment. Although the general economic climate in Bulgaria has also seen negative effects, the Bulgarian


-----

economy has historically demonstrated economic growth and fiscal stability with low levels of government
debt. According to the BNSI, Bulgaria’s real GDP grew at an average rate of 3.3% each year between 2017
and 2019.

Following the outbreak of the COVID-19 pandemic, on March 13, 2020 the Bulgarian parliament declared a
state of emergency in Bulgaria and on March 23, 2020, it adopted certain measures and actions aimed at
mitigating the negative consequences of the pandemic on citizens and businesses. Subsequently, similar
extraordinary measures were introduced, some of which are still in effect since May 14, 2020. The Bulgarian
Minister of Healthcare and the Bulgarian parliament adopted several social distancing and other restrictive
measures, particularly with respect to access to restaurants, shopping centers and other commercial facilities,
aimed at managing the spread of the pandemic, which have had a material adverse impact on the overall
economy of Bulgaria. As of the date of this offering memorandum, even though the most restrictive social
distancing measures were lifted and the Bulgarian government has implemented economic recovery measures
while new infections have decreased, certain restrictions and social distancing measures remain in place, and
additional restrictions could be reinstated at any time and at different levels as new variants of the virus
spread. Such existing and potential measures may continue to adversely affect the overall economy of Bulgaria
and could have a material adverse impact on Vivacom’s results of operations, in particular on its ARPUs and
roaming revenues. However, these effects have been partially offset by the decrease in interconnect and roaming
expenses. A potential prolonged recession and a deepening economic crisis due to the COVID-19 pandemic
could impact Vivacom’s growth prospects, customer spending and collection, and may result in assumptions
and estimates that could trigger material adjustments to the carrying value of assets and liabilities in the
future.

Vivacom operates in the telecommunications sector, for which underlying customer demand has in the past
been less cyclical than a number of other areas of consumer spending. However, the general macroeconomic
environment could still have an adverse effect on consumer spending. In poor economic conditions, consumers
are likely to delay the replacement of their existing mobile phones or may be more likely to disconnect or
cancel their services. Generally, weak economic conditions may weigh on the growth prospects of the
telecommunications market in Bulgaria, which in turn may negatively impact Vivacom’s number of
subscribers and ARPU.

**_Competition_**

Vivacom faces competition from the two other major Bulgarian mobile network operators, A1 Bulgaria and
Telenor Bulgaria, each of which holds a greater share of the mobile market than does Vivacom. Vivacom’s
mobile service revenue market share was approximately 29% as of December 31, 2020 according to the CRC.
Vivacom is the market leader in the fixed broadband market, with a 27% subscriber market share as of
December 31, 2020, followed by A1 Bulgaria and Bulsatcom, according to the CRC. In the Bulgarian fixed
broadband market, Vivacom competes primarily with A1 Bulgaria, Telenor Bulgaria, Bulsatcom and a
significant number of small-scale regional operators. Many of the small-scale operators are considered to
operate in the “grey market”as they do not pay taxes or license fees and use illegal aerial cables to deliver their
fixed broadband services, which gives them an anticompetitive advantage, as they are able to offer lower
priced fixed broadband products. If the enforcement of regulations against “grey market”operators increases,
as Vivacom management expects, its penetration rate is expected to increase.

Vivacom’s primary competitors have pursued aggressive marketing and pricing strategies to retain and expand
their respective market shares which, if further pursued in the future, could reduce Vivacom’s margins, cause
Vivacom to increase its marketing and promotional expenses in response to such strategies and result in
increased customer churn. In addition, the competitive nature of the market in which Vivacom operates may
be exacerbated by new market entrants or the consolidation of some of its primary competitors. Vivacom
tries to avoid direct price competition and believes that its revenues and profitability will be supported by
continued growth in the number of its subscribers, cross-selling and up selling of services, the launch of
innovative new services and the active management of its subscriber acquisition, maintenance and retention
costs.

Total fixed-telephony ARPU increased by 1% to BGN 10.2 for the year ended December 31, 2020, from

due to increased take-up of more generous tariffs with higher monthly recurring charges.

Total fixed-telephony ARPU increased by 2% to BGN 10.1 for the year ended December 31, 2019, from
BGN 9.9 for the year ended December 31, 2018. The increase in total fixed-telephony ARPU was primarily
due to the introduction of more generous tariffs with included minutes by destinations.

Fixed Broadband

Vivacom’s fixed broadband subscribers increased by 3% to 475 thousand as of December 31, 2020, from
459 thousand as of December 31, 2019. This increase was mainly due to higher FTTx connections driven by
growing demand for high-speed bandwidth capacity and reliable broadband service.

Vivacom’s total fixed broadband subscribers increased by 3% to 459 thousand as of December 31, 2019, from
444 thousand as at December 31, 2018. This increase was mainly due to higher FTTx connections driven by
growing demand for high-speed bandwidth capacity and reliable broadband service.

Vivacom’s fixed broadband ARPU decreased by 0.1% to BGN 10.1 for the year ended December 31, 2020,
from BGN 10.2 for the year ended December 31, 2019. This decrease was primarily due to bundling discounts
and price competition from other alternative operators, which were partially offset by a growing share of
tariffs with high bandwidth capacity.

Vivacom’s total fixed broadband ARPU increased by 7% to BGN 10.2 for the year ended December 31, 2019,
from BGN 9.5 for the year ended December 31, 2018. This increase was primarily due to a growing share of
tariffs with high bandwidth capacity, despite bundling discounts and price competition from alternative
operators.

Fixed Pay-TV

services with superior user experience, rich content and HD channels.

Vivacom’s total fixed Pay-TV subscribers also increased 5% to 490 thousand as of December 31, 2019, from
468 thousand as of December 31, 2018. This increase was mainly due to the increased demand for high-quality
services with superior user experience, rich content and HD channels.

Vivacom’s total fixed Pay-TV ARPU increased by 5% to BGN 17.5 for the year ended December 31, 2020,
from BGN 16.7 for the year ended December 31, 2019. This increase was mainly attributable to the growing
share of tariffs with higher monthly recurring fees and additional packages with rich content and sports
channels.

Vivacom’s total fixed Pay-TV ARPU also increased by 10% to BGN 16.7 for the year ended December 31,
2019, from BGN 15.2 for the year ended December 31, 2018. This increase was mainly attributable to the
growing share of tariffs with higher monthly recurring fees and additional packages with rich content.

**_Implementation of Accounting Policies_**

_IFRS 16 Leases_

Under IFRS 16, a lessee is required to recognize assets and liabilities for principally all leases on its balance
sheet. Vivacom adopted the new standard on January 1, 2019 but has not restated comparatives for the 2018


-----

reporting period. The reclassifications and the adjustments arising from the new leasing rules are recognized
on Vivacom’s opening balance sheet on January 1, 2019. On transition to IFRS 16, Vivacom recognized an
additional BGN 258,676 thousand of right-of-use assets and BGN 259,403 thousand of lease liabilities.

**Explanation of Key Income Statement Items**

**_Revenue_**

Vivacom’s revenue recognition policy comprises all revenues from the ordinary business activities, including
not only revenues generated by core businesses, but also other recurring sales of goods or rendering of services,
and income from contractual penalties and default interest. Revenues are recognized net of value added tax in
accordance with the provision of goods or services. Gains from sales of property, plant and equipment,
investment property or intangible assets are not classified as revenue but presented in other gains and losses,
net.

Following the mandatory implementation of IFRS 15 effective as of January 1, 2018, Vivacom presents its
revenues in three main categories.

_Services Revenue_

Services revenue is generated from principal activities including provision of mobile and fixed voice and data
services, broadband internet access, Pay-TV services (DTH and IPTV), rent of terrestrial network (ducts), TV
and radio broadcasting, collocation services, connection and roaming fees billed to other operators. Services
revenue is recognized upon rendering of the agreed service. Services are usually billed and paid for on a
monthly basis. For service contracts with a continuous service provision, the contractually agreed total
consideration is recognized as revenue on a straight-line basis over the minimum contract term, regardless of
the payment pattern.

_Equipment Revenue_

Equipment revenue comprises the sale or lease of mobile handsets, other telecommunications equipment, and
accessories. Revenue associated with the sale of telecommunications equipment and accessories are recognized
when the products are delivered, provided there are no unfulfilled obligations that affect the customer’s final
acceptance of the arrangement. For telecommunications equipment sold separately, customers pay in full at
the point of sale. For devices sold or lease in combination with a term service contract, customers usually pay
monthly in equal instalments over a period of 12 or 24 months.

_Other Revenue_

Other revenue primarily includes penalties, revenues from marketing activities and revenues from assigned
overdue customer receivables, commission fees and rental income.

**_Interconnect Expenses_**

Interconnect expenses relate to the costs incurred when Vivacom’s customers’ calls are terminated on another
operator’s network or when its customers use the mobile network of other operators when roaming.

**_Other Operating Expenses_**

Other operating expenses include maintenance and repair costs for network and information systems, the
charged provisions for impairment of assets, costs of advertising, facilities and license fees and administrative
and professional costs amongst others. Prior to the financial period beginning January 1, 2012, Vivacom
recorded costs of value added services as other operating expenses, whereas subsequently revenue from value
added services has been recorded net of costs. With effect from January 1, 2019, the amount of recognized
losses for impairment of financial and contract assets is included under the separate line item “Net impairment
losses on financial and contract assets.”

**_Net Impairment Losses on Financial and Contract Assets_**

Net impairment losses on financial and contract assets include the amount of recognized losses resulting
from the impairment of financial and contract assets, which were previously included under “Other operating
_expenses” prior to the financial period beginning January 1, 2019._


-----

**_Materials and Consumables Expenses_**

Materials and consumables expenses are comprised of the costs of the materials consumed by Vivacom’s
business during the respective period, including the costs associated with mobile handsets sold and CPEs sold
and leased as well as electricity expenses.

**_Staff Costs_**

Staff costs include salaries, wages and bonuses, and pension, health and unemployment fund contributions.

**_Depreciation and Amortization_**

Vivacom’s tangible and intangible assets are depreciated and amortized on a straight-line basis over the best
estimate of their useful lives.

**_Finance Income and Costs_**

Finance income and costs include interest income on bank deposits and finance leases and interest expense on
borrowings and foreign exchange gain and loss.

**_Other Gains and Losses, Net_**

Other gains and losses, net comprises the result from sales of non-current assets and materials which are not
sold or otherwise disposed of in the ordinary course of business, such as the decommissioning of cables and
disposals of real estate assets.

**_Income Tax Expenses_**

Income tax expenses include current and deferred taxes.

Vivacom’s fixed-line revenue, which is comprised of fixed voice (fixed-telephony and other), fixed data (fixed
broadband and other), fixed Pay-TV (IPTV and DTH) and other fixed-line services was BGN 356.6 million
for the year ended December 31, 2020, an increase of BGN 5.2 million, or 1.5%, from BGN 351.4 million for
the year ended December 31, 2019. The increase was mainly attributable to the increase in fixed Pay-TV
revenues due to a growing share of tariffs with higher monthly recurring fees and additional packages with
rich content and sports channels, which was partially offset by strong price competition in fixed-telephony
and bundling discounts and price competition from other alternative operators in fixed data.

Vivacom’s mobile revenue was BGN 650.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, an increase of
BGN 24.2 million, or 4%, from BGN 626.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2019. The increase in
mobile revenue was mainly attributable to higher revenue from mobile data and a growing share of tariffs
with higher monthly recurring fees as a result of our smart “more for more” offerings and the quality of our
mobile network.

Vivacom’s NURTS revenue was BGN 36.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, An increase of
BGN 0.7 million, or 1% from BGN 36.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, mainly attributable to
higher revenue from services provided by the NURTS Group.

_Interconnect Expense_

Vivacom’s interconnect expense was BGN 82.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, an increase of
BGN 1.4 million, or 2%, from BGN 80.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2019. This was mainly due
to higher mobile outbound traffic to other national mobile operators.

_Materials and Consumables Expenses_

Vivacom’s materials and consumables expenses were BGN 178.8 million for the year ended December 31,
2020, an increase of BGN 11.9 million, or 7%, from BGN 166.9 million for the year ended December 31,
2019, which was mainly attributable to higher expenses for CPEs, handsets and devices.

_Other Operating Expenses_

Vivacom’s other operating expenses were BGN 168.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, a decrease
of BGN 1.7 million, or 1%, from BGN 169.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, primarily due to
lower other net expenses, professional fees, facilities expenses, license fee expenses and maintenance and repairs
expenses, partially offset by higher advertising, customer service, billing and collection and administrative
expenses, leased lines and data transmission expenses and vehicles and transports expenses. Higher
advertising, customer service and billing and collection expenses was driven by higher content costs for
television rights. Administrative expenses increased mainly as a result of non-recurring payments for


-----

settlement of legal disputes. Increases in leased lines and data transmission was primarily related to higher
costs for international internet access and peering.

_Net impairment losses on financial and contract assets_

Vivacom’s net impairment losses on financial and contract assets were BGN 7.8 million for the year ended
December 31, 2020, a decrease of BGN 1.8 million, or 18%, from BGN 9.6 million for the year ended
December 31, 2019, primarily as a result of the reversal of previously impaired receivables, partially offset by
certain delays in customer payments due to the COVID-19 pandemic reflected in higher expected credit losses.

_Staff Costs_

Vivacom’s staff costs were BGN 161.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, an increase of
BGN 22.9 million, or 16.5%, from BGN 138.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, mainly resulting
from one-off payments to management personnel and governing bodies.

_Depreciation and Amortization_

Vivacom’s depreciation and amortization costs were BGN 250.5 million for the year ended December 31,
2020, an increase of BGN 5.9 million, or 2%, from BGN 244.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2019.
Depreciation of right-of-use assets amounted to BGN 48.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2020.

_Finance Costs_

Vivacom’s finance costs were BGN 54.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, an increase of
BGN 11.8 million, or 27%, from BGN 43.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2019. This increase
related primarily due to the settlement of Vivacom’s senior facilities agreement and related hedges.

_Finance Income_

Vivacom’s finance income was BGN 20.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, an increase of
BGN 11.9 million from BGN 8.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, mainly attributable to interest
income on loans granted to related parties, which were fully settled upon completion of the Vivacom
Acquisition.

_Other Gains and Losses, Net_

Other gains and losses, net were a net loss of BGN 2.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, a
decrease of BGN 7.0 million from a net gain of BGN 4.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2019. The
decrease was attributable to changes in fair value of investment properties and lower sales of non-core assets,
mainly non-operational buildings and properties.

_Income Tax Expenses_

Income tax expense was BGN 14.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, a decrease of
BGN 1.3 million, from BGN 15.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, which was driven mainly by
a lower current income tax charge.

_Net impairment losses on financial and contract assets_

Vivacom’s net impairment losses on financial and contract assets were BGN 9.6 million for the year ended
December 31, 2019, a decrease of BGN 1.7 million, or 15%, from BGN 11.3 million for the year ended
December 31, 2018 as a result of improved collections reflected in expected credit losses.

_Materials and Consumables Expenses_

Vivacom’s materials and consumables expenses were BGN 166.9 million for the year ended December 31,
2019, a decrease of BGN 5.3 million, or 3%, from BGN 172.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2018,
which was mainly attributable to lower expenses for CPEs and subsidies for handsets.

_Other Operating Expenses_

Vivacom’s other operating expenses were BGN 169.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, a decrease
of BGN 33.7 million, or 17%, from BGN 203.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, primarily due
to transitional effects related to the implementation of IFRS 16 which was effective as of January 1, 2019.
These transitional effects have reflected facilities expenses, vehicles and transports expenses, leased lines and
data transmission expenses and advertising, customer service, billing and collection expenses. The effect on
facilities expenses was mainly due to rental of commercial properties, technical premises and offices. The
effect on vehicles and transport expenses consisted of fleet lease charges. The impact on leased lines and data
transmission was due to rented capacity for satellite transmission used for broadcasting services. The effect on
advertising, customer service, billing and collection expenses was mainly related to satellite capacity charges
for the DTH-TV platform.

_Staff Costs_

Vivacom’s staff costs were BGN 138.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, an increase of
BGN 5.9 million, or 4%, from BGN 132.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, mainly resulting
from an increase in average salaries.

_Depreciation and Amortization_

Vivacom’s depreciation and amortization costs were BGN 244.6 million for the year ended December 31,
2019, an increase of BGN 46.0 million, or 23%, from BGN 198.6 million for the year ended December 31,
2018. This increase was mainly due to transitional effects related to the implementation of IFRS 16 and
subsequent recognition of right-of-use assets. Depreciation of right-of-use assets amounted to BGN
46.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2019.

_Finance Costs_

Vivacom’s finance costs were BGN 43.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, an increase of
BGN 2.1 million, or 5%, from BGN 40.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2018. This increase related
primarily to the accounting treatment of leases following the adoption of IFRS 16, which was partially offset
by lower interest expenses under Vivacom’s €365 million senior facilities agreement.

_Finance Income_

Vivacom’s finance income was BGN 8.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, an increase of
BGN 1.4 million, or 18%, from BGN 7.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, mainly attributable to
higher interest income on granted loans and income from lease contracts.

_Other Gains, Net_

Other gains, net were BGN 4.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, a decrease of BGN 12.8 million,
or 73%, from BGN 17.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2018. The higher amount for the year ended
December 31, 2018 was due to the one-off effect of a refund for a prepayment to Bulgarian tax authorities.

_Income Tax Expenses_

Income tax expense was BGN 15.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, an increase of
BGN 7.3 million, from BGN 8.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, which was driven mainly by
a higher current income tax charge reflecting the higher net profit for the period and a lower deferred tax
charge.

**Liquidity and Capital Resources**

Vivacom’s liquidity requirements arise primarily from the need to fund capital expenditures for the expansion
and maintenance of its network operations, both in terms of quality of services and innovative technologies,
for working capital and to repay debt. Historically, Vivacom’s principal sources of liquidity have been cash
flows from operating activities, which include revenues generated by its mobile and fixed-line subscribers,
periodically as supplemented by borrowings under certain debt facilities.

Vivacom’s ability to generate cash from operations will depend on its future operating performance, which in
turn is dependent on various factors, including but not limited to those described under “—Key Factors
_Affecting Results of Operations,”many of which are beyond its control. If Vivacom’s cash flow from operating_
activities is lower than expected, or its capital expenditure requirements exceed its projections, Vivacom may
be required to seek additional financing, which may not be available on commercially reasonable terms, if at
all. On July 31, 2020, United Group Bulgaria EOOD granted a related party loan to Vivacom with a maturity
of ten years and bullet repayment at maturity. With the funds received under such related party loan, Vivacom
pre-paid all liabilities under a senior debt facility that was due in 2023. As a result, Vivacom reduced its
exposure to long-term third-party financings, which improved the ability to manage its liquidity requirements
going forward.

Vivacom believes that its operating cash flows and borrowing capacity will be sufficient to meet requirements
and commitments for the foreseeable future. Vivacom’s actual financing requirements will depend on
numerous factors, including general economic conditions, the availability of credit from banks, other financial
institutions and capital markets, Vivacom’s liquidity situation, restrictions in the instruments governing its
debt, and its general financial performance, the future projects it could undertake and the impact that the
COVID-19 pandemic could have on any of such factors. In particular, any prolonged economic crisis or


-----

recession caused by the COVID-19 pandemic could negatively impact customer spending and collections
and, in turn, have a material adverse effect on Vivacom’s liquidity position.

Vivacom maintains cash and cash equivalents to fund the day-to-day requirements of its business. Vivacom
holds cash primarily in Bulgarian levs and euros.

BGN 120.7 million to BGN 401.3 million, compared to BGN 280.6 million for the year ended December 31,
2018, mainly as a result of better operating performance and optimization in inventories. As a result of the

mainly due to a lower amount of loans granted to related parties, partially offset by higher acquisitions of
