**Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures about Market Risk**

Vivacom is exposed to various market risks, including foreign currency exchange rate and interest rate risk,
credit and liquidity risks associated with its underlying assets, liabilities, forecast transactions and firm
commitments.

Vivacom’s treasury department is responsible for managing exposure to market risks that arise in connection
with operations and financial activities, including foreign currency exchange rate, credit and liquidity risk
management. These risks are identified, measured and monitored through various control mechanisms so
that Vivacom can establish adequate prices for the services it provides, appropriately assess the market
circumstances related to its investments and maintain free liquid funds to prevent undue concentration of a
particular risk.

The following sections discuss Vivacom’s most significant exposures to market risk. The following discussions
do not address other risks that Vivacom faces in the normal course of business, including country, political,
regulatory and legal risks.

**_Foreign Exchange Rate Risk_**

Vivacom’s foreign exchange rate risk exposure mainly relates to its exposure to U.S. dollars, mainly from
committed purchases of certain network equipment, satellite capacity and content. Vivacom manages its
foreign currency exchange rate risk related to future supplies denominated in USD by hedging the exposure
through forward contracts. All forward contracts are entered into with credible counterparties.

When a significant exposure to foreign currency arises, Vivacom takes into account the following factors:

- future outlook on the volatility of financial market variables, which are modeled by Vivacom’s treasury
department and are in accordance with best practice analytical techniques and economic models;

- effect of the given foreign exchange exposure on Vivacom’s financial results; and

- the cost of foreign exposure hedging.


-----

**_Credit Risk_**

Credit risk is the risk of financial loss arising from Vivacom’s counterparties’ inability to repay or service debt
in accordance with the contractual terms. Credit risk includes both the direct risk of default and the risk of a
deterioration of creditworthiness, as well as concentration risks. Vivacom believes it has appropriate credit
policies, procedures and authorization guidelines in place to manage and monitor credit risk.

Vivacom’s credit risk is principally associated with trade and other receivables. Vivacom seeks to minimize
credit risk through the application of monthly subscription contracts, initial credit checks, credit limits and
credit monitoring procedures. Vivacom also seeks to minimize credit risk by obtaining cash deposits from its
retail customers and distributors where it perceives credit risk to exist.

Vivacom believes that its implementation of the foregoing procedures has led to experiencing a limited amount
of credit losses. Expenses for receivables written off are recognized in other operating expenses in the profit or
loss for a given period. For 2018, 2019 and 2020, BGN 174 thousand, BGN 195 thousand and
BGN 102 thousand, respectively, of receivables were written off. In addition, Vivacom’s allowance for
impairment of receivables in the statement of financial position as of December 31, 2018, December 31, 2019
and December 31, 2020 amounted to BGN 105,512 thousand, BGN 97,547 thousand and
BGN 40,864 thousand, respectively for all trade and other receivables not written off, including CCB.
Furthermore, as a general rule, Vivacom’s has no significant level of credit concentration related to accounts
receivable.

Credit risk relating to cash and cash equivalents, derivative financial instruments, financial deposits and money
market funds arises from the risk that the counterparty becomes insolvent and accordingly is unable to return
the deposited funds or execute the obligations under the derivative transactions as a result of the insolvency.
To mitigate this risk, wherever possible Vivacom conducts transactions and deposit funds with investment
grade rated financial institutions and monitor and limit the concentration of its transactions with any single
party.

Additionally, due to the impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic, net impairment losses on financial and contract
assets increased as a result of delays in customer payments during the second quarter of 2020, resulting
respectively in higher expected credit losses rates and an increase in the allowance for impairment of trade and
lease receivables measured by applying the IFRS 9 simplified approach. However, on a full-year basis, in the
year ended December 31, 2020 both net impairment losses on financial and contract assets and the allowance
for impairment of trade and lease receivables decreased compared to 2019. We believe that during the first
quarter of 2021, Vivacom’s ability to collect receivables improved and as of March 31, 2021, it has returned to
close to pre-COVID-19 levels.

**_Liquidity Risk_**

Liquidity risk is the risk that Vivacom may have difficulty in obtaining funds in order to meet both its
day-to-day operating requirements and debt servicing obligations (interest and debt repayments). This arises
mostly in connection with the contractual maturity of Vivacom’s monetary assets and liabilities that result
from business activities and from the possibility that its trade debtors may not be able to settle their payment
obligations within the normal terms of trade.

Vivacom monitors its liquidity requirements and aims to mitigate liquidity risk through monitoring cash
flows, ensuring the availability of overdraft facilities and preparing daily liquidity reports. Short and medium
term cash flow forecasting is performed by its treasury department. These forecasts are monitored to ensure
Vivacom’s cash and liquidity requirements are sufficient to meet operational needs and to monitor compliance
with borrowing limits and debt covenants on its borrowing facilities.

Any prolonged economic crisis or recession due to the COVID-19 pandemic could have a significant impact
on Vivacom’s growth prospects. However, Vivacom continues to generate profits and sufficient cash from
operations, supporting its activities and contractual commitments.

**Critical Accounting Estimates and Judgments**

**_COVID-19 (Coronavirus) pandemic_**

The rapid development of COVID-19 and its social and economic impact in Bulgaria and globally, may result
in assumptions and estimates requiring revisions which may lead to material adjustments to the carrying value
of assets and liabilities within the next financial year. Following a resurgence of COVID-19 infections in late


-----

2020, the government-imposed lockdown measures in November 2020. Infections decreased and certain
measures were lifted but most remained in force until the end of January 2021. Vivacom’s operations were not
restricted by the lockdown, and the impact on its financial position and performance remained in line with
the disclosure in the Vivacom Audited Financial Statements as of and for the year ended December 31, 2020.
Any prolonged economic crisis or recession due to the COVID-19 pandemic could impact Vivacom’s growth
prospects, customer spending and collection, and may result in assumptions and estimates that could trigger
material adjustments to the carrying value of assets and liabilities in the future. In particular, management
expects the assumptions and estimates used in determining impairment of Trade and other receivables,
Contract assets, Property, plant and equipment, Intangible assets, Right-of-use assets and valuation of
Investment property, and the related Deferred tax assets and liabilities to be affected. Management is not able
to reliably estimate these impact as events are unfolding day by day. The COVID-19 pandemic had a negative
impact on Mobile services revenue due to lower roaming revenue, primarily as a result of the COVID-19
related travel restrictions. This was partially offset by a decrease in interconnection and roaming expenses.
Further impacts on service revenues are limited by the increased demand for telecom services during the
periods in which the COVID-19 related restrictions were implemented. The longer term impact of the
COVID-19 pandemic may also affect trading volumes, cash flows and profitability.

The COVID-19 pandemic did not have an impact on the other critical accounting estimates and judgements
disclosed in the Vivacom Audited Financial Statements for the years ended December 31, 2020.

The discussion and analysis of Vivacom’s results of operations and financial condition are based on the
Vivacom Audited Financial Statements for the years ended December 31, 2019 and 2020 disclosed in Note 4
thereof, which have been prepared in accordance with IFRS. The preparation of these financial statements
requires management to apply accounting methods and policies that are based on difficult or subjective
judgments, estimates based on past experience and assumptions determined to be reasonable and realistic
based on the related circumstances. The application of these estimates and assumptions affects the reported
amounts of assets and liabilities and the disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities at the balance sheet date
and the reported amounts of income and expenses during the reporting period. The resulting accounting
estimates could differ from the related actual results. All assumptions, expectations and forecasts used as a
basis for certain estimates within the Vivacom Audited Financial Statements represent good faith assessments
of Vivacom’s future performance for which management believes there is a reasonable basis. Estimates and
judgments are continually evaluated and are based on historical experience and other factors, including
expectations of future events that are believed to be reasonable under the circumstances.

Detailed information regarding significant accounting policies is provided in Note 2 to the Vivacom Audited
Financial Statements for the years ended December 31, 2019 and 2020 included elsewhere in this offering
memorandum.

**_Impairment of Goodwill, Tangible and Intangible Assets_**

In recent years, Vivacom has been conducting annual impairment testing of its assets, and no need for
impairment has been identified. Taking into account the fact that Vivacom has during this period performed
in line with its projections, and based on the assessment that no internal or external indicators exist that affect
the recoverable amount of assets or trigger the need for annual impairment testing of assets, Vivacom
considers that the carrying amount of assets as of December 31, 2019 did not exceed their recoverable amount.
Taking into account the outbreak of the COVID-19 pandemic in 2020, Vivacom has performed new
impairment testing of its assets as of December 31, 2020 and no need for impairment was identified. Based on
the analysis performed, there would be no need for impairment even in the event estimated cash flows were
10% lower.

**_Useful Lives of Assets_**

The determination of the useful lives of assets is based on historical experience with similar assets as well as
any anticipated technological development and changes in broad economic or industry factors. The
appropriateness of the estimated useful lives of assets is reviewed annually, or whenever there is an indication
of significant changes in the underlying assumptions. Vivacom believes that the accounting estimate related
to the determination of the useful lives of assets is a critical accounting estimate as it involves assumptions
about technological development in an innovative industry. Further, due to the significance of depreciable
assets as a percentage of Vivacom’s total assets, the impact of any changes in these assumptions could be
material to its financial position and results of operations.


-----

Were the actual useful lives of the assets to differ by 10% from management’s estimates as of December 31,
2020, the carrying value of the plant and equipment and respectively depreciation and amortization charges
would be an estimated BGN 17.2 million higher or lower.

**_Provisions, Decommissioning Costs and Contingent Liabilities_**

As set out in Note 28 of the Vivacom Audited Financial Statements for the year ended December 31, 2019
and and Note 29 of the Vivacom Audited Financial Statements for the year ended December 31, 2020,
Vivacom is a participant in several lawsuits and administrative proceedings. For more information, see “Our
_Business—Legal Proceedings.”Vivacom’s treatment of obligations with uncertain timing and amount depends_
on management’s estimation of the amount and timing of the obligation and probability of an outflow of
resources embodying economic benefits that will be required to settle the obligation (both legal and
constructive).

A provision is recognized when Vivacom has a present obligation as a result of past events, it is probable that
an outflow of resources will be required to settle the obligation and a reliable estimate can be made of the
amount of the obligation. Contingent liabilities are not recognized because their existence will be confirmed
only by the occurrence or non-occurrence of one or more uncertain future events not wholly within Vivacom’s
control. Contingent liabilities are assessed continually to determine whether an outflow of resource embodying
economic benefits has become probable. If it becomes probable that an outflow of future economic benefits
will be required for an item previously dealt with as a contingent liability, a provision is recognized in the
financial statements of the period in which the change in probability occurs.

**_Going Concern_**

The financial statements have been prepared on a going concern basis, which assumes that Vivacom will
continue in operational existence for the foreseeable future. In the year ended December 31, 2020, Vivacom
realized a profit of BGN 123,265 thousand, compared to BGN 137,748 thousand in the year ended
December 31, 2019 Vivacom’s future viability depends upon the business environment as well as upon the
continuing support of its existing and potential owners and providers of finance. Vivacom’s directors, in light
of their assessment of expected future cash flows, are satisfied that it is appropriate for the financial statements
to be prepared on a going concern basis.

**_Revenue Recognition, Contract Assets and Liabilities_**

Multiple element arrangements involving the delivery or provision of multiple products or services are assessed
to determine whether it is necessary to separate the different identifiable components and apply the
corresponding revenue recognition policy to each element. The transaction price for the entire multiple
element arrangement is allocated among the identified elements based on their respective standalone selling
prices. Determining standalone selling prices for each identified element requires estimates that are complex
due to the nature of the business. A change in estimates of standalone selling prices could affect the allocation
of revenue among the elements and, as a result, the timing of recognition of revenues and the carrying amount
of contract assets and liabilities.

**_Allowance for Impairment of Trade and Other Receivables, Leases and Contract Assets_**

An allowance for impairment of trade and other receivables is established for estimated losses resulting from
the inability of customers to make their payments due. When evaluating the adequacy of an allowance for
doubtful accounts, management bases its estimates on the aging of accounts receivable balances and historical
write-off experience, customer creditworthiness and estimated probability of default. If the financial condition
of customers were to deteriorate, actual write-offs might be higher than expected.

**_Income Tax Provision_**

Vivacom is subject to income taxes in the Bulgarian tax jurisdiction. Significant judgment is required in
determining the provision for income taxes. Vivacom recognizes liabilities for anticipated tax due based on
management estimates. Where the final tax outcome of these matters is different from the amounts that were
initially recorded, such differences will impact the income tax and deferred tax provisions in the period in
which such determination is made.

**_Assignment of receivables on cash deposits_**

The transactions for assignment of receivables on cash deposits in Corporate Commercial Bank AD—in
bankruptcy (CCB), were executed in 2014 as per the provisions of the applicable law.


-----

In August 2015, two of the transactions concluded in 2014 for the assignment of cash deposits in CCB were
terminated and as a result the assignments were cancelled with retroactive effect where Vivacom became a
titleholder of the assigned receivables in the amount of BGN 53,033 thousand (BGN 9,970 thousand, net of
impairment as of 31 December 2019). Despite of the validly executed transactions, the receivers of CCB have
not included the cancelled assignments in the list of accepted receivables of CCB creditors.

In 2020, remaining receivables representing cash and cash equivalents at CCB were assigned to InterV
Investment S.à r.l. for cash consideration equal to their net book value.

**_Fair value measurement_**

Fair value is the price that is assumed would be received in the sale of an asset or paid to transfer a liability in
a common transaction between independent market participants at the measurement date. Fair value assumes
that such a transaction will take place in the principal market where such assets and liabilities are traded or, in
the absence of such principal market or, in case of lack of access to such market by Vivacom, in the market
where such a transaction would be most advantageous. For the purposes of financial reporting, certain of
Vivacom’s assets and liabilities are valued and presented at fair value. Such assets and liabilities presented at
fair value are (a) on a recurring (annual) basis: financial assets through other comprehensive income, financial
assets through profit or loss, investment property, loans granted or borrowings received to/from third or
related parties, certain trade and other receivables and payables, finance lease receivables and payables, and
(b) on a non-recurring (period basis): non-financial assets such as property, plant and equipment.

**_Determining the lease term and the incremental borrowing rate_**

In determining the lease term, management considers all facts and circumstances that create an economic
incentive to exercise an extension option, or not exercise a termination option. Extension options (or periods
after termination options) are only included in the lease term if the lease is reasonably certain to be extended
(or not terminated).

If there are significant penalties to terminate (or not extend), or any leasehold improvements are expected to
have a significant remaining value, Vivacom is typically reasonably certain to extend (or not terminate). Other
factors including historical lease durations and the costs and business disruption required to replace the leased
asset are also considered. For lease contracts with indefinite term or short-term technical site rentals the
Vivacom estimates the length of the contract to be equal to the economic useful life of non-current assets
located in the leased property.

To determine the incremental borrowing rate, the Vivacom uses a buildup approach that starts with a risk free
interest rate adjusted for credit risk for the country and the company and makes adjustments specific to the
lease, e.g. term, currency and security.

**United Group geographies**

**_Macro-Economic Overview_**

We operate most of our business across the following eight countries in South Eastern Europe: Bulgaria,
Greece, Serbia, Slovenia, Croatia, Bosnia and Herzegovina (“B&H”), Montenegro and North Macedonia.
These countries have a combined population of approximately 37 million people, distributed across
approximately 15 million households. Despite economic differences, these countries share a joint history and
form a single market in which small local differences are overshadowed by the influence of similarities in
cultural preferences and language across the region. As a result, this region is one of the three largest markets
in CEE, along with Poland and Romania. The following table provides an overview of our countries of
operations:

Over the past fifteen years, our eight countries of operations have implemented significant political and
economic reforms aimed at, among other things, reducing economic and structural imbalances, increasing the
flexibility of their respective economies (including liberalization of the media and telecommunications
sectors), and creating a business friendly environment that is conducive to foreign investment. As a result of
such reforms, Slovenia and Croatia were admitted to the European Union in 2004 and 2013, respectively.
Bulgaria joined the European Union in 2007 and Greece in 1981 (and adopted the euro in 2001). Serbia
officially applied for European Union membership in 2009, received full candidate status in 2012 and in
January 2014, the first accession negotiations took place. Negotiations are ongoing with several Chapters
having been opened up for discussion and review. Montenegro was granted candidate status in 2010 and the
accession negotiations started in June 2012. North Macedonia has been a candidate for accession to the
European Union since 2005, and in 2009 the European Commission recommended that accession negotiations
be opened. Bosnia and Herzegovina formally applied for EU membership in February 2016 and in
December 2016 and has received the accession questionnaire from the European Commission.

The macroeconomic environment is improving in our four core countries (Bulgaria, Greece, Serbia and
Slovenia). Real GDP growth in our four core countries is and will continue to be the key driver of private
consumption and disposable income growth.

Bulgaria’s economy has experienced a slightly negative growth for the period from 2018 to 2020, with real
GDP decreasing by 0.2% from 2018 to 2020. However, real GDP per capita from 2018 to 2020 increased by
0.5%. Furthermore, in 2020, unemployment rate increased by 0.9 percentage points, driven by COVID-19.
From 2018 to 2020, the unemployment decreased by 0.6 percentage points.

In Greece, positive growth in disposable personal income is expected to continue, supported by expanding
employment, wage growth and a stable inflow of worker remittances. Unemployment rate dropped by
0.8 percentage points in 2020. From 2018 to 2020, the unemployment decreased by 2.9 percentage points.


-----

In Serbia, the growth in real GDP per capita is expected to continue, driven by monetary policy relaxation,
structural reforms and supported by expanding employment. Unemployment rate dropped by 1.5 percentage
points in 2020. From 2018 to 2020, the unemployment decreased by 3.8 percentage points.

Growth is further driven by solid expansion in household spending as well as a trade surplus. Capacity
utilization levels in industry and services have reached their highest level since 2007 and conditions for
investment (e.g. high profits and low interest rates) remain favorable, which could potentially drive capital
spending growth. Higher than expected employment and rising disposable income has led to healthy private
consumption growth. Strong fiscal performance could support gradual reduction of public debt as a share of
GDP. Eurozone membership allows the country to benefit from the credibility of the European Central Bank’s
monetary policy and access to the Economic and Monetary Union’s highly developed capital markets.

In Slovenia, the economy has been significantly hit by the COVID-19 pandemic, with real GDP and real GDP
per capita decreasing by 6.1 percentage points. However, the country has experienced an increase in disposable
personal income (+5.7% YoY in 2020). Unemployment rate increased by 0.5 percentage points in 2020, while
from 2018 to 2020, the unemployment decreased by 0.1 percentage points.

freely fluctuates against the Euro. The Serbian dinar depreciated against the Euro. Historically, Serbian
consumer price index (“CPI”) inflation has tended to more than offset depreciation of the Serbian dinar
against the Euro, leading to a constant “pass through” of the impact of the depreciation of the dinar to the
consumer.

We believe that our pricing strategy reflects the “pass through” principle outlined above. With respect to the
Croatian kuna, the long-time policy of the Croatian National Bank has been to keep the exchange rate
fluctuation of the kuna against the Euro within a relatively stable range.

Between 2018 and 2020, overall Pay-TV market penetration increased from 73% to 87% in Serbia, 76% to 77%
in Slovenia and stable at 68% in Bulgaria. This translated into substantial growth in subscribers at CAGRs of
10.1% (from 1,781 thousand to 2,160 thousand), 1.0% (from 637 thousand to 650 thousand) and (0.5%) (from
2,014 thousand to 1,993 thousand) during the corresponding period in Serbia, Slovenia and Bulgaria,
respectively.

The growth occurred primarily due to availability of increasingly attractive content, improving output quality
(mainly as a result of increasing digitalization rates), increased product functionality (e.g. video on demand
and CatchUp TV) and higher disposable income per household across the region.

The positive growth in the number of Pay-TV subscribers is expected to continue in Serbia and initiate in
Bulgaria, with estimated penetration rates in 2024 of 90% and 72%, respectively. The positive growth in Serbia
and Slovenia is expected to be driven by increasing demand for digital TV and other value add services that
can be delivered through digital TV platforms, such as VoD and CatchUp TV.

In our three core markets, Pay-TV content is predominantly distributed through cable, IPTV and Satellite
networks:

  - Cable

Cable Pay-TV is characterized by easy to use technology, quick installation of customer equipment and
reliability of signal delivered directly to the home. Population density is a key factor for cable operators when
deciding whether to invest in extending their existing cable network. A higher population density reduces the
overall cost associated with the deployment, operation and maintenance of cable infrastructure and allows for
mass marketing. Cable operators that operate in urban areas with high population density benefit from easier
access to customers and more cost effective network upgrades and maintenance expenditures. As a result,
cable networks in South Eastern Europe are mainly concentrated across metropolitan regions in Bulgaria,
Serbia and Slovenia. As of December 2020, approximately 26% of households in Bulgaria, approximately
56% in Serbia and approximately 39% in Slovenia received their Pay-TV content via cable. The popularity of
cable Pay-TV in Serbia is a result of the attractive content available on cable television, the high service quality
and the capability to deliver interactive services such as VoD and CatchUp TV.

  - IPTV

As a consequence of improvements in broadband internet technology, IPTV is increasingly being used for the
distribution of television services and has traditionally been the second most commonly used distribution
medium for television services across South Eastern Europe. In Slovenia, IPTV has recently become the most
used distribution medium (56% of all households as of December 2020), supported by EU investment in
shared open fiber networks, which are accessible to all operators for a fee. However, as these shared open fiber
networks have been built with the objective of making high quality services available in rural parts of Slovenia,
these networks have traditionally had a limited impact on our cable footprint, which typically covers urban
and high population density areas. The principal providers of IPTV are Telekom Slovenije and T2 in Slovenia,
Telekom Srbija (who regularly offers IPTV at a significant discount to attract subscribers) in Serbia and
Bulsatcom in Bulgaria.


-----

  - DTH-TV

DTH has traditionally been the third most commonly used distribution network medium for television services
in South Eastern Europe region after cable and IPTV. Pay-TV content owners can penetrate rural areas more
cost efficiently through DTH than through fixed line cable networks which are economically unviable to
develop because of low population density in rural areas. Satellite operators, such as our own Total TV and
competitors, such as Digi and Max TV, distribute digital signals via satellite directly to television viewers. To
receive DTH, viewers need a satellite dish and a set top box. Depending on the service provider, viewers may
also require a smart card for the subscription based and premium television services distributed via satellite.

As of December 2020, approximately 46% of households in Bulgaria that had subscribed to Pay-TV services
received their content via DTH, compared to approximately 16% in Serbia and approximately 5% in Slovenia.
We believe that the majority of DTH Pay-TV subscribers live in rural areas without access to a cable network,
which limits the overlap between our cable Pay-TV and DTH Pay-TV offerings.

  - OTT

Another emerging technology is the delivery of television content “over-the-top” of an existing broadband
internet network, which allows Pay-TV distributors to reach customers through the internet. We operate two
of our own OTT content platforms: our regional OTT platform (which operates under the EON brand of
products and services) and our international OTT platform, NetTV Plus. Our regional OTT platform offers
customers of our broadband internet competitors within the region access to our full digital Pay-TV channel
offering. As a result, EON subscribers can watch all of our digital Pay-TV channels on their TV screens,
computers, tablets, mobiles or other internet enabled devices. Through NetTV Plus, we deliver extensive local
and regional content, to the entire former Yugoslav expatriate community worldwide. Like EON, our
subscribers can watch Net TV Plus directly on their TV screens, computers, tablets, mobiles or other internet
enabled devices. We are a leading provider of Pay-TV services across our three core markets.

We mainly compete with local incumbents in our three core markets (Telekom Slovenije in Slovenia, Telekom
Srbija in Serbia and Bulsatcom in Bulgaria), as well as with other local players (T2 in Slovenia, Telekom
Srpske, HT Eronet and A1 Bulgaria in Bulgaria, among others). We have managed to maintain our leadership
and grow our market shares across our three core markets due to high quality content offering, excellent
customer care, positive brand perception and better value and product propositions.

Fixed broadband internet household penetration rates in Bulgaria grew from approximately 65% in 2018 to

We believe that the positive growth in the broadband internet market in our three core markets also stems
from the overall increasing importance of the internet as the primary communication medium of choice as
well as from a decrease in end user equipment costs, leading to increasing usage of personal computers and
smartphones. By 2024, broadband internet penetration rates are expected to reach 82%, or 2,351 thousand, of
households in Bulgaria, 73%, or 1,765 thousand, of households in Serbia and 84%, or 722 thousand, of
households in Slovenia. As data consumption demand grows in households, the penetration rate of high
speed broadband (lines capable of providing at least 30 Mbps) is expected to increase rapidly in Slovenia and
Serbia in the coming years. The Serbian “Strategy for the Development of Broadband and Networks and
Service,” adopted in 2014, established a target of 100% coverage with 30 Mbps by 2020 and 50% coverage for
100 Mpbs in an effort to align with EU targets.

  - DSL

DSL uses basic telephone infrastructure to access the internet. DSL technology leverages the fact that copper
wires used in telephone networks have a much higher bandwidth (7 MHz) than that required for normal voice
conversation (0 3.4 KHz). DSL utilizes the extra bandwidth to provide broadband internet connections. The
most commonly used variant of DSL is ADSL which assumes that internet users normally receive or
download significant more information than they would send or upload. Hence, ADSL connections normally
have three to four times more bandwidth for downloading. However, as copper is a distance sensitive medium,
access speeds for DSL technology decrease substantially as the distance from DSL hubs increases. The
maximum download speed of DSL networks has to be shared between all services: television, broadband
internet and telephony. Under currently available technology, DSL based multi-play providers can therefore
not provide broadband internet and television services of comparable quality to those provided over cable
networks. Another variant of DSL is VDSL, a DSL technology that provides a faster data transfer rate than
ADSL technologies. It is an access technology that exploits the existing infrastructure of copper wires that
were originally deployed for traditional telephone service as a way of delivering very high speed internet
access.


-----

Historically, DSL has been distribution platform and accounted for approximately 6% of all internet
connections in Bulgaria, 37% in Serbia and 28% in Slovenia at the end of 2020. However, its market share has
been consistently eroded by upgraded cable networks which offer higher quality service and higher speed as
well as by the steady development of fiber based networks.

  - Cable

Cable networks have been designed for the transmission of large amounts of analogue TV and radio signals
and are able to deliver consistent speeds irrespective of the distance to the customer, unlike DSL. United
Group companies are leading cable providers in the region with fully bi directional network, largely
EuroDOCSIS 3.0 enabled and offering up to 220 Mbps download speeds, with the upgrade path up to 1.2
Gbps. Furthermore, the deployment of EuroDOCSIS 3.1 technology will allow cable operators to provide
data download speeds as high as 10 Gbps and data upload speeds as high as 2 Gbps over existing hybrid
fiber/coax (“HFC”) lines (with full duplex EuroDOCSIS 3.1, upstream capacity will also be as high as 10
Gbps). EuroDOCSIS 3.1 when deployed enables us to compete head on with fiber networks. In addition to
faster download and upload speeds, EuroDOCSIS 3.1 also offers other tangible benefits, such as higher
bandwidth capacity, better operational efficiencies, higher quality control, real time performance analysis and
lower costs. All these other tangible benefits should be available without necessarily upgrading existing HFC
networks or adding more fiber lines. EuroDOCSIS 3.1 is also backward compatible with Euro DOCSIS 3.0,
which allows us to roll out the new specifications seamlessly, on an incremental basis.

In 2020, cable distribution accounted for 14%, 50% and 30% of all broadband infrastructure in Bulgaria,
Serbia and Slovenia, respectively.

  - FttH

FttH is based on optical fiber cables and is the only infrastructure that offers similar speeds. Currently, FttH
broadband internet connections play a very limited role in Serbia. FttH had a broadband market share in
Slovenia of approximately 41% as of December 31, 2020, compared to approximately 35% in 2018. The main
providers of FttH in Slovenia are Telekom Slovenije and T2. The increase in the FttH broadband market
share is primarily due to extensive fiber roll out by Telekom Slovenije and T2 in 2009, as well as EU investment
in municipally owned open fiber networks. As fiber roll out is more expensive than cable and the open fiber
networks have traditionally been built with the objective of making high speed broadband internet and IPTV
services accessible in rural areas, we believe that any competitive impact on cable operators will be limited, as
these operators traditionally provide services in more urban and high density areas (i.e. no overlap).

FttH is the technology of choice by United Group for greenfield expansion and new buildings in adjacent
areas.

  - Other Broadband Internet

We also compete with service providers that use other alternative technologies for broadband internet access,
such as satellite technologies or mobile standards such as WiMax, universal mobile telecommunications
system (“UMTS”) and high speed packet access (“HSPA”). These mobile broadband internet access
technologies may allow both incumbent and new broadband internet access providers the ability to provide
high speed connection services for voice, data, video and television. We estimate that only a small portion of
households were using UMTS/HSPA for primary broadband internet access via laptops or PCs in 2014. We
believe that the majority of mobile broadband internet users presently use mobile internet services to
complement, rather than to replace, fixed line broadband internet.


-----

_Technology_

We provide fixed line telephony services in Bulgaria, Serbia and Slovenia, using VoIP telephony technology.
VoIP technologies place and transmit telephone calls over the internet instead of using the traditional PSTN.
Following the liberalization of fixed line telephony markets in Serbia, all telephony markets in our three core
markets are now fully liberalized, providing us with significant growth opportunities. Slovenia is one of the
few European telephony markets in which VoIP technology accounts for the majority of the fixed line
telephony connections. We believe that this increase in VoIP market share was primarily driven by lower prices
of VoIP connections compared to PSTN connections which are often offered as part of a competitively priced
cable or FttH internet and television bundle.

which allows customers to make traditional fixed line telephone calls using a standard telephone handset and
provides comparable quality to PSTN at lower prices, the respective Bulgarian, Serbian and Slovenian
incumbents have generally lost market share to us:

Residential Segment (Mobile)

_Slovenian Mobile Market_

_Overview_

Following our acquisition of Tušmobil in April 2015, we provide mobile telephony services in Slovenia as an
MNO. There were approximately 2.5 million mobile subscribers in Slovenia as of December 31, 2018, which
resulted in a penetration rate of 119%, below the average mobile penetration rate in Europe. The number of
mobile subscribers in Slovenia grew at a CAGR of approximately 1.5% between 2014 and 2018. We believe
mobile penetration in Slovenia is still below the penetration benchmarks provided by certain developed mobile
markets in Western Europe, such as Germany and Sweden, supporting continued subscriber growth potential
in the market. The Slovenian mobile market is a predominantly contract (post-paid) market.

**_Mobile Penetration Rates (% of Total Population), 2020_**


139%

Source: Ampere


147%
136%


There has been a continuous decline in Slovenian mobile termination rates (“MTR”) since 2008. MTR
asymmetry in the Slovenian market was eliminated as of January 1, 2013, when MTR for all operators became
€0.0324 per minute. In July 2014, the Slovenian regulator, AKOS, announced a significant reduction in MTRs
to €0.0114 per minute and implemented this rate for all Slovenian operators with effect from September 1,
2014. Following this reduction, Slovenian MTR was brought closer in line with the target EU benchmark of
€0.01 per minute, indicating limited further downside.

_Licenses_

  - Spectrum Licenses

The first ever spectrum auction in Slovenia was completed in April 2014 with the award of several frequency
bands to three mobile operators: Telekom Slovenije, Si.mobil (now A1) and Tušmobil (Telemach Slovenia).
Three of the four MNOs (T 2 did not participate) acquired the following bands: A1 acquired total of 90 MHz
on paired 800, 900, 1800 and 2600 MHz and a total of 45 MHz on unpaired 2100 and 2600 MHz; Telekom
Slovenije acquired a total of 85 MHz on paired 800, 900, 1800 MHz and a total of 25 MHz on unpaired 2600
MHz band, Telemach Slovenia acquired a paired spectrum of 5 MHz on 900, 10 MHz on 1800 as well as 10


-----

MHz in the 800 MHz band which is widely recognized as the most efficient band for 4G LTE roll out. The
licenses were awarded for a long term tenure of 15 years which we believe represents a significant barrier to
entry for a potential fifth MNO.

In July 2016, AKOS announced its decision to conduct an auction for various mobile spectrum bands in
Slovenia that remained unallocated. These included frequencies in the 1800 MHz band and the 2100 MHz
band. AKOS set the reserve price at €2.6 million for each block of 2x5 MHz in the 1800 MHz frequency band,
two blocks of which were available for auction, and €1.3 million for the block of 2x5MHz in the 2100 MHz
band, one block of which was available for auction. On August 5, 2016, we submitted our tender for these
frequencies. On August 29, 2016, AKOS issued a decision in our favor on the allocation of two blocks of 2x5
MHz in the 1800 MHz frequency band and one block of 2x5 MHz in the 2100 MHz frequency band for an
aggregate amount of €6.6 million. Telemach Slovenia’s license for the frequencies in the 1800 MHz band is
valid through January 2031, and for the frequencies in the 2100 MHz band is valid through September 2021.
Telemach Slovenia currently possesses 60% less spectrum compared to its main two competitors. In April
2021, we secured 15-year spectrum licenses in Slovenia for 5G frequencies, and commenced deployment and
commercial launch of 5G 3600 MHz in Slovenia in June 2021. We believe additional frequencies will be
needed to be able to address our growing mobile business, especially in the domain of mobile broadband.

On September 2020, we announced the commercial launch of our 5G network in Bulgaria and, to that end, in
May 2021, we secured a 20-year license for 100 MHz spectrum frequencies in the 3.6 GHz band.

_Competition_

Telekom Slovenije is the largest mobile operator in the market, with a market share of 40% as of December 31,
2020. Telemach Slovenia had a market share of 24% as of December 31, 2020. The mobile markets in Bulgaria
and Serbia are led by incumbents as well as mobile players that are part of international groups. Historically,
international groups have invested in mobile operations only in Serbia, and we believe the limited focus of
international groups in the rest of our core region is set to continue, potentially offering interesting acquisition
opportunities for us.

Bundles

Customers in our three core markets increasingly seek to receive their multimedia and communications
services in a bundled offer from one provider. In response, service providers are providing television,
broadband internet and fixed line and mobile telephony services in bundled offerings; such bundled offerings
are marketed as the best value for money. We believe that bundled offerings allow media and


-----

telecommunication service providers to better meet customers’ communication and entertainment demands,
increase average revenue per customer while also increasing customer loyalty and attract new customers via
an enhanced value proposition.

As of December 31, 2018, approximately 81% of unique fixed line customers are bundled customers in
Telemach Slovenia. Fixed and mobile convergence was approximately 43% as of December 31, 2018 with 1.9
SIMs per customer on average. As of December 31, 2018, SBB Serbia and Telemach BH had bundle
penetration of 80% and 74% respectively. While such convergence has occurred at a relatively fast pace in a
number of Western and Eastern European markets, notably in Slovenia, a series of regulations, including
those limiting alternative operators other than the incumbent service providers from providing telephony
services in Serbia and Bosnia and Herzegovina, have historically prevented such convergence to occur in our
three core markets. However, the relatively recent liberalization of the Serbian and Bosnian fixed line telephony
markets is accelerating the convergence in our three core markets. The ability to bundle products and services
plays an important role in our three core markets, and we believe cable operators will be well positioned to
benefit from this.

**_B2B Segment_**

Almost all businesses in our three core markets (Bulgaria, Serbia and Slovenia) have internet/broadband
connections. Large companies and small and medium enterprises can receive the following services from
telecommunications companies: infrastructure and transport (dark fiber, wavelengths and synchronous digital
hierarchy), co-location, enterprise connectivity (including internet access, Ethernet and multiprotocol label
switching, virtual private network/wide area network, security and managed services), hosting & cloud storage
(including infrastructure as a service and platform as a service) and voice.

According to Solon, business fixed data spending (which includes internet access (comprising connection
charges and monthly fees, excluding equipment costs), Ethernet (installation and monthly services charges),
internet protocol virtual private networks (costs of underlying broadband and dedicated connections,
excluding dial line rental and usage charges), very high bandwidth services (upfront connection and monthly
service charges on optical and dark fiber services) and legacy data services (digital leased line, Frame Relay
and asynchronous transfer mode connections)). We expect the business fixed data spending to remain
relatively stable. In more developed markets, additional spending for co-location, hosting & cloud storage is
typically around three times the amount of fixed data spending.

**Media Overview**

Despite economic differences, the countries of South Eastern Europe have a joint history and form a single
media market in which local differences are compensated by the influence of similarities in cultural preferences
and language across the region. Television is by far the main source of news and information in our three core
markets. Through United Media, we play a significant role in this attractive market and even offer our own
content, including some of the region’s most popular sports, news, children and general entertainment
channels. We believe that the Nova TV Croatia Acquisition, which includes Nova TV (the most viewed channel
in Croatia) enhances our media offering and strengthens our leadership position in Croatia. In
September 2018, we completed the Direct Media/Pink Acquisition, a leading media buying agency in Serbia.
The Direct Media/Pink Acquisition included its operations in Montenegro, North Macedonia and Albania
as well as its terrestrial TV stations Pink BiH and Pink Montenegro. On October 22, 2018, we rebranded these
channels as Nova BH and Nova M to facilitate synergies with Nova TV in Croatia. In 2019, we also launched
Nova S in Serbia, which although a Pay-TV channel, is structured as a full format national TV station with
attractive talk shows, sports and own production local fiction series in the market. In January 2021, we
acquired Nova BG, the largest Bulgarian multi-platform media company. The acquisition perfectly
complements UG’s Vivacom operations, as the leading media group in the country.

**_Broadcasting_**

_Overview and Technology_

Television in Slovenia was first introduced in 1958, with the launch of JRT RTV Ljubljana (now RTV
Slovenija) as the first TV station. Following the independence from Yugoslavia in 1991, the Mass Media Act
which was passed in 1994, laid out the specific model for the privatization of media in Slovenia. The Mass
Media Act was revised in 2001 and 2006 to define clear rules for ensuring media pluralism. Today, TV market
in Slovenia is operated by both state owned and for profit corporations and is mainly shared between public


-----

service RTV Slovenia and private stations Kanal A and Pop TV. Kanal A was the first commercial TV station
which launched in 1991, followed by Pop TV which launched in 1995.

Television in Serbia was first introduced in 1958 with state owned Television Belgrade, now known as Radio
Television of Serbia (“RTS”). The Serbian broadcasting system evolved from a public monopoly into a dual
system of public and private stations. The switch over from analogue to digital terrestrial television in the
country was completed in 2015.

Television in Bosnia and Herzegovina was first introduced in 1956 and since then, it has now developed into
a market with both private and public channels. Three public TV stations (BHT1, FTV and RTRS) are
operating within the Public Service Broadcasting system and are financed from radio and television fees.
Together with private stations, as well as regional public stations, they form the national TV market. The
Pay-TV market is significantly fragmented with the majority of private TV stations being locally focused.
However, there are a number of players that aim to capture a wider audience throughout the country (for
example, N1 of Telemach BH). The process of TV digitalization is still ongoing in Bosnia and Herzegovina.

Television in Croatia was first introduced in 1956 with Television Zagreb. Today there are four channels with
nationwide coverage. Digital video broadcasting terrestrial signal broadcasting was introduced in 2002, with
the full digital switchover being completed by 2010 via gradual ceasing of analogue TV throughout the
country.

**_Advertising_**

Across our three core markets, television is the medium of choice for advertising, accounting for approximately
50% of total advertising spent. The internet, as a medium of choice for advertising, is expected to grow at
higher rates than television, but will still remain below television in coming years. The average daily viewing
time across the three core markets ranges from approximately 3.5 to 5.5 hours demonstrating the importance
of TV as medium for information and entertainment. Most importantly, the demand for TV is relatively
inelastic. TV continues to offer a unique proposition to advertisers: enormous scale, fast reach, very high
quality advertisement inventory and an attractive contextual environment for brand building. As a result, TV
advertising should continue to be resilient, with any gradual volume reductions more than offset by price
inflation.

Television broadcasting in each of our markets is regulated by a governmental authority or agency. For
example, privately owned broadcasters in Slovenia are allowed to broadcast advertising for up to 12 minutes
in any hour, whereas the public broadcaster, Radiotelevizija Slovenija, is allowed to broadcast advertising for
up to 10 minutes per hour given the additional financing from TV licensing fees. Between the hours of
6:00 p.m. and 11:00 p.m., the advertising time limit is reduced to seven minutes for the public broadcaster. In
Serbia, advertising time is regulated on an hourly and daily basis, where commercial broadcasters are restricted
to 20% of the daily broadcasts and to 20% per hour of broadcasting. Similarly to Slovenia, in Croatia the
permitted advertising time per hour is 12 minutes with no daily limit and direct sales advertising must be at
least 15 minutes.

The advertising markets in South Eastern Europe have benefitted from robust macro-economic conditions.
Advertising spend in our core three countries (Slovenia, Serbia and Bosnia and Herzegovina) is expected to
grow faster than real GDP, with TV channel advertising remaining resilient. The recent decline of advertising
spend in Croatia resulted from bankruptcy of one of Croatia’s biggest company, Agrokor, which employed
approximately 60 thousand total staff members and its revenues accounted for more than 15% of Croatia’s
total GDP.

The Direct Media/Pink Acquisition, completed in September 2018, focuses on targeted advertising and
specialized Pay-TV and positions us at the forefront of digital advertising in the region. As a result, we
acquired the know-how of more than 100 of the best professionals in the region who provide significant
synergies with the broader operations of the Group.

**OUR BUSINESS**

**Our Business Overview**

We are the leading cable and media player in Southeastern Europe, providing services to approximately
3.7 million homes as of March 31, 2021. We are the leading distributor of Pay-TV in our core markets of
Slovenia, Serbia, Bosnia and Herzegovina and the number two distributor in Montenegro. As of March 31,
2021, we provided services to approximately 10.9 million RGUs and analog and digital cable Pay-TV services
to approximately 1.9 million unique subscribers. United Group’s revenue for the three months ended
March 31, 2021 was €439.4 million and UG Adjusted EBITDA was €179.2 million. The Group had Run-Rate
Revenue for the annualized last two quarters ended March 31, 2021 of €1,916.4 million and Run-Rate Last
Two Quarter Annualized Adjusted EBITDA for March 31, 2021 was €706.3 million.

The Combined Group is the clear multi-play leader in its footprint, with market leading positions in Pay-TV,
broadband internet and fixed-line and mobile-telephony in Slovenia, Serbia, Bosnia and Herzegovina,
Montenegro, North Macedonia, Bulgaria, Croatia and, following the Forthnet Acquisition, Greece. The
Combined Group’s addressable market comprised 13.4 million households as of December 31, 2020.

We have grown rapidly through both acquisitions and organic growth. In July 2020, we acquired Vivacom, the
market leading integrated telecommunications operator in Bulgaria, based on total revenue for the year ended
December 31, 2020, which is the leading operator in fixed-line telephony services and broadband services, the
number three provider of mobile-telephony services and the number three provider of Pay-TV, in each case,
by number of subscribers as of March 31, 2021. The Vivacom Acquisition increased our addressable market
by approximately 35% in terms of population, and the addition of Vivacom’s subscriber base more than
doubled our existing subscriber base. In March 2020, we also acquired Tele2 Croatia, the third largest
telecommunications operator in Croatia, based on mobile revenues as of March 31, 2021, through which we
offer mobile services in Croatia. In November 2020, we completed the acquisition of a controlling interest in
Forthnet S.A., a prominent telecom operator and Pay-TV provider in Greece, which marked our entry into
the Greek market and will strengthen our position as an industry leader in Southeastern Europe. In
January 2021, we acquired Bulgaria’s largest multi-platform media company, Nova Broadcasting Group
EOOD, from Advance Media Group EAD, providing a strong base for our content offering in Bulgaria. In
July 2021, we signed an agreement to acquire a majority interest in Optima Telekom, a Croatian telecom
operator offering a broad range of fixed internet and pay-TV services. Subject to its completion, the Optima
Telekom Acquisition will allow us to further expand our presence in the Croatian market and offer a full range
of telecommunication services, including pay-TV, through our existing infrastructure in the country.

We offer a diverse and differentiated line of products and services. We are the leading distributor of satellite
(“DTH”) Pay-TV across Southeastern Europe, with Pay-TV product and service offerings in each of Slovenia,
Serbia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, North Macedonia and Montenegro, where we use our Total TV platform to
serve subscribers both inside and outside of our cable footprint to deliver content across the entire region,
including rural areas. Following the Vivacom Acquisition, we also provide Pay-TV services in Bulgaria and
are the leading IPTV provider in Bulgaria, while the Nova Broadcasting Group Acquisition strengthened our
content offering in Bulgaria. Following the Forthnet Acquisition, we also provide cable and DTH services in
Greece. In addition to our cable-based and satellite-based services, we offer mobile-telephony services in
Slovenia, Bulgaria and Croatia. We provide 4G LTE coverage to almost the entire population in each of these
countries, and we are rolling out 5G networks across our mobile-telephony footprint. On September 21, 2020,
we announced the commercial launch of our 5G network in Bulgaria, and to that end in May 2021, we
secured a 20-year license for 100 MHz spectrum frequencies in the 3.6 GHz band. We also in April 2021
secured 15-year spectrum licenses in Slovenia for 5G frequencies, and commenced deployment and
commercial launch of 5G 3600 MHz in Slovenia in June 2021. We are participating in a 5G spectrum auction
in Croatia this year.

Our core telecommunications business is also complemented by our two OTT distribution platforms that
customers can access through internet based streaming: EON, our regional OTT platform, which enables
customers connected to our competitors’ broadband internet connections outside of our cable footprint to
access our attractive portfolio of Pay-TV channels, and NetTV Plus, our international OTT platform, which
delivers ethnic and local language content to the ex-Yugoslav diaspora around the world. In July 2020, we
launched Shoppster, our regional e-commerce online-shopping platform, which offers more than 20 popular
product categories, including electronics, home and gardening, tools, fashion, items for children and kitchen
appliances. Shoppster is available as an integrated online and TV shopping platform in Serbia and Slovenia.


-----

Through our in-house content business, we produce distinctive and attractive in-house media content for our
Pay-TV channels across multiple key genres that have historically driven Pay-TV subscriptions. These channels
include Southeastern Europe’s most popular family of branded Pay-TV sports channels, as well as popular
movie channels, children’s channels, a 24/7 news channel, music channels and other specialized channels,
which we continue to expand both organically and through acquisitions. We currently produce over 40% of
the total content in our national (terrestrial) and cable operations, and our programs typically receive ratings
of between 30% to 60% in the markets in which they are available. The Group also has in-house media and
content production in Greece. We believe that our market leading content portfolio differentiates us from our
competitors, has enabled strong growth in our business and provides us with predictable third-party carriage
fees.

As part of our media business, we also provide advertising services and digital production and distribution.
Our Nova TV Croatia channel has strong local content production and profitability, with an audience share
of 40% and market share by advertising revenue of 50%. Nova BH and Nova M have appealing content, such
as popular national team football events until 2022, such as the Euro Cup qualifiers, Euro Cup, World Cup
qualifiers and League of Nations. In March 2019, we launched Nova S in Serbia. Nova S is a channel offering
high-quality local production series, sports, talk shows with well-known national presenters and high-quality
international productions, fully exclusive to SBB, Total TV and EON. The Nova Broadcasting Group
Acquisition makes us a major content player in Bulgaria by adding Nova BG’s media platform comprising
ten television channels, including NOVA TV, which broadcasts throughout Bulgaria, Bulgaria’s largest online
platform, Net Info, which reaches on average 80% of the Bulgarian population each month, and four radio
stations.

In addition to our own content, as a result of our pan regional presence and well established distribution
network, we are a distribution partner of choice for premium regional and international content owners, such
as Discovery/Eurosport, Viacom, AXN, CNN, HBO, Fox and Universal, and sports rights owners, such as
the English Premier League, Spanish Football League LaLiga, 2020 UEFA European Championship
qualifiers, 2020 UEFA European Championship, 2022 FIFA World Cup qualifiers, UEFA League of Nations,
ATP, Formula 1, Euroleague, and Moto GP, which we believe allows us to consistently obtain high-quality
content and attractive payment terms. Nova BG holds licenses to offer compelling content in Bulgaria through
distributors such as CBS Intenrational, the Walt Disney Company, Columbia Pictures and Paramount
Pictures, as well as popular sports content such as the English Premier League football, Euro Cup qualifiers
and the Euro Cup and Formula One racing. We believe these providers partner with us because of our
well-known brands, large network and our focus on Southeastern Europe.

We operate most of our business across eight countries in Southeastern Europe: Slovenia, Serbia, Bosnia and
Herzegovina, Bulgaria, Croatia, North Macedonia, Montenegro and Greece. These countries have a
combined population of approximately 40 million, distributed across approximately 13.4 million households
as of December 31, 2020, and represent the second-largest CEE market after Poland. Despite economic
differences, many of these countries share a joint history and form a single market in which small local
differences are overshadowed by the influence of similarities in cultural preferences and language across the
region and are characterized by growing Pay-TV and broadband markets that are currently underpenetrated
relative to some other CEE and Western European markets.

We are the leading multi-play provider in Slovenia, Serbia, Bosnia and Herzegovina and Bulgaria, where we
combine our services into packages, or bundles, which offer subscribers the convenience of being able to
purchase television, broadband internet and telephony services from a single provider, and provides us with
significant opportunities to cross-sell our products.

We believe that we are well-positioned to maintain our market leading positions in the Pay-TV and cable
broadband internet markets in Slovenia, Serbia and Bosnia and Herzegovina, and to further increase our
market shares, as we differentiate our product offerings through one of the highest download speeds in our
broadband markets, access to desirable media content, a well invested network and high-quality customer
service, which has led to relatively low churn rates which we believe demonstrate customer loyalty. We also
believe that we are well-positioned to continue to grow in our region, and build on our expansion into Bulgaria
and Greece. Our customers view the telecommunications products and services that we offer as part of their
everyday lives, which results in recurring, high demand for our products and makes our business more resilient
to macro-economic disruptions when compared to other discretionary products and services. For example,
during the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic our products and services have been instrumental in providing
connectivity and entertainment, as an increasing number of people began to work or study remotely and
spent significant amounts of time at home, which resulted in a significant increase in our voice and data
traffic between March and May 2020. In particular, over this period, our fixed data traffic increased at rates


-----

between 50% and 70%, while fixed voice traffic increased at rates between 50% and 85%, depending on the
country. In addition, our mobile data and voice traffic increased at rates between 30% and 40%, depending on
the country. Traffic levels decreased during the summer months and started increasing again as new lockdowns
were implemented in various countries. To accommodate such higher customer demand, we increased capacity
on network elements and interconnections. In this recurring, high demand environment, we believe we offer
superior products, faster broadband speeds and higher quality content than many of our competitors.

**Competitive Strengths**

We believe a number of key factors give us a competitive advantage, including:

**_We are the leading multi-play service provider with a pan regional platform across Southeastern Europe._**

We are the leading multi-play telecommunications and media provider in Southeastern Europe, a position
which we have strengthened significantly through the Vivacom Acquisition. Specifically, we are the leading
provider of Pay-TV in our three core markets of Slovenia, Serbia and Bosnia and Herzegovina, and the
leading provider of broadband in Slovenia and Bosnia and Herzegovina, in each case, based on market share
by number of subscribers. We are also the leading provider of broadband and the number three provider of
Pay-TV in Bulgaria based on market share by number of subscribers for the year ended December 31, 2020,
and the second-largest Pay-TV operator in Greece. In addition to our cable-based and satellite-based services,
we offer mobile-telephony services in Slovenia, in Bulgaria and in Croatia. The acquisitions we have made
have delivered significant geographic expansion and diversification of our business into Bulgaria and Greece.
The Vivacom Acquisition, for example, increased our addressable market by 35% in terms of population, and
doubled our existing customer base. Furthermore, our scale and presence across Southeastern Europe and
across our product portfolios allows us to cross-sell our services and expand the number of multi-play
packages we provide, creating opportunities to expand our customer base.

and which we believe forms a single media market. The Vivacom Acquisition and Forthnet Acquisition added

whereas competitors operating in a single country within the region cannot offer similarly broad coverage. We
are also able to offer our content partners value added services such as providing subtitles for television shows
and can spread the costs across our operations in the entire region, whereas we believe such costs would not be
economically justifiable for a competitor operating within a single country in the region.

Media activities at United Media fall into four categories: channel production, distribution, advertising and
digital. We believe that several factors make us an attractive partner to third-party content owners: our pan
regional presence, large subscriber base, advanced network, cable and DTH platforms and leading market
positions. We also offer attractive advertising services with desirable advertising slots, which we sell to both
local advertisers and high-profile clients from around the world. We work with advertisers to tailor
advertisements to their target audiences, and we have begun to generate revenue from the sale of advertising
across our platforms, particularly in our television stations and on our broadcast and cable networks. We have
also established a digital music production and content distribution business. Following the Nova TV Croatia
Acquisition and Direct Media/Pink Acquisition, we significantly developed our media business by adding
leading full format TV stations in Croatia, Bosnia and Herzegovina and Montenegro. Nova TV Croatia has
strong local content production and profitability, with an audience share of 40% and market share by
advertising revenue of 50% as of December 31, 2020. Nova BH and Nova M have appealing content, such as
popular national team football events until 2022 (Euro Cup qualifiers, Euro Cup, World Cup qualifiers and
League of Nations). In March 2019, we launched Nova S in Serbia. Nova S is a channel offering high-quality
local production series, sports, talk shows with well-known national presenters and high-quality international
productions, fully exclusive to SBB, Total TV and EON. The Nova Broadcasting Group Acquisition makes us
a major content player in Bulgaria.

With our own content, we can control the end-to-end creation process, produce a wide range of attractive
local and genre specific content and maintain a structural hedge on content costs. Our in-house production
has significantly increased over recent years, and the content offered has continually improved, including by
way of the leading Sport Klub channel by adding popular sporting events to our content portfolio, which
includes some of the most popular sports offerings in the region, some of which have been temporarily
suspended and/or postponed during the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. In addition, we have sold distribution
rights for this channel to all major third-party distribution platforms in the region, who pay a recurring
carriage fee. Due to our own distribution platforms and our relationships with all major third-party
distribution platforms in the region, we are able to immediately distribute new channels throughout the region,
including Bulgaria following completion of the Vivacom Acquisition.
