**_Low churn rates despite regular price increases demonstrate our loyal customer base and differentiated_**
**_proposition._**

Our business model is attractive and resilient. We believe our portfolio of must have products and our superior
offering have resulted in a growing and loyal customer base with relatively low churn rates, combined with the


**Most importantsports events**


-----

ability to up sell and cross-sell products. Our customers view the telecommunications products and services
that we offer as part of their everyday lives, which results in recurring, high demand for our products and
makes our business more resilient to macro-economic disruptions when compared to other discretionary
products and services. For example, during the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic our products and services have
been instrumental in providing connectivity and entertainment, as an increasing number of people began to
work or study remotely and spend significant amounts of time at home, which resulted in a significant increase
in our voice and data traffic between March and May 2020. In particular, over this period, our fixed data
traffic increased at rates between 50% and 70%, while fixed voice traffic increased at rates between 50% and
85%, depending on the country. In addition, our mobile data and voice traffic increased at rates between 30%
and 40%, depending on the country. To accommodate such higher customer demand, we increased capacity
on network elements and interconnections. In this recurring, high demand environment, we believe we offer
superior products, faster broadband speeds and higher quality content than our competitors. Customer loyalty
is evidenced by our relatively low historical churn rates. Churn rate is defined as the percentage of customers
that no longer subscribe for a certain service compared to the average number of customers in a particular
month. Churn rates for a period of one year or longer are an average of the monthly average churn rate. For
the three months ended March 31, 2021, our unique cable subscriber churn rate annualized was 10%, which is
below recent reported cable subscriber churn rates of certain Western European peers. We believe our relatively
low churn rates provide, among other benefits, recurring cash flows and visibility with respect to future
revenue. Moreover, these churn rates have persisted notwithstanding regular price increases. From 2017, our
Blended Cable ARPU excluding Vivacom has grown from €20.5 for the nine months ended September 30,
2017 to €23.2 for the three months ended March 31, 2021, representing a CAGR of 3.6%. Average triple play
monthly fees have also increased across geographies, from €28 in 2013 to €33 for legacy packages (21% of
triple play base) and €34 for current EON packages (78% of triple play base) in Serbia, from €41 in 2015 to
€46 for legacy packages (28% of triple play base) and €48 for current EON packages (72% of triple play base)
in Slovenia, and from €27 in 2013 to €31 for legacy packages (21% of triple play base) and €32 for current
EON packages (78% of triple play base) in Bosnia and Herzegovina, each for the three months ended
March 31, 2021. In addition, Vivacom’s declining churn rates, together with our experience in driving customer
loyalty, present significant upside potential. For the three months ended March 31, 2021, Vivacom’s mobile
subscriber churn rate was 18% annualized compared to 25% for the year ended December 31, 2017, and its
IPTV subscriber churn rate was 11% annualized compared to 15% for the year ended December 31, 2017.

**_Our business and market positioning benefit from a well invested, advanced cable network infrastructure with a_**
**_broad reach across the region and from national mobile networks in Slovenia, Bulgaria and Croatia._**

We strive to be the most advanced media and telecommunications company in Southeastern Europe. We
operate an advanced proprietary HFC network which is fully bi-directional and EuroDOCSIS 3.0 enabled,
covering all of our homes passed in Serbia, Bosnia and Herzegovina and Montenegro, and approximately
98% of homes passed in our HFC network in Slovenia as of November 1, 2020 are fully bi-directional. We
operate the largest fiber network in the region, comprised of 8,966 kilometers of backbone and extending
10,119 kilometers across metropolitan regions in Slovenia (approximately 3,506 kilometers), Serbia
(approximately 4,907 kilometers), Bosnia and Herzegovina (approximately 1,080 kilometers) and Montenegro
(approximately 626 kilometers). We also operate one of the largest fiber networks in Bulgaria, with 1.7 million
(or 58%) of households in the country covered and a fully owned fiber connecting to major points of presence
across Europe. As of March 31, 2021, 91% of our core network was DOCSIS 3.1 ready. With the addition of
Vivacom’s cable network, our cable network covers approximately 3.7 million homes passed, as of March 31,
2021. Our network has an average homes passed per fiber optics node ratio in the range of approximately 274,
213 and 234 across Slovenia, Serbia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, respectively, which we believe is unrivalled in
Southeastern Europe and compares favorably to other European cable operators, which average 562 homes
passed per node on the basis of comparable peers operating in UK, Sweden, Spain, Germany and Belgium.

We believe that our cable TV infrastructure allows us to provide higher quality digital TV, high-speed
broadband and fixed-line telephony than other cable operators in our markets. Our EuroDOCSIS 3.0 network
allows us to compete effectively in Slovenia, where FttH constituted approximately 44% of the broadband
market share as of December 31, 2020. We can match FttH speeds in overlapping markets and have a service
speed advantage in non-FttH areas. In Serbia, our broadband internet speed gives us an advantage over most
of our broadband internet competitors, and we provide broadband speeds of 75-1000 Mbps for the majority
of our subscribers in Serbia. We also provide internet download speeds which we believe compare favorably to
the national average in Serbia with our average recorded download speed being 1.8x faster than that of one of
our main competitors. Additionally, we also believe that we provide superior internet download speeds in
Slovenia with our average recorded download speed being 2.9x faster than that of one of our main competitors
(which the competitor is only able to offer in certain geographic areas). In Bosnia and Herzegovina, we are


-----

well-positioned to compete with incumbents that primarily use DSL, as well as with smaller regional cable
operators. In Bosnia and Herzegovina, we believe that our average recorded download speed is 4.5x faster
than that of one our main competitors. In Montenegro, we have developed FttH GPON with over 25,438
homes passed and over 5,742 homes connected to this network. Following the Vivacom Acquisition, we
operate the largest fiber network in Bulgaria, providing VDSL with speeds of more than 70 Mbps for more
than 50% of our network and more than 50 Mbps for 74% of our network, with full redundancy capability
and high service reliability.

Our mobile network covers the majority of Slovenia’s population through our extensive 2G/3G/4G networks,
and at present we have the capability to provide 4G (LTE) and 4G+ (LTE-A) coverage to approximately 99%
and 98%, respectively, of the Slovenian population. We are also the third largest mobile operator in Bulgaria
by market share, with approximately three million subscribers as of March 31, 2021, and provide LTE mobile
network coverage to 99.94% of the Bulgarian population. We believe Vivacom’s mobile strategy, which
includes attractive tariff plans, flexible service bundles, integrated IT systems and the fastest 4G/LTE mobile
network in Europe, has allowed it to differentiate itself from competitors and consistently gain market share
in recent years. In addition, we are the third largest telecommunications operator in Croatia based on mobile
revenues as of March 31, 2021, with a highly competitive 4G service, a signal covering all major cities and
important roads in Croatia and a growing customer base of nearly one million as of March 31, 2021. To
further develop our networks, we have successfully tested and are rolling out next generation 5G networks
across our mobile-telephony footprint. On September 21, 2020, we announced the commercial launch of our
5G network in Bulgaria, and to that end in May 2021, we secured a 20-year license for 100 MHz spectrum
frequencies in the 3.6 GHz band. We also in April 2021 secured 15-year spectrum licenses in Slovenia for 5G
frequencies, and commenced deployment and commercial launch of 5G 3600 MHz in Slovenia in June 2021.
We are participating in a 5G spectrum auction in Croatia this year.

We believe that our cable network is well invested and benefits from low maintenance UG Adjusted Capital
Expenditure requirements. We believe that this will allow us to manage our UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure
in the near to medium term, with expenditures largely being success and capacity based as our business
expands, while making targeted improvements to our network. We believe that Vivacom has a similarly well
invested network and profile. UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure was €91.3 million for the three months ended
March 31, 2021, and we estimate that UG Adjusted Capital Expenditure for the year ended December 31,
2021 will be between €371 million and €373 million (excluding mobile frequencies and any amounts for
Forthnet, Nova BG or Optima Telekom ).

**_Strong track record of profitable growth driven by low penetration rates and cross-selling opportunities, as well_**
**_as successful integration of acquisitions._**

We have a strong track record of profitable growth, underpinned by low penetration rates in the markets in
which we operate and cross-selling opportunities due to our scale, as well as a record of successfully integrating
acquisitions. We operate most of our business across the following eight countries in Southeastern Europe:
Slovenia, Serbia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Bulgaria, Croatia, Greece, North Macedonia and Montenegro.
These countries are characterized by growing Pay-TV and broadband markets that are currently
underpenetrated relative to some other CEE and Western European markets. Following the Forthnet
Acquisition we also operate in Greece. As of March 31, 2021, in Slovenia, our Pay-TV penetration of homes
passed and broadband internet penetration were 61% and 89%, respectively; in Serbia, Pay-TV penetration
and broadband internet penetration were 65% and 73%, respectively; and in Bosnia and Herzegovina, Pay-TV
penetration and broadband internet penetration were 61% and 81%, respectively. Additionally, due to
historically strong regulatory constraints on bundling Pay-TV, broadband internet and telephony services,
RGUs per cable subscriber in our key markets in Serbia, Slovenia and Bosnia and Herzegovina have lagged
behind CEE and Western European cable markets. Markets in Bulgaria have similar characteristics. Our cable
RGUs per subscriber ratios of 2.3x for Serbia, 2.7x for Slovenia and 2.3x for Bosnia and Herzegovina, in each
case as of March 31, 2021, demonstrate that there are strong opportunities to continue to utilize up selling
and cross-selling opportunities to grow our cable RGUs per subscriber ratio in Slovenia.

At the same time, Pay-TV penetration in all of our markets has been growing, driven by increasingly attractive
content and bundled offers. Service penetration in our markets has increased as multi-play packages have
expanded but is still below the levels of some Western European cable markets (except in Slovenia). Leveraging
our extensive cable infrastructure, we use our high-quality Pay-TV content as a basis to cross and up sell our
broadband internet and telephony products to existing cable Pay-TV customers and offer multi-play packages
to new customers, which we expect will allow us to continue to improve penetration rates as customers
increasingly focus on the convenience of receiving their multimedia and communications services in a bundled
offer from one provider. For example, while penetration rates in Slovenia are more comparable to those of
Western European operators, a substantial number of our subscribers in Slovenia are subscribed to a single
service, which we believe offers significant cross-selling opportunities. Our number of quad-play subscribers
in Slovenia has grown since we began offering mobile services in late 2012 as an MVNO, and, since the
acquisition of Tušmobil in April 2015, we have increased the number of quad-play subscribers in Slovenia,
from 1% in April 2015 to 38% as of March 31, 2021.

In addition to organic growth, we have made targeted and value accretive investments and acquisitions of
attractive cable and mobile assets, and we have been successful at integrating these acquisitions and realizing
synergies related to a number of these acquisitions, providing lessons learned and significant know-how for
integrating Vivacom, Forthnet, Nova BG and Tele2 Croatia. For example, our acquisition of Telemach
Slovenia from Liberty Global in 2009, a foray into a new market with a different language and culture, proved
to be a successful cross border acquisition story. Within a decade, we tripled blended cable ARPU of Telemach
Slovenia (from €13 in 2008, to €35 in 2018) and adjusted EBITDA (from €24 million in 2008, to €71 million in
2018), while revenue grew from €46 million in 2008 to €1.2 billion in the year ended December 31, 2020. This
was achieved through both organic growth and the acquisition of Tušmobil in April 2015 which provided us
with an opportunity to create a fully convergent cable, internet, fixed-line and mobile-telephony operator in
Slovenia, and allowed Slovenian customers to benefit from a convenient bundled product offering consisting
of cable Pay-TV, internet, fixed-line and mobile-telephony services from a single provider.

**_We have a track record of delivering revenue and UG Adjusted EBITDA growth and realizing cost synergies_**
**_related to our acquisitions while generating strong UG Adjusted EBITDA margins._**

Our revenues have historically proven to be resilient, even during periods of challenging economic conditions.
During the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, almost all of our revenue streams have proven resilient and stable,
particularly those generated by our telecommunication business segments, such as broadband internet and
mobile-telephony. Since 2018, we have increased RGUs from 3.8 million as of December 31, 2018, to
10.9 million as of March 31, 2021, and we have delivered strong organic growth in both revenue and UG
Adjusted EBITDA during such period, significantly outperforming GDP growth in the countries in which we
operate. In addition to organic growth, we have benefitted from targeted and value accretive investments and
acquisitions of attractive cable and mobile assets, and have been successful in integrating these acquisitions


-----

and realizing synergies related to them. Our revenue increased to €439 million for the three months ended
March 31, 2021, compared to €194 million for the three months ended March 31, 2020, and UG Adjusted
EBITDA increased to €179 million for the three months ended March 31, 2021, compared to €85 million for
the three months ended March 31, 2020. We have also proven our ability to generate strong adjusted EBITDA
margins. Despite investments in new ventures, we had operating profit margin of 11% and 7% for the
three months ended March 31, 2020 and 2021, respectively, and maintained UG Adjusted EBITDA margins
of 44% and 41% for the three months ended March 31, 2020 and 2021, respectively, highlighting our successful
approach to integrating new businesses and driving profitability.

**_A highly experienced management team with a proven track record of supporting and growing our business_**
**_and successfully integrating accretive, cross border acquisitions, with a highly committed Sponsor._**

Many of our key management members have been with the business since its inception, including our founder
and chairman of the advisory board, Dragan Šolak; chief executive officer and group vice president of
marketing and media, Victoriya Boklag; and group vice president of operations, Violeta Vasilijević. Our
senior management team also includes Janez Živko, group vice president of finance, who joined in March 2015
and had previously served as the chief financial officer of the Petrol Group, one of the largest companies in
Slovenia; Vladislav Ratajac, group vice president of corporate development, joined management in 2011,
having previously held positions at Mid Europa Partners and Deutsche Bank; Željko Batistić, group vice
president of technology who joined the group in 2012 as CEO of Telemach Bosnia and prior to that held a
number of technical and operational management positions in the industry; and Dragica Pilipović Chaffey,
group vice president of corporate affairs, joined the management team in 2009 and had previously held a
number of senior posts in the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development. Other members of our
senior management team also have substantial experience in the telecommunications, media and technology
industry, as well as in banking, private equity and corporate finance firms. Many members of our senior
management team, including our founder, have each held different positions within our business and have
shaped the direction of our development and growth within Southeastern Europe. As our operations have
become more mature, the senior management team has been positioned to leverage its significant industry
experience and corporate background and to successfully expand our business through bolt on acquisitions
and integration of cable assets and content companies. Furthermore, certain members of management hold
significant equity stakes in the business, which amount to approximately 42%. See “Principal Shareholders.”
Due in part to the significant international experience of most members of the senior management team, who
either attended university abroad or worked internationally for a prolonged period of time, we have
successfully grown our business from being a single country Pay-TV operator to being the telecommunications
and media services leader in Southeastern Europe.

We also intend to draw from the market expertise, business relationships, knowledge and experience of our
sponsor, BC Partners. BC Partners has strong telecommunications expertise and an extensive and successful
track record of investing in companies in Europe and in the telecommunications and information sectors
through portfolio companies that include:

- Advanced Computer Software Group, which is a leading UK provider of critical software to mid-sized
companies and public sector organizations;

- NAVEX Global, which is the global leader in ethics and compliance software as a service provider;

- Suddenlink Communications, which was the seventh largest cable operator by subscribers in the United
States prior to its acquisition by Altice USA in 2015, and which BC Partners fully exited in 2020;

- Com Hem, Sweden’s leading cable TV and broadband operator, which was successfully floated on the
Nasdaq Stockholm exchange in 2014 and which BC Partners fully exited in 2017; and

- Unitymedia, an integrated telecoms service provider and the second-largest cable company in Germany,
which BC Partners sold to Liberty Global in 2009 after growing the business through acquisitions and
operational improvements.

BC Partners has a strong track record of driving cost savings and improvements in margin, while at the same
time growing its portfolio companies both organically and through targeted acquisitions.

**Strategy**

Our goal is to strengthen our telecommunications and media leadership position in Southeastern Europe and
to continue our strong growth momentum by successfully integrating Vivacom, Tele2 Croatia, Forthnet,
Nova BG, Optima Telekom and other acquisitions and by leveraging our competitive strengths: well invested


-----

fixed and mobile networks, differentiated content offerings and local production capabilities and a loyal
customer base. Our focus is on continuing to provide our customers the best products and services in each of
our segments and markets, including more innovative products and features, a superior customer experience
and better value compared to competitors. In parallel, our goals are to continue to deliver exceptional revenue
growth across segments (both organically and through strategic acquisitions) and capitalize on operating
leverage and continued operating efficiencies to deliver strong profitability and cash flow growth.

In order to achieve these goals, we have identified the following strategic pillars:

**_Continued focus on our competitive market position by leveraging our advanced network, differentiated_**
**_content offerings and loyal customer base._**

We have differentiated ourselves with our customers by having superior next generation infrastructure in our
footprint. Where we believe the return on investment is appropriate, we will continue to expand the coverage
and capacity of those networks, including 5G capability. Our strategy is to continue to offer the most attractive
products in Southeastern Europe with better content choice, speed, functionality and service quality than
those of our competitors, at prices that provide a compelling value. We will continue to deliver value to our
customers based on a consistent and effective strategy that is underpinned by simplicity, value for money and
innovation. We believe that our acquisitions of Vivacom, Tele2 Croatia, Forthnet, Nova BG and Optima
Telekom are in line with a strategy of expanding coverage in Southeastern Europe and will enable the
development of our business in attractive markets.

**_Increase service penetration across the region by cross-selling products and services and up selling value adding_**
**_products to existing customers._**

We intend to continue to focus on subscriber growth opportunities in our relatively under penetrated markets.
Over time, we expect our businesses in Serbia and Bosnia and Herzegovina to converge with Slovenia in terms
of broadband and Pay-TV penetration as well as in service penetration (measured by RGU per subscriber).

We aim to achieve an increase in triple play (and in the case of Slovenia and Bulgaria, quad-play) penetration
by continuing to shift focus in marketing and subscriber interactions from single services to bundled services
and utilizing next generation digital television services, attractive local content and high-speed broadband
services to continue to promote bundled services. We have significantly grown our mobile business and
developed our multi-play (including quad-play) offering in Slovenia, and we intend to continue to build on
that success in Bulgaria, where the Vivacom Acquisition has significantly expanded our addressable market,
and provide further opportunities for cross-selling and multi-play bundling. In particular, we intend to leverage
Vivacom’s high-quality 4G/LTE network to expand its leadership in mobile data and build on its track record
of subscriber growth. In addition, we aim to retain and grow Vivacom’s existing customer base by competing
on value, for example, by offering more add on products, incentivizing longer term contracts by offering
better pricing and subsidies for certain products, offering bundled services to decrease churn, including
premium Pay-TV services and providing FTTx solutions in larger cities to satisfy customer demand for high
broadband speeds.

We also intend to capitalize on our superior high-speed broadband capabilities to increase revenue. Specifically,
we intend to migrate our existing high-speed broadband subscribers to higher speeds, which we believe will
continue to support broadband ARPU growth and further reduce residential subscriber churn rates. In
addition, recent acquisitions have enhanced our ability to monetize premium content, cross promote and
generate compelling cost synergies.

**_Consolidate United Media as the leading media company in Southeastern Europe._**

Since inception, our strategy has been centered on differentiating our offering by producing superior and/or
exclusive Pay-TV channels for our customers. We have applied this philosophy to all of our Group companies
with great success, and we have created an attractive portfolio of full format national as well as specialized,
thematic Pay-TV channels that we believe are a must have on all regional distribution platforms. Following the
Vivacom Acquisition, with the integration of Vivacom and Nova BG into our operations, we are applying
this philosophy in Bulgaria. We intend to continue to grow our content offering by further developing our
portfolio of owned content, entering into strategic partnerships with third-party content owners and acquiring
content owners, as in the past with the acquisition of Nova TV Croatia and Direct Media/Pink.

**_Further expand our addressable market by utilizing our OTT platform and attractive content._**

Leveraging our strong brands and our attractive content, we intend to continue to develop our two OTT
content platforms, our regional OTT platform, EON, and our international OTT platform, NetTV Plus, to


-----

further expand our addressable market to areas outside our cable footprint. While our DTH Pay-TV platform
aims to deliver our content to subscribers in rural areas in our markets without cable infrastructure, our
regional OTT platform enables customers in metropolitan areas outside of our cable footprint, who have
subscribed to the broadband internet services of our competitors, to access our attractive portfolio of Pay-TV
channels and unique user interface and customer experience. Additionally, NetTV Plus allows us to provide
over 200 local language channels showing ethnic content to the entire ex-Yugoslav diaspora around the world.
By expanding our geographic reach outside of Southeastern Europe to customers in countries in Western
Europe and North America, we believe that we are positioned to further increase our RGU base and earnings
potential. We also plan to further invest in our in-house development of customer premises equipment,
including OTT TV boxes for EON, which enables video streaming to customers’ TVs and allows us to offer
services on competitors’ broadband networks.

**_Continued focus on innovation._**

We seek to continue innovating and enhancing our product offering to further strengthen our leading position
in Southeastern Europe. Our in-house technology innovation and software development center, United.Cloud,
enables us to focus on leading the introduction of next generation television and broadband internet services
by delivering to subscribers services such as EON (our next generation video delivery platform that includes
linear and non-linear digital broadcasting, over 22,000 VoD assets, CatchUp TV, a Smart TV application for
Samsung and LG and a multiscreen service for mobile, tablet and personal computer/laptop devices),
UNIFON (our proprietary VoIP application connecting customers’ fixed-line telephones outside of their
homes), our self-help application, enhanced TV features such as VoD and CatchUp TV services and many
others. We will also continue to promote the digitalization of internal and external processes to improve
customer satisfaction and profitability. In July 2020, we leveraged our position in both the broadband and
Pay-TV markets to launch Shoppster, our regional e-commerce online-shopping platform, which will initially
offer more than 20 popular product categories, including electronics, home and gardening, tools, fashion,
items for children and kitchen appliances. We intend for Shoppster to deliver the simple, reliable and secure
e-shopping experience that modern consumers expect.

**_Continue to grow customer base and operations through value accretive acquisitions._**

We have a successful track record of making acquisitions on attractive terms and successfully integrating
those acquisitions. Between 2011 and March 31, 2021, we have acquired and integrated (or are in the process
of integrating) approximately 50 cable TV operators, content platforms, media companies, mobile service
providers, B2B service providers and ISPs in Slovenia, Serbia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Bulgaria, Greece,
Croatia and Montenegro. We have also expanded our addressable market through the Vivacom Acquisition
and Nova Broadcasting Group Acquisition (in Bulgaria), the Forthnet Acquisition (in Greece) and the
Optima Telekom Acquisition (in Croatia), as well as various other recent acquisitions. Our acquisition strategy
consists of expanding our scale in a value accretive manner, enhancing our content offering, expanding our
fixed-line and mobile-telephony operations and leveraging our experience and successful acquisition history
to continue to make acquisitions that allow us to generate additional value for our operations through
increasing scale and product offerings.

We plan to continue to make value accretive acquisitions at attractive multiples to integrate regional service
providers, cable assets and fixed-line and mobile-telephony operators into the business, and we intend to
continue taking a disciplined approach to acquisitions by assessing individual opportunities on the basis of
merit, ability to integrate assets into our existing business plans and potential for value creation.

**_Continue to Focus on Environmental, Social and Corporate Governance (“ESG”) Matters_**

We and our shareholders recognize that achieving a sustainable and responsible business that has a positive
social impact will be key to our future success. As we have grown our Group, we have increased our emphasis
on integrating ESG considerations into our decision-making and reporting processes. In 2020, we established
a dedicated ESG coordinator role within the Group and finalized a detailed ESG action plan and
implementation roadmap in consultation with external advisors.

To promote environmental sustainability in our operations, we are taking active steps to minimize our
environmental footprint, while also collecting and analyzing Group historical data to set future KPI targets
for reductions in carbon emissions, climate change policy, energy use and energy sourcing. We have committed
to the Science Based Targets initiative which helps to drive climate action in the private sector by enabling
companies to set emissions reduction targets with scientific data. We are committed to reducing greenhouse
gas emissions across our offices and infrastructure and we established a solar power plant in Slovenia in 2019


-----

with an annual production capacity of 254 kWh and have leveraged our experience in this project to look for
additional green energy projects which could cover a significant part of our carbon emission footprint. In
addition, we use electric vehicles in our operations where feasible, and we work to exchange old, less-energy
efficient equipment for more energy-efficient devices. In 2020, we generated approximately 128.1 thousand
tons of CO2 emissions (9.3 thousand tons of scope 1 emissions and 118.8 thousand tons of scope 2 and
3 emissions), including the contribution of acquired companies, and we intend to reduce these to
approximately 50.6 thousand tons by 2030. In 2020, we recycled 1,539 tons of network telecom equipment,
batteries, cables, paper and cardboard. We are also committed to minimizing waste and we repurpose, reuse or
recycle 100% of returned customer devices and accessories.

We actively support the communities in which we operate, and in 2020, we named a Group-level director for
corporate social responsibility to coordinate efforts in this regard among our operating companies. We have
as a Group donated €4.5 million in 2020 and €2.0 million for the twelve months ended March 31, 2021, to
groups and activities dedicated to protecting the environment, education and the socially vulnerable, as well
as other donations, such as donating personal protective equipment to help fight COVID-19. We have also
engaged in multiple community engagement activities in the past few years, with a focus on using our platform
to deliver knowledge to children (including programs for online safety), students, the general public and
disadvantaged groups, by leveraging our core competencies in broadband internet and other
telecommunications. For 2021, we aim to increase the percentage of staff participating in a community
engagement activity (e.g., volunteering time or knowledge), which in 2020 stood at 7%.

We focus on building a safe, fair and inclusive working environment for our employees. To inform our diversity,
inclusion and safety targets, we collect data on our workforce, such as gender mix (55% male, 45% female),
percentage of women in management positions (30%, including our Chief Executive Officer) and percentage
of disabled employees (1%), in each case as of March 31, 2021. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2021,
staff total turnover is 12% and we have experienced 50 workplace injury incidents. We also have mandated
diversity and inclusion rules, and have documented these in employee manuals at our Group companies,
which include, among others, statutory requirements related to workers’ rights and human rights (e.g., antidiscrimination and anti-mobbing) and annual employee eNPS measurements. To facilitate further
transparency and accountability, we plan to expand our anonymous suggestion boxes already present in
certain of our Group companies and establish whistle-blowing programs as a distinct transparency function.
We also offer training programs to employees which are focused on improving job-related technical and
management skills, as well as on compliance with our internal policies.

**History**

Our founder and group executive chairman, Dragan Šolak, founded the company as a Serbian cable TV
operator in 2000. Between 2001 and 2005, we grew our business by constructing an advanced cable network
throughout Serbia. We also consolidated several sub-scale family owned cable operators and successfully
integrated them into our business. We launched our DTH services, Total TV, in Serbia in 2006 and in Slovenia,
Bosnia and Herzegovina and Montenegro in 2007 and expanded Total TV into Croatia in 2008 (divested in
2018) and North Macedonia in 2009. In 2007, we entered into a strategic alliance with Sport Klub, and we
acquired a controlling stake in the Ultra family of Pay-TV channels in 2009. As a result of our strategic
alliances, as well as the acquisition of local language television channels, we were among the first pay-TV
providers in Southeastern Europe to provide localized regional and international content.

In 2009, we acquired Telemach Slovenia, a leading triple-play provider in Slovenia, adding 160 thousand
subscribers to our operations. During 2010, our consolidation of three cable pay-TV operators in Sarajevo,
including KT Global Net, BH Cabel Net and ELOB, led to the formation of Telemach BH. In addition, over
recent years we have amassed a comprehensive portfolio of owned pay-TV channels, covering sports, movies,
news, music, general entertainment and children’s programming, through our United Media business, which
we have grown through focused and consistent investment. We continue to leverage our position as the sole
credible consolidator in the fragmented regional markets and have successfully acquired and integrated a
number of businesses since 2010, including Maxtel in 2016, a local B2B internet provider in Slovenia, and
Ikom in 2017, a cable operator in Serbia. In addition, following the acquisition of M kabl in 2016, a cable
operator in Montenegro, we have further expanded our subscriber base in Montenegro.

Following the liberalization of the fixed-line telephone markets in Bosnia and Herzegovina and Serbia in
2011 and 2012, respectively, we launched fixed-line telephony services in these two markets and, leveraging
our existing cable pay-TV and broadband internet subscriber base, became the second-largest Serbian fixedline telephone services provider in June 2013. We also launched our MVNO services in Slovenia in late 2012
and became an MNO upon our acquisition of Tušmobil in 2015, which allowed us to provide quad-play


-----

bundles (cable pay-TV, broadband internet, and fixed-line telephony and mobile-telephony services) to our
subscribers in Slovenia, in addition to stand-alone mobile-telephony services.

In July 2018, we acquired Nova TV d.d. from CME B.V. We believe this acquisition, which included several
popular television channels in Croatia, is helping us create a strong mainstream media platform, which further
differentiates our distribution platform, promotes our pay-TV channel portfolio, drives continued growth
and creates a strong platform for additional bolt on, accretive acquisitions. In September 2018, we acquired
Direct Media, a leading media buying agency in Serbia, which included Direct Media’s operations in Serbia,
Montenegro, North Macedonia and Albania, as well as our terrestrial TV stations Pink BiH and Pink
Montenegro, which have been rebranded Nova BH and Nova M, respectively.

On March 3, 2020, we completed the acquisition of Tele2 Croatia, the third largest telecommunications
operator in Croatia based on mobile revenues as of September 30, 2020. Tele2 Croatia seeks to offer the best
value proposition in the Croatian mobile market, for example, through its offering of unlimited mobile
services. Now trading as Telemach Croatia, the acquisition has enabled us to accelerate our growth and further
diversify our operations.

On July 31, 2020, we completed our acquisition of Vivacom, the market leading integrated
telecommunications operator in Bulgaria (based on revenue for the year ended December 31, 2020) which
offers both fixed and mobile telecommunications services, as well as broadcasting and satellite services, with
a market share of 30% in Bulgaria by revenue as of December 31, 2019, according to the CRC. Expansion in
Bulgaria increased our addressable market by approximately 35% in terms of population, and the addition of
Vivacom’s subscriber base more than doubled our existing subscriber base. Vivacom’s size, including
approximately three million mobile subscribers, 514 thousand fixed-telephony subscribers, 4 64 thousand
fixed broadband subscribers and 489 thousand pay-TV subscribers, provides us with significant additional
scale, compounding our existing leadership. We believe that the acquisition of Vivacom provides us with
greater scale and increases business diversification, expands our reach, cements our position as the industry
leader in Southeastern Europe and continues our growth.

In September 2020, we completed the acquisition of a significant minority interest in Forthnet S.A., a
prominent telecom operator and Pay-TV provider in Greece, and in November 2020, we acquired a controlling
interest in Forthnet. Forthnet provides home entertainment and communications services to nearly 1.4 million
RGUs. This marked our entry into the Greek market and strengthens our position as an industry leader in
Southeastern Europe. Forthnet is the second-largest Pay-TV operator in Greece. The Forthnet Acquisition
enables us to accelerate our growth and further diversify our Group

In January 2021, we acquired Bulgaria’s largest multi-platform media company, Nova Broadcasting Group
EOOD, providing a strong base for our content offering in Bulgaria.

In July 2021, we signed an agreement to acquire a majority interest in Croatian telecommunication operator
Optima Telekom. Optima Telekom offers a broad range of fixed broadband internet services to approximately
117 thousand subscribers and pay-TV services to approximately 57 thousand subscribers in Croatia. Upon
completion, the Optima Telekom Acquisition will allow us to further expand our presence in the Croatian
market enabling us to offer a full range of telecommunication services, including pay-TV, through our existing
infrastructure.

**_Pay-TV_**

We provide analog and digital cable pay-TV throughout our network in Slovenia, Serbia, Bosnia and
Herzegovina, Bulgaria and Montenegro. As of March 31, 2021, we provided our cable pay-TV services to
212 thousand subscribers in Slovenia through Telemach Slovenia (61% of homes passed), 736 thousand
subscribers in Serbia through SBB Serbia (65% of homes passed), and 208 thousand subscribers in Bosnia
and Herzegovina through Telemach BH (61% of homes passed). In Bulgaria, Vivacom offers DTH and IPTV
services throughout the country. As of March 31, 2021, Vivacom provided pay-TV services to approximately
521 thousand subscribers in Bulgaria. Following completion of the Optima Telekom Acquisition, we will
offer IPTV services to approximately 57 thousand subscribers in Croatia. In line with our business strategy,
we leverage our extensive cable network and distinctive cable pay-TV content to encourage our subscribers to
purchase one of our bundles, which offer the convenience of being able to receive television, broadband
internet and telephony services from a single provider. As of March 31, 2021, approximately 82% of our cable
pay-TV subscribers had purchased one of our bundles. For the three months ended March 31, 2021, our
analog and digital cable pay-TV business segment generated revenues of €51.6 million and an average ARPU
of €11.3.

We offer high-quality analog and digital pay-TV throughout our network. All of our pay-TV customers receive
our analog pay-TV service (“Basic TV”). Our Basic TV package has been standardized across our network


-----

and offers customers access to over 54 analog TV channels in Serbia, over 15 in Slovenia, and over 54 in
Bosnia and Herzegovina. In addition to Basic TV, we provide our customers with the option to subscribe to
our digital cable pay-TV services (previously offered under our D3 brand and now offered under the EON
brand of products and services), and we focus on migrating analog subscribers to digital services and on
continuing to take advantage of the cross and up selling opportunities provided by an influx of potential new
customers switching from analog to digital cable pay-TV. Our digital cable pay-TV service provides our
customers with access to between 106 and 310 digital channels depending on the particular market, including
up to approximately 88 HD channels and 162 radio stations. We offer channel line ups across a variety of
popular genres, such as sports, children’s entertainment and movies. We believe our high-quality and broad
channel and content offering allows us to take a distinctive position in the market as compared to our
competitors. In July 2020, in cooperation with Bosnian operator Trion Tel, we started offering EON bundle
packages in Republika Srpska (the Serbian part of Bosnia and Herzegovina), where we previously had no
cable presence, through the GPON of Trion Tel.

In addition to our bundles, we also offer our subscribers digital add on TV packages, each containing premium
SD and HD television channels, such as HBO, as well as bundled VoD options for subscribers who have
leased one of our digital receivers. Our digital cable pay-TV service also includes CatchUp TV and VoD
services. CatchUp TV provides subscribers with the ability to view a wide variety of television programs from
a group of popular channels at any time within seven days after the programs originally aired. VoD provides
subscribers with access to a library of over 26,000 movies and other programming titles, either on a
transactional basis or a monthly subscription contract.

In 2012, we launched our TV everywhere applications (previously offered under the D3 Go brand name and
now offered as one of our EON brand of products and services) for computer, tablet and mobile devices in
2012. Through these applications, we provide our existing cable pay-TV subscribers with access to our digital
pay-TV content “on the go.”Our TV everywhere content is also available to our mobile subscribers in Slovenia
over our mobile network.

_Direct to Home Pay-TV_

Our DTH, or satellite, pay-TV service, known as Total TV, is targeted at households outside our cable footprint
across Southeastern Europe. Since January 2018 we have not offered pay-TV services in Croatia, due to the
divestiture of our Total TV operations in Croatia in connection with the Nova TV Croatia Acquisition.
Following the acquisition of Forthnet, United Group also offers DTH pay-TV across Greece to approximately
313 thousand subscribers. Total TV provides subscribers with access to up to 122 channels in Serbia, 53 of
which are also available in HD format, 126 channels in Slovenia, 49 of which are also available in HD format,
and 129 channels in Bosnia and Herzegovina, 48 of which are also available in HD format. In Bulgaria,
Vivacom offers DTH pay-TV with over 160 channels, 20 of which are in HD, as well as multi-feed with over
200 additional channels. In Greece, Forthnet offers DTH pay-TV under the Nova Sports, Nova Cinema and
Nova Go brands, with 75 channels, 47 of which are in HD. As we only actively market our DTH offering in
those areas that are outside our cable footprint, there is limited to no overlap with analog and digital cable
Pay-TV offering. Additionally, there is a low risk of cable pay-TV cannibalization, due to the fact that, for a
similar price as basic DTH pay-TV services, our basic cable pay-TV services offer a better value.

As with our analog and digital cable pay-TV offering, customers can choose from a range of DTH packages
across different price points. Additionally, we have entered into partnership agreements with Telekom Slovenije
in Slovenia and Telekom Srbija in Serbia pursuant to which we offer DTH pay-TV content and re sell their
respective ADSL internet services to customers outside of our cable footprint.

_OTT Television_

Our two OTT content platforms: our regional OTT platform (previously branded as D3i, now operating
under the EON brand) and our international OTT platform (NetTV Plus), have enabled us to further expand
our reach:

- Regional OTT. Our EON regional OTT platform enables customers of our broadband internet competitors
within Serbia and Slovenia (but outside of our cable footprint) to access our distinctive digital content via
the internet. Unlike our DTH pay-TV platform, which aims to deliver content to subscribers in rural areas
without cable infrastructure, our regional OTT platform delivers pay-TV services to customers in
metropolitan areas. By expanding our reach beyond the traditional cable footprint using a regional OTT
platform, we are able to increase the number of subscribers to our pay-TV content.


-----

- International OTT. Our NetTV Plus platform, which we launched in 2013, provides over 300 channels in
SD, 73 channels in HD and 265 radio channels, of which more than 250 local language TV channels showing
ethnic content, including all national free-to-air channel offering, to the entire Yugoslav diaspora (estimated
at over 4 million people) around the world through the internet. As of December 31, 2020, we had
106 thousand NetTV Plus subscribers. Subscribers can access our NetTV Plus content through their TVs
using a set-top box connected to the internet, “Smart TVs” that have built in internet functionality or by
streaming content via internet enabled tablets, mobile devices and personal computers. By expanding our
geographic reach outside our region to customers in affluent countries in Western Europe and North
America, we are positioned to charge prices that are higher than the prices we are able to charge for our
pay-TV services in our other markets in Southeastern Europe.

- Forthnet OTT. Our own OTT content platform, which operates under the NOVA brand of products and
services, Novago, Novaflix, Nova on Demand. Our regional OTT platform offers our customers within the
region access to their digital Pay-TV channel offering. As a result, our NOVA subscribers can watch our
digital Pay-TV channels on their TV screens, computers, tablets and mobile devices.

**_Broadband Internet_**

We offer broadband internet in Slovenia, Serbia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Bulgaria, Montenegro and Greece.
Beginning in 2009, we upgraded our network to EuroDOCSIS 3.0, and our network is fully EuroDOCSIS 3.0
enabled. Our network offers our customers up to 1.6 Gbps download speeds. We believe that EuroDOCSIS
3.0 is superior to DSL and on par with the FttH services offered by our competitors. We currently provide
internet download speeds that we believe compare favorably to the national average with our average recorded
speeds being faster than that of the respective local incumbent by a factor of 2.7x in Slovenia, 1.5x in Serbia
and 2.9x in Bosnia and Herzegovina, as of April 16, 2021.

As our broadband internet operations provide us with very attractive margins due to little additional cost, we
leverage our attractive pay-TV offering to sell broadband internet services to existing pay-TV customers. As a
result, we do not sell our broadband internet services on a stand-alone basis and customers wishing to receive
our broadband internet services must, at a minimum, subscribe to our analog Basic TV package. As of March 31,
2021, we provided our broadband internet service to approximately 1,396 thousand subscribers across Telemach
Slovenia, SBB Serbia, Telemach BH, Vivacom Bulgaria and Telemach MNE. For the three months ended
March 31, 2021, our broadband internet business generated revenues of €73.9 million and an ARPU of €9.6.

In addition, we offer out-of-footprint internet services (broadband internet services provided through a thirdparty network) across Greece to approximately 528 thousand subscribers through Forthnet as of
December 31, 2020.

Following completion of the Optima Telekom Acquisition, we will offer boardband internet services to
approximately 117 thousand subscribers in Croatia.

_Telemach Slovenia_

Within Slovenia, in a large portion of our cable footprint, our competitors offer DSL services offered by
competitors, and not fiber, enabling us to provide the fastest broadband speed available within those areas.
Our EuroDOCSIS 3.0 enabled network allows us to compete effectively in the remainder of our cable
footprint, which is covered by our competitors’FttH network as it can match speeds offered by FttH operators
in these overbuilt areas. We only offer broadband in Slovenia as part of a double, triple, or quad-play package
with our cable pay-TV subscriptions. We offer our subscribers several for broadband internet service options,
varying in price according to download capacity and speed, and range from a minimum download speed of
50 Mbps to a maximum speed of up to 1,000 Mbps. As of March 31, 2021, Telemach Slovenia provided
broadband internet to approximately 189 thousand subscribers.

For the three months ended March 31, 2021, Telemach Slovenia’s broadband internet business generated
revenues of €11.2 million and an ARPU of €18.2.

According to Fitch Solutions, in 2018, the total broadband market (which includes cable, FttH, DSL and
other subscribers) in Slovenia was estimated at 613 thousand subscribers compared to 189 thousand
subscribers for Telemach Slovenia (including ADSL subscribers) as of March 31, 2021, which we believe
represents significant growth potential in the broadband market in Slovenia.

In 2018, cable-based broadband accounted for 29% of the broadband services in Slovenia based on number
of households, while FttH, DSL and others (which primarily includes wireless, Ethernet, LAD and fixed
wireless access) accounted for 71%. As of December 31, 2020, our total broadband market share in Slovenia


-----

was 31%. Our fixed broadband penetration in Slovenia was 54% as of December 31, 2020 (estimated). As of
December 31, 2020, 96% of our customers in Slovenia received broadband speeds greater than 70 Mbps.

_Telemach BH_

Within Bosnia and Herzegovina, our subscribers benefit from our fully two way enabled and EuroDOCSIS

broadband internet services with our analog TV service. These internet services are available with various
download capacities and speeds and at varying price points. Higher broadband internet speeds are available
when our internet services are purchased as part of a bundle with our digital pay-TV as compared to the
internet services offered as a bundle with our analog pay-TV. As of March 31, 2021, we provided broadband
internet to approximately 169 thousand subscribers.

For the three months ended March 31, 2021, Telemach BH’s broadband internet business generated revenues
of €5.6 million and an ARPU of €9.5.

According to Fitch Solutions, in 2018, the total broadband market (which includes cable, FttH, DSL and
other subscribers) in Bosnia and Herzegovina was estimated at 694 thousand subscribers compared to
169 thousand subscribers for Telemach BH as of March 31, 2021, which we believe represents significant
growth potential in the broadband market in Bosnia and Herzegovina.

In 2018, cable-based broadband accounted for 33% of the broadband services in Bosnia and Herzegovina
based on number of households, while FttH, DSL and others (which primarily includes wireless, Ethernet,
LAD and fixed wireless access) accounted for 67%. As of December 31, 2020, our total broadband market
share in Bosnia and Herzegovina as of December 31, 2019 was 22%. Our fixed broadband penetration in
Bosnia and Herzegovina was 49% as of December 31, 2020. As of December 31, 2020, 85% of our customers
in Bosnia and Herzegovina received broadband speeds higher than 30 Mbps. While Bosnia and Herzegovina
is generally not yet making use of high-speed broadband higher than or equal to 30 Mbps, we believe Bosnia
and Herzegovina displays clear trends of acceleration.


-----

_Telemach MNE_

Within Montenegro, our subscribers benefit from a fully two way enabled and EuroDOCSIS 3.0 upgraded
network. We offer cable broadband internet in Montenegro to our existing TV customers primarily as part of
a multi-play package with our digital cable pay-TV.

For the three months ended March 31, 2021, Telemach MNE’s broadband internet business generated
revenues of €0.6 million and an ARPU of €8.3.

_Vivacom_

Vivacom provides an array of fixed broadband services over ADSL, VDSL and FTTx connections to both
residential and business customers in Bulgaria as well as other data services such as the sale of CPEs, VPN
and MAN services and associated complex solutions. All of Vivacom’s offerings include a variety of tariff
plans to suit each subscriber’s usage levels.

Vivacom has focused on the build out of its fiber network in targeted areas, the retention of its current ADSL
subscriber base and migration to VDSL and FTTx and seeks to provide customers with comprehensive after
sales services. Vivacom began its FTTx roll out in 2011 in Sofia and Varna and has since achieved significant
progress, with 1,292 thousand fiber homes passed as of March 31, 2021. As of December 31, 2020, United
Group’s total broadband market share in Bulgaria was 25%.

Vivacom maintains a disciplined approach to expanding its fiber network in carefully selected areas and
adhering to stringent project acceptance criteria. Vivacom believes its low build out costs are attributable to
its ownership of the telecom ducts and the low-cost of labor in Bulgaria, allowing for an attractive return on
investments in fiber. In addition, Vivacom bundles fixed-telephony and fixed broadband services, as its fixed
broadband plan requires a fixed-telephony subscription and includes a free Wi Fi modem.

For the three months ended March 31, 2021, Vivacom’s fixed broadband services generated revenues of
€14.2 million and an ARPU of €5.2. Vivacom had approximately 476 thousand fixed broadband subscribers
as of March 31, 2021.

**_Fixed-line Telephony_**

We offer fixed-line telephony services in Serbia, Slovenia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Bulgaria and Montenegro.
We intend to leverage on our existing customer base and our extensive network and high-quality pay-TV
content to cross-sell telephony products and bundled products to new and existing customers. Accordingly,
other than in Bulgaria, our fixed-line telephony services are only available to our existing cable pay-TV
customers. Through Forthnet, United Group also offers out-of-footprint telephony services (telephony
provided through a third-party network) across Greece.

According to Fitch Solutions, the total fixed-line telephony market in 2018 was estimated at 665 thousand
subscribers in Slovenia, 2,430 thousand subscribers in Serbia and 740 thousand subscribers in Bosnia and
Herzegovina. Since we had 191 thousand subscribers for Telemach Slovenia, 442 thousand subscribers for
SBB Serbia and 105 thousand subscribers for Telemach BH, each as of March 31, 2021, we believe there is
significant growth potential in such broadband markets. In Bulgaria, the total fixed-line telephony market in
2019 was estimated at 868 thousand subscribers (compared to 514 thousand subscribers for Vivacom as of
March 31, 2021). The total fixed-line telephony market in 2020 was estimated at 4,852 thousand subscribers
in Greece (compared to 536 thousand out-of-footprint subscribers for Forthnet as of March 31, 2021).

Our “Basic Package”in Serbia, Slovenia, Bosnia and Herzegovina and Montenegro offers free calls within the
Group network and only an analog touchtone phone is required to use our service. In addition to our Basic
Package, we offer our subscribers various other packages, which include free calls to customers of other
regional fixed-line telephony providers. Despite the relatively recent launch of our fixed-line telephony
operations in Serbia, we believe it is the second-largest provider of fixed-line telephony services in Serbia
behind the incumbent Telekom Srbija. We are the largest provider of fixed-line telephony operations in
Bulgaria through Vivacom.

As of March 31, 2021, we provided our fixed-line telephony services to 1,269 thousand subscribers (including
Vivacom). For the three months ended March 31, 2021, our fixed-line telephony services generated revenues
of €29.1 million and an ARPU of €4.3.


-----

**_Mobile-telephony_**

_Telemach Slovenia_

We provide mobile voice, messaging and data to consumers and small businesses on a contract and prepaid
basis, together with an attractive suite of fixed mobile convergence services in Slovenia, which we believe has
contributed to lower churn rates relative to our competitors. Since 2015, we have been the fastest growing
mobile operator in Slovenia following our acquisition of Tušmobil. As a result of consistent growth, as of
December 31, 2020, we hold a 24% market share in the Slovenian mobile market (as compared to 14% at the
end of 2015) and cross-sell mobile services to more than 50% of our fixed-telephony subscriber base. Our
growth over the last five years was largely underpinned by continuous investments in our mobile and fixedtelephony network. In August 2020, we received, for the second year in a row, the “Best in Test” award for
both our mobile and fixed-telephony network by Umlaut (formerly P3 Group), an independent research
agency. According to the Ipsos Brand Tracking Report 2017, our “top of mind” recognition as a mobile

Our mobile network provides coverage to almost all of Slovenia’s population through our extensive 2G/
3G/4G and as of June 2021 5G networks. Licenses for use of spectrum for 2G are valid through 2031, while
spectrum for 3G is valid through 2021 (5 MHz on the 2100 band), 2023 (another 5 MHz on the 2100 band)
and 2031 (5 MHz on the 900 band). In 2016, Telemach acquired additional spectrum in the 1800 MHz and
2100 MHz bands. This acquired spectrum allowed United Group to expand our 3G and 4G networks. Use of
frequencies in the LTE network currently includes 2x10 MHz in the 800 MHz spectrum band and 2x10 MHz
in 1800 MHz spectrum band (which is the key spectrum band used for LTE services). These licenses are valid
through 2029 (800 MHz) and 2031 (1800 MHz). We are capable of providing 4G (LTE) coverage to
approximately 99% of the Slovenian population and 4G+ (LTE-A) coverage to approximately 98% of the
Slovenian population. In addition, we have successfully tested and are rolling out next generation 5G networks
across our mobile-telephony footprint. In April 2021, Telemach Slovenia secured 15-year spectrum licenses in
Slovenia for 5G frequencies, and commenced deployment and commercial launch of 5G 3600 MHz in
Slovenia in June 2021.

As of March 31, 2021, we had 596 thousand subscribers for our post-paid and prepaid mobile services. During
each month of the first three months of 2021, Telemach Slovenia achieved 34% of gross additions in the
mobile market, as compared to 32% during each month of 2020 and 31% during each month of 2019. Our
principal focus is post-paid subscribers, who generate significantly higher ARPU and generally have lower


-----

churn rates than prepaid subscribers, and as of March 31, 2021, contract subscribers accounted for 83% of
our subscriber base. According to Fitch Solutions, in 2018, the total mobile-telephony market in Slovenia was
estimated at 2.5 million subscribers compared to 596 thousand subscribers for Telemach Slovenia as of
March 31, 2021, which we believe represents significant growth potential in the mobile-telephony market in
Slovenia.

In April 2017, we updated our mobile packages, with more data, more calls and more text messaging, and
introduced our UNIFI Travel Wi Fi roaming application, providing access to more than 70 million Wi Fi
hotspots around the world. All products include free on net calls with unlimited off net national calls in
medium and high end packages, and with the introduction of new EU roaming regulations which took effect
on June 15, 2017, customers can now utilize their text message and voice minute allotments across the EU
with no roaming charges.

For the three months ended March 31, 2021, Telemach Slovenia’s mobile-telephony services generated
revenues of €21.3 million and an ARPU of €10.9.

_Telemach Croatia_

We provide mobile-telephony services in Croatia through Telemach Croatia, the third largest
telecommunications operator in Croatia based on mobile revenues as of December 31, 2020, after Croatian
Telekom and A1. In the post-paid mobile segment, Telemach Croatia seeks to offer the best value proposition
in the Croatian mobile market, for example through its offering of unlimited mobile services.

Telemach Croatia has an extensive 2G/3G/4G mobile network covering all major cities and important roads
in Croatia. In February and March 2019, Telemach Croatia acquired 2100 MHz and 2600 MHz frequencies,
enhancing spectrum capacity. Telemach Croatia is participating in a 5G spectrum auction in Croatia this year.

For the three months ended March 31, 2021, our mobile-telephony services in Croatia generated revenues of
€32.2 million and an ARPU of €12.1.

_Vivacom_

Vivacom is among the market leaders in offering mobile services in Bulgaria. Vivacom offers mobile voice
and data services and products over GSM/GPRS/EDGE and UMTS/HSPA+/LTE networks, on either a
post-paid or pre-paid basis, through multiple volume based and flat rate offerings, each with multiple tariff
options, and we believe that Vivacom’s mobile post-paid offerings are some of the most comprehensive in the
Bulgarian telecommunications market. Vivacom offers other mobile services and products, including the sale
of mobile handsets and accessories. Such services include unlimited mobile data, roaming voice and mobile
data packages (within the European Union or within neighboring countries), SMS and MMS and
international calls to both fixed and mobile lines. In all of its post-paid tariffs, Vivacom bundles mobile TV
services under the TV GO brand with over 90 channels, as well as music streaming (Tidal) and cloud storage
with mobile subscriptions. In addition, all of Vivacom’s customers have access to a digital wallet (Pay by
VIVACOM) that is currently free of charge. On September 21, 2020, we announced the commercial launch of
our 5G network in Bulgaria, and to that end in May 2021, we secured a 20-year license for 100 MHz spectrum
frequencies in the 3.6 GHz band.

Vivacom is also a leading provider of a full suite of telecommunications solutions for the corporate segment,
with a portfolio of services suitable for all business sizes. All business mobile plans include national and
international minutes, mobile data and a range of other features that support companies in running their
businesses. For large business customers, the approach is to offer customized services tailored to their specific
needs. For small and medium sized companies, we offer more standardized products, such as all-inclusive
tariff plans that have a set amount of minutes (national and international) and data for a fixed monthly fee.

For the three months ended March 31, 2021, Vivacom’s mobile operations generated revenues of €64.0 million,
representing 49% of its total revenue in the same period. Vivacom had approximately 3.0 million mobile
subscribers as of March 31, 2021, of which approximately 88% were post-paid subscribers and approximately
12% were pre-paid subscribers. For the three months ended March 31, 2021, blended mobile ARPU was €7.3.

**_United Media_**

Through focused and consistent investment over the last few years, and by a combination of our investment in
developing owned pay-TV content and in entering into strategic partnerships with regional and international


-----

third-party content owners, we have built a comprehensive content offering, covering sports, movies, news
and children’s content.

_Owned Content Business_

Through our owned-content business we directly own many of the region’s popular pay-TV channels. In 2006,
we acquired Sport Klub, the most popular sports channels in the region, and in 2012, we added Cinemania, a
popular movie channel, to our content portfolio. We strive to continually improve these offerings. For example,
in collaboration with notable studios in the United States, we have improved Cinemania’s movie content helping
to establish Cinemania as a leading movie channel in the region. We have also continued to improve the content
we offer through our leading Sport Klub channel by adding popular sporting events to its content portfolio. We
have introduced localized feeds for Sport Klub channels, in both HD and SD. Furthermore, we organize and
produce eSports events, which we broadcasts via Fortuna eSports. In April 2017, we acquired Fight Channel, a
Croatian channel with premium content focused on Ultimate Fighting Championship, and IDJ Digital Holding
Limited, a digital distributor of music and online video content in Malta.

In 2014, we launched N1, an independent 24/7 regional news channel affiliated with CNN, with studios in
Belgrade, Zagreb and Sarajevo and a large network of reporters and journalists reporting on regional events,
and which is now available to subscribers in all of United Group’s geographic markets. In addition, we have
sold distribution rights for this channel to all major operators in the region. In 2020, we signed an exclusive
partnership with NewsMax International and launched NewsMax Adria, a 24/7 cable news channel. Since
the beginning of 2015, we have utilized our majority stake in Grand Production, a leading Serbian music and
TV production house with a long history of broadcasting popular shows in Serbia, Bosnia and Herzegovina
and North Macedonia (formerly Macedonia) to introduce a 24/7 local music and entertainment channel
called Grand. In 2016, we launched the Grand 2 channel, expanding our music channels portfolio with new
content offered to our subscribers. In March 2021, we completed the acquisition of the remaining 49% of
Grand Production.

We have also been successful in broadening the distribution reach of our other pay-TV channels. For example,
during 2015, we sold distribution rights for N1 and certain Grand Production channels to other major cable
operators in the region. We have extended the distribution scope for Orlando Kids and Bambino (which have
been rebranded as Pikaboo and Vavoom, respectively), popular channels geared towards children that
complement our Ultra family of pay-TV channels, to include Bosnia and Herzegovina, North Macedonia,
Montenegro and Serbia, as well as Croatia and Slovenia, where those offerings were already present. We have
also increased revenues from our Sport Klub channels by successfully extending our existing contracts with
third-party pay-TV distributors while maintaining access to premium content. We have also extended the
production of the most popular entertainment shows for national TV stations in Serbia, Bosnia and
Herzegovina, Croatia, and North Macedonia, such as Your Face Sounds Familiar, Grand Stars, Never too
Late and Practical Woman, which became among the most watched shows in their respective markets.

In July 2018, we acquired Nova Croatia that features several popular television channels in Croatia. We believe
this acquisition will help us to create a strong mainstream media platform that will further differentiate our
distribution platform, promote our pay-TV channel portfolio, drive continued growth and create a strong
platform for additional bolt-on, accretive acquisitions.

In September 2018, we acquired Direct Media, a leading media-buying agency in Serbia, enabling us to deliver
targeted solutions to advertisers, for both television (national and pay-TV) and digital, product placements
and sponsorships. The transaction included Direct Media’s operations in Serbia, Montenegro, North
Macedonia (formerly Macedonia) and Albania, as well as the company’s terrestrial TV stations Pink BiH and
Pink Montenegro. In October 2018, we rebranded these channels as Nova BH and Nova M, respectively, to
facilitate synergies with the existing brand equity of Nova in Croatia.

In March 2019, we launched Nova S in Serbia, a channel fully exclusive to our SBB Serbia, Total TV and
EON platforms. Nova S offers high-quality, locally produced series as well as sports and talk shows. Recently,
we have significantly increased viewership in most of our channels, particularly Nova S, which has become
one of the most popular TV channels in Serbia.

In January 2021, we acquired Nova Broadcasting Group, Bulgaria’s largest multi-platform media company,
which operates 10 television channels, including Nova TV, and Bulgaria’s largest online platform. Forthnet
also produces its own media and content for the Greek market.

We believe that the attractiveness of our content platform across key pay-TV genres supports the sustainable
leadership position of our distribution platform. While a significant part of our content business’s revenue


-----

consists of carriage fees charged to our own distribution platforms (Telemach Slovenia, SBB Serbia, Telemach
BH and Total TV), we also generate revenues through carriage fees paid by third-party distribution platforms,
such as Telekom Slovenije, Hrvatski Telekom, T2 and A1 (formerly Si.Mobil), sales of advertising and the
sublicensing of some of the sports rights we acquire to regional free-to-air broadcasters or to TV operators in
Kosovo, where the Group does not have any operations.

Our Sport Klub sports TV channels are by far the most in-demand channels of its content business, followed
by N1 and Nova S.

The variety that we offer in our content business allows us to tailor our approach for each individual country
and market in which we operate. We plan to continue to review our content offering and will continue to
develop our own distinctive content. We continue to view content differentiation as the cornerstone of our
strategy and to drive the attractiveness of our content offerings relative to those of our competitors.

_Third-party Content_

In addition to our owned content offerings, our pay-TV distribution platforms typically license the rights for
the distribution of our channels, as well as third-party owned channels, typically for a period of three to
five years.

As the prominent pan-regional operator, we have been able to negotiate contracts with third-party providers
that we believe are beneficial. For example, we have been able to lock in flat-rate contracts for content that
provide for terms spanning multiple years, which benefits our profit margins as our number of subscribers
increases because we are able to retain the benefits of increases in our subscriber base, and thereby increase
our margins. We also pay royalties based on our subscribers’ usage of our VoD content. We generally pay such
license fees on a “per subscriber”basis. For on-demand content purchased by subscribers (transactional VoD),
we generally pay a revenue share of the retail price. For packaged on-demand content, we pay on a “persubscriber”basis (subscription VoD), often subject to fixed minimum guarantees. If necessary, we also license
third-party copyrights through various collective rights associations. We generally seek to negotiate fixed-fee
contracts and attempt to move away from per- subscriber agreements. We expect that our content costs (above
the minimum amounts) will generally increase in line with increased revenues from digital pay-TV and ondemand content and continued investment in high-quality content to differentiate our platform from our
competitors. We negotiate our contracts for content and other third-party rights on a Group-wide basis, so
that we are able to maximize the benefits of our scale and best practices across the Group, and we have
historically been successful at renewing these contracts on comparable terms. We plan to acquire additional
broadcasting rights in the future to further enhance our content offering.
