achieved by the security interest thereon being notified by the debtor and the acceptance thereof by the
debtor of such claims.

Absent perfection, the holder of the security interest may have difficulty enforcing his/its rights in the collateral
with regard to third parties, including a trustee in bankruptcy and other creditors who claim a security interest
in the same collateral. Finally, since the ranking of pledges is determined by the date on which they became
enforceable against third parties, a security interest created on a later date over the same collateral, but which
come into force for third parties earlier (by way of registration in the appropriate register or by notification)
has priority.

**_Luxembourg Guarantee Considerations_**

The Law 1915 does not provide for rules governing the ability of a Luxembourg company to guarantee the
indebtedness of another entity of the same group. A company may give a guarantee provided the giving of the
guarantee is covered by the company’s corporate purpose, corporate benefit and is in the best interest of the
company. Although no statutory definition of corporate benefit (intérêt social) exists under Luxembourg law,
corporate benefit is widely interpreted and includes any transactions from which the company derives a direct
or indirect economic or commercial benefit in return (such as an economic or commercial benefit) and whether
the benefit is proportionate to the burden of the assistance. It is generally held that within a group of
companies, the corporate interest of each individual corporate entity can include, to a certain extent, the
interest of the group, and that the existence of a group interest can in certain cases result in the guarantee
being held enforceable even where corporate benefit is not established. In this way, reciprocal assistance from
one group company to another does not necessarily conflict with the interest of the assisting company.
However, this assistance must be temporary, in proportion to the real financial means of the assisting company
(i.e., limited to an aggregate amount not exceeding the assisting company’s own funds (capitaux propres)), the
company must receive some benefit or there must be a balance between the respective commitments of all the
affiliates and the companies involved must form part of a genuine group operating under a common strategy
aimed at a common objective. As a result, the guarantees/security interests granted by a Luxembourg company
may be subject to limitations in order to ensure their enforceability. Further, a guarantee or security interest
that substantially exceeds the guarantor’s or security provider’s ability to meet its obligations to the beneficiary
of the guarantee/security provider and to its other creditors, or from which the Luxembourg company derives
no or very limited direct benefit in return, or where no direct or indirect consideration is granted to the
company in exchange, would expose its directors or managers to personal liability. In addition to any criminal
and civil liability incurred by the directors or managers of the Luxembourg company, in extreme circumstances
the guarantee or security interest could itself be held unenforceable, if it is held that it is contrary to public
policy (ordre public), in the case of facts consisting of a misuse of corporate assets. Any guarantee granted in
connection with the New Notes by Luxembourg companies may be limited to a certain percentage of, among
others, the relevant company’s net worth. The Indenture provides for general limitation language to the effect
that each guarantee granted therein and each security interest granted as well as any other obligation, liability
or indemnification under a security document will be limited to the maximum amount that can be guaranteed/
secured by the relevant guarantor/security provider with respect to the aggregate obligations and exposure of
the guarantor/security provider without rendering the relevant guarantee/security interest voidable or
otherwise ineffective under Luxembourg and other applicable law. If one or more of these laws and defenses


-----

are applicable, a Guarantor may have no liability or decreased liability under its guarantee or the security
documents to which it is a party.

**Bulgaria**

**_Overview of limitations_**

The validity, binding effect and enforceability of guarantees/security interests granted by Bulgarian guarantors
may be limited or otherwise be affected by the applicable stabilization or insolvency proceedings against the
Bulgarian guarantors, avoidance or similar laws of general application relating to or affecting the enforcement
of creditors’ rights and remedies, as well as financial assistance prohibitions. These are reviewed in turn below.

**_Stabilization Proceedings_**

As of 2017 Bulgarian law also provides for a pre-insolvency restructuring procedure called “stabilization
procedure.” It currently exists as an additional procedure to the traditional restructuring as a part of the
insolvency procedure, and it is similarly to the insolvency procedure a procedure, the main steps in which must
be sanctioned by a court. The stabilization procedure under the Bulgarian Commerce Act may be applied
when there is a “threat of insolvency” but where the debtor is still not insolvent. Actually, all court cases since
the inception of the new procure have been focused on whether the requirements for launching stabilization
were fulfilled and all publicly available judgments so far, the courts held that the debtor was actually insolvent
(in most cases over-indebted), so insolvency rather than stabilization procedure had to be opened. We are not
aware of any case where the new procedure was applied, and the debtor was successfully restructured to avoid
insolvency. In terms of substance, the stabilization procedure provides for a temporary standstill where all
court enforcement and out of court enforcement procedures (including those under special pledges) shall be
stopped. Further there are rules for partial cram down of the debtor’s liabilities. As of the date of this offering
memorandum, Bulgaria has not yet transposed Directive (EU) 2019/1023. Although a draft bill was published
on the webpage of the Bulgarian government on February 26, 2021, the legislative implementation process
that starts with a submission of a draft bill to the Bulgarian Parliament has not yet been commenced. In
addition, since following the parliamentary elections in Bulgaria that took place on April 4, 2021, no
government could be formed, new elections took place on July 11, 2021. The results of the new elections were
similar to those held in April 2021 and therefore there is uncertainty on whether a government will be formed.
As a result, there is a risk that the July 17, 2021 deadline for the implementation of Directive (EU) 2019/1023
in Bulgaria may not be met. However, this Directive is expected to be implemented approximately in the
second half of 2021. The exact timing for such implementation will depend on the formation and stability of
a new government.

**_Insolvency Proceedings_**

Should a Bulgarian guarantor have its “centre of main interests” (which is presumed to be the case due to
their incorporation in Bulgaria, unless something else is proven) they may be subject to Bulgarian insolvency
proceedings.

The insolvency proceedings do not affect out of court enforcement over Bulgarian special pledges, only if the
out of court enforcement was commenced before launching of the insolvency proceedings. Otherwise the
pledgee under a special pledge may only satisfy within the insolvency proceedings having a first-ranking
priority over the insolvency proceeds from the collateral.

A Bulgarian guarantor would be deemed insolvent in any of the following three cases occurs. The first case is
one of balance sheet insolvency (over indebtedness). When a creditor claims that a debtor is balance sheet
insolvent (as a ground for commencement of insolvency proceedings against the latter) it has to be established
that the debtor’s “liabilities exceed his assets.” All liabilities must be compared to all assets for the purpose.
This includes all existing liabilities including those that are not yet due (e.g. future payments under an existing
contract). Contingent (conditional) liabilities however are not covered. There is no formal requirement that
the negative balance for the purposes of over indebtedness should be substantial and though the dominating
understanding among scholars is that minor negative balance should not be taken into account where the
prospects for the entity are positive, it cannot be ruled out that even a minor negative balance may trigger over
indebtedness. The second case is the one of cash flow insolvency. This means a state of inability to pay: (i) a
monetary obligation under or in relation to a commercial transaction, or (ii) public law obligation towards the
State/municipalities connected with the commercial activity of the entity; or (iii) private law obligation towards
the State/municipalities. So, in the cash flow insolvency scenario a creditor must establish both: (i) the existence
of a particular payment obligation of any of the three types listed above that was due but was not paid


-----

(i.e.—the “First Condition”), and the inability of the debtor to pay (“Second Condition”). The First Condition
involves establishment of only factual matters. The Second Condition however requires again a comparison
between assets and liabilities of the debtor, although in a more limited manner (compared to the over
indebtedness scenario). In particular (according to the case law) in order to determine whether a debtor is
unable to pay, the ratio has to be established between the current/short-term assets (i.e. those that can be easily
turned into cash) vis à vis short-term liabilities (i.e. existing liabilities with a maturity of up to 1 year in the
future). If the ratio is below 1 (meaning that the short-term liabilities exceed the short-term assets), it is
normally presumed that the debtor is unable to pay (i.e. the Second Condition is met). The third case where
insolvency proceedings should be opened is the one of “concealed insolvency.” This means that an entity is
concealing commercial activity behind an insolvent entity, so if that is proven to be case insolvency proceedings
must be opened against the former.

In general, the opening of insolvency proceedings by a Bulgarian court does not result in the automatic
termination of contracts. However, the insolvency administrator may choose to terminate certain contracts as
to avoid the worsening of the financial condition of the company. Any power of attorney terminates upon
initiation of bankruptcy proceedings provided that the insolvency court has established that the debtor
jeopardizes the interests of creditors and that the debtor has been deprived of the right to manage and dispose
of the property of the company.

Insolvency proceedings may therefore have a material adverse effect on the relevant Vivacom Guarantor’s
business and assets and the Vivacom Guarantor’s respective obligations with respect to the New Notes.

**_Avoidance Claims_**

Within the insolvency proceedings certain Bulgarian avoidance rule may have to be considered. The general
claim that creditors may take recourse to, even if there is no insolvency is Actio Pauliana (павлов иск) under
art. 135 of the Obligations and Contracts Act. Under that claim a creditor may request that any act of the
Bulgarian guarantor/security provider having a detrimental effect on the creditor be declared void as against
the creditor, provided that the Bulgarian guarantor/security provider knew about that detrimental effect at the
time of performing the act. In the context of non-gratuitous acts, the plaintiff (creditor) must furthermore
prove that counterparty (creditor) to the Bulgarian guarantor/security provider also knew about the
detrimental effect of the challenged act on other creditors. This means proof that both the Bulgarian
guarantor/security provider and its counterparty knew there were other creditors having valid claims existing
before the challenged act and the act in question was detrimental to them. Pure knowledge is sufficient, it is
not necessary to prove that there was intention to inflict detrimental effect on the other creditors. However, if
the parties intend to defraud the other creditors it is not necessary as a prerequisite for the Actio Pauliana that
the respective creditor’s claim should have arisen before the challenged act. The detrimental effect for the
purposes of Actio Pauliana exists if the possibility for the creditor to satisfy himself from the Bulgarian
guarantor/security provider’s property is reduced, which means that via the challenged act created or increased
its state of inability to pay to other creditors.

In addition (subject to some technical exceptions) the following acts and transactions may be declared null
and void with respect to the insolvency creditors if made by the Bulgarian guarantor/security provider after
the initial date of insolvency or over indebtedness and cumulatively—within the timelines—under the
following items (i) (iii) before the submission of the application for opening of insolvency proceedings:
(i) performance of a monetary obligation that was not yet due (неизискуемо) regardless of the manner of
performance made within a one year period; (ii) performance of a monetary obligation that was due
(изискуемо) regardless of the manner of performance made within a six month period; and (iii) establishing
a pledge, mortgage or personal security (i.e. a guarantee) to secure a previously not secured obligation made
within a two year period.

In addition to other general statutory rules providing for setting aside of certain acts and transactions, the
following acts and transactions carried out by the debtor (within the timeline under items 1 3 below) before
the submission of the application for opening of insolvency proceedings may be set aside with respect to the
insolvency creditors: (i) establishment of a mortgage, pledge or personal security for another person’s debts,
effected within one year, but not earlier than the date of the insolvency or over indebtedness, as the case may
be; (ii) establishment of a mortgage, pledge or personal security for another person’s debts to the benefit of a
creditor, which is a related party to the debtor, effected within two years; (iii) a transaction that is detrimental
to the creditors, a party to which is a person related to the debtor, effected within two years; (iv) a transaction
where the consideration provided by the insolvent Bulgarian guarantor/security provider exceeds significantly
the consideration granted by its counterparty, effected within 2 years period before the submission of the
application for opening of insolvency proceedings but not earlier than the date when the Bulgarian guarantor/


-----

security provider was in a state of inability to pay or over indebtedness; (v) gratuitous transaction made
within a two year period (resp. three years if made to a related person).

Lastly, the following shall be considered null and void (in accordance with art. 646, par. 1 of the Bulgarian
Commerce Act (Търговски закон)) with respect to the insolvency creditors if carried out after the date of the
decision on opening of insolvency proceedings and in violation of the insolvency procedures: (i) performance
of an obligation that had occurred prior to the date of the decision on opening of insolvency proceedings;
(ii) establishing a pledge, or mortgage; (iii) transactions with rights or properties from the insolvency estate.

**_Limitations with respect to corporate benefit_**

Bulgarian law does not explicitly require the existence of a corporate benefit upon the grant of security for a
third-party debt. However, the grant of the SSN Guarantees and the security interests by the Vivacom SSN
Guarantors without benefit or obvious rationale for the Vivacom SSN Guarantors may be interpreted as an
act with a detrimental effect and thus subject to certain of the claims set forth in “Avoidance Claims” above,
such as: (i) actio pauliana (Павлов иск) within and outside of insolvency and (ii) insolvency avoidance claims
within insolvency.

**_Limitations to avoid overindebtedness_**

The obligations of the Vivacom SSN Guarantors are further limited to the extent that they result in (i) over
indebtedness (свръхзадлъжнялост) in the meaning of Article 742, paragraph 1 of the Bulgarian Commerce
Act (Търговски закон), promulgated in State Gazette No. 48/18.06.1991, effective July 1, 1991, as amended,
and (ii) a state of immediate threat of insolvency in the sense of Article 762, paragraph 1 (непосредствена
_опасност от неплатежоспособност) of the Bulgarian Commerce Act._

**_Limitations with respect to subordination arrangements_**

The subordination arrangements in the SSN Guarantees assumed by the Vivacom SSN Guarantors (see
“SSN Guarantees” above) may not be enforceable against third parties in case of enforcement proceedings
against the Vivacom SSN Guarantors in Bulgaria. There is still no court judgement in Bulgaria confirming
that the respective public or private bailiff (държавен или частен съдебен изпълнител) or insolvency
administrator (синдик) who would be in charge of the distribution among creditors should in case of such
arrangements disregard the statutory rules on ranking of creditors and apply instead the contractual
subordination arrangements. Certain academic scholars insist that subordination arrangements may not be
binding to any third-party different to those under the contract and would in particular would not bind the
respective public or private bailiff (държавен или частен съдебен изпълнител) or insolvency administrator
(синдик) as the procedural rules for creditors ranking are mandatory in nature.

**_Validity of guarantees in connection with litigation involving the Vivacom Group_**

The validity, binding effect and enforceability of guarantees and security interests granted by the Vivacom
SSN Guarantors may be limited or otherwise be affected by the litigation described in “Our Business—Legal
_Proceedings.”_

**_Use of Security Agent and Parallel Debt_**

Under Bulgarian law, security interests can be granted to a security trustee for the claims of all bondholders
only if the security trustee is a bank. Parallel debt arrangements governed by a foreign system of law are also
often used, mainly for credit agreements where the Bulgarian security trustee concept is not applicable.

We note that parallel debt structures governed by a foreign law under which such arrangements are valid and
enforceable have not yet been tested in Bulgarian courts.

**_Enforcement over Bulgarian Special Pledges—General Rules_**

Under Bulgarian law, depending on the type of security, certain perfection requirements as set forth below
must be satisfied in order for a security to become enforceable.

The following enforcement mechanisms are possible: (i) court execution over dematerialized shares in a joint
stock company (and sale) pursuant to the statutory provisions on execution and securing of claims (for which
a prior writ of execution is required); and (ii) out of court execution over dematerialized shares in a joint stock
company or shares (quotas) in a limited liability company through a private sale, pursuant to the currently


-----

effective legislation and as of January 2022 (unless extensions are introduced), are required to be carried out
under rules involving greater transparency and publicity than the existing rules, whereas the choice between
court or out of court execution is at the sole discretion of the pledgor.

Regarding collateral enforcement in this section only out of court enforcement of non-possessory special
pledges (over going concerns, shares in limited liability companies and joint stock companies) under Bulgarian
law will be considered. The term “out of court” refers to an extra judicial summary procedure for the seizure
and sale of the collateral (i.e., a procedure without court involvement), pursuant to the rules set out in the
Bulgarian Special Pledges Act. Under the Bulgarian Special Pledges Act, such out of court enforcement
(i) does not require a prior Bulgarian, or any other court judgment, arbitral award, writ of execution or other
judicial ruling; (ii) may be undertaken without acceleration of the New Notes for the amount outstanding and
payable under the New Notes at the date of enforcement; and (iii) may be carried out simultaneously,
independently and irrespective of any insolvency proceedings that may be opened with respect to the
Bulgarian guarantor/security provider. This out of court Collateral enforcement is in effect a “fast track”
recovery procedure irrespective of any other pending or contemplated actions or litigation proceedings.

The enforcement starts with a notification of the commencement of out of court pledge enforcement to the
Bulgarian Central Register of Special Pledges or another register depending on the type of collateral by the
Trustee, on behalf and at the direction of holders of the New Notes. This does not require the assistance or
the consent of the respective Bulgarian pledgor. The Trustee shall notify the respective pledgor of the
commencement of the out of court enforcement proceeding, specifying, amongst other information, the
nature of the default, the outstanding amount due and payable, and the collateral subject to sale. This
notification may be served on the pledgee immediately following the notification to the respective register.
Upon service of the above-mentioned notifications to the register and the applicable pledgor the Trustee is
entitled to take possession of the Collateral that is the subject of enforcement. In the event the pledgor refuses
to voluntarily surrender such Collateral, the Trustee may seek the intervention of and engage a bailiff (public
or private enforcement officer) at the expense of the pledgor. On the basis of a certificate from the register
confirming that enforcement has been initiated, such bailiff is entitled to force the pledgor to surrender the
collateral, with police assistance, as necessary. The collateral sale may occur after expiry of a 2 week grace
period from the notification to the register, to enable making voluntary payment before the collateral is sold.
During this grace period, the Trustee may nevertheless organize the collateral sale (take possession of the
collateral, engage the depository (as defined below), identify creditors, and so on). The collateral sale must be
undertaken by and in the name of the Trustee. The Trustee must make reasonable efforts to achieve the best
price for the collateral and there are some specific requirements to publicize the terms of the sale in advance
by registration with the register. The Trustee may engage the pledgee, assuming it is cooperative, as its agent to
manage the actual collateral sale process. The Trustee shall appoint a professional accountant or a bailiff (the
“Depository”) who will administer the proceeds collected from the collateral sale. Amongst other things, the
Depository shall (i) identify the creditors who have rights to the collateral that is subject to enforcement
(“Qualified Creditors”) and notify the Qualified Creditors, who have two weeks to comment, after which the
definitive list of Qualified Creditors is finalized and is not subject to challenge, (ii) open a special purpose
depository bank account in the name of the Depository for the collection of sale proceeds, (iii) provide
information on the contemplated distribution of proceed to the creditor(s) (which will be only the Trustee as
creditor on behalf of the Bondholders), and (iv) if there are no objections or challenges, distribute such
proceeds to the creditors (which will be only the Trustee as creditor on behalf of the Bondholders).

**_Specifics regarding Pledge over Shares in Joint Stock Companies (such as BTC) and Enforcement over such_**
**_Shares_**

Shares in a joint stock company, existing in a dematerialized form (such as the shares in BTC) may be pledged
under the Bulgarian Special Pledges Act. This requires an agreement in writing and registration with the
Bulgarian Central Depository which is the institution in whose databases dematerialized shares exist in a legal
form.

Enforcement over such shares requires respectively that the commencement of enforcement should be
registered with the Central Depository AD. The enforcement may take place by an out of court transfer of the
pledged shares so that the pledgee may satisfy the secured debt directly from its sale proceeds.

**_Specifics regarding Pledge over Shares in Limited Liability Companies (such as Viva Telecom and United_**
**_Group Bulgaria) and Enforcement over such Shares_**

Shares in a limited liability company (such as Viva Telecom and United Group Bulgaria) may be pledged
under the Bulgarian Special Pledges Act. This requires an agreement in writing with notarized signatures and


-----

registration with the Bulgarian Commerce Register. Enforcement over such shares requires respectively that
the commencement of enforcement should be registered with the Bulgarian Commerce Register.

The pledgee will be restricted in its options in case of enforcement only to enforcement through a liquidation
of the company the shares in which are pledged, and the pledgee may satisfy the secured debt only out of the
liquidation quota for the pledgor whose quota, in turn, may only be formed after voluntary liquidation
proceedings. In particular, the general possibility under the Bulgarian Special Pledges Act to sell the pledged
property out of court is inapplicable when it comes to enforcement over shares in a limited liability company.
The attempts of some lawyers nevertheless to effect such an enforcement sale of shares in a limited liability
company are regularly dismissed by the authorities in Bulgaria.

**_Bulgarian Guarantee Considerations_**

Except for bank guarantees, under Bulgarian law there are no provisions regulating abstract guarantees that
are independent of the novation or replacement of the guaranteed debt or of any changes to the creditors and
the debtors under the guaranteed debt. Thus, even if a guarantee is valid under the applicable law, the Vivacom
SSN Guarantors may oppose its validity based on certain Bulgarian law principles claiming that they are
rules of overriding nature that should be applied regardless of the foreign applicable law. Although the
overriding nature of the local rules has been confirmed by court practice with regard to certain of the
limitations set forth below, there is no conclusive case law evidencing that the remaining rules would not be
considered as overriding mandatory rules and/or rules of public policy. Such rules are as follows:

(i) a guarantee will terminate upon novation (including by way of change of the parties or replacement of
the debt) or transfer of the guaranteed debt, unless the relevant Bulgarian guarantor expressly agrees
that the guarantee extends to the novated or transferred obligations;

(ii) a Bulgarian guarantor will not be liable for any increased amount of the guaranteed debt, unless it has
expressly agreed to such liability, and the extension of maturity of the guaranteed debt in relation to the
debtor is not effective in relation to the Bulgarian guarantor, unless the Bulgarian guarantor has expressly
agreed to such extension;

(iii) a Bulgarian guarantor will not remain liable under the guarantee after the due date for repayment of the
debt, unless the creditor has claimed repayment from the principal debtor within six months as of that
repayment date; and

(iv) since under Bulgarian law a guarantee would be considered as an accessory personal security, the waiver
of the right to refer to the personal defenses of the respective debtor as well as to the set-off right of the
respective debtor may not be enforceable under mandatory Bulgarian law and therefore the Bulgarian
guarantor can avail itself of such personal defenses and set-off rights. For the same reason, the valid
existence and the scope of the guarantee depends on the valid existence and the scope of the guaranteed
debt.

**Stabilization**

The Stabilizing Manager may engage in over-allotment, stabilizing transactions and covering transactions in
accordance with Regulation M under the Exchange Act. Over-allotment involves sales in excess of the offering
size, which creates a short position for the Stabilizing Manager. Stabilizing transactions permit bidders to
purchase the underlying security so long as the stabilizing bids do not exceed a specified maximum. Covering


-----

transactions involve purchases of the New Notes in the open market after the distribution has been completed
in order to cover short positions.

The Stabilizing Manager is not required to engage in these activities, and may end these activities at any time.
Accordingly, no assurance can be given as to the liquidity of, or trading markets for, the New Notes. These
stabilizing transactions and covering transactions may cause the price of the New Notes to be higher than it
would otherwise be in the absence of these transactions.

**Short Positions**

In connection with the offering of the New Notes, the Initial Purchasers may purchase and sell the New Notes
in the open market. These transactions may include short sales, stabilizing transactions and purchases to
cover positions created by short sales. Short sales involve the sale by the Stabilizing Manager of a greater
number of Notes than they are required to purchase in the offering of the New Notes. Stabilizing transactions
consist of certain bids or purchases made for the purpose of preventing or retarding a decline in the market
price of the New Notes while the offering of the New Notes is in progress.

These activities by the Stabilizing Manager, as well as other purchases by the Initial Purchasers for their own
accounts, may stabilize, maintain or otherwise affect the market price of the New Notes. As a result, the price
of the New Notes may be higher than the price that otherwise might exist in the open market. If these activities
are commenced, they may be discontinued by the Initial Purchasers at any time. These transactions may be
effected in the over the counter market or otherwise.

Persons who purchase New Notes from the Initial Purchasers may be required to pay stamp duty, taxes, and
other charges in accordance with the laws and practice of the country of purchase in addition to the offering
price set forth on the cover page hereof.

**ENFORCEABILITY OF JUDGMENTS**

The Issuer is a Dutch company. The Guarantors are entities organized under the laws of the Netherlands,
Luxembourg, Bosnia and Herzegovina and Slovenia. The Vivacom Guarantors are entities organized under
the laws of Bulgaria. All the respective directors and executive officers of the Issuer and the Guarantors
reside outside of the United States. Substantially all of the assets of the Issuer and the Guarantors and their
respective directors and officers are located outside the United States. Although the Issuer and the Guarantors
have agreed, in accordance with the terms of the Indenture, to accept service of process in the United States
through agents designated for such purpose, it may not be possible for holders of the New Notes to (a) effect
service of process upon the Issuer, the Guarantors or their respective directors or officers, or (b) enforce
judgments of courts of the United States predicated upon the civil liability of such entities or persons under
the U.S. securities laws and state securities laws or other laws against any such entities or persons in the courts
of a foreign jurisdiction.

**The Netherlands**

The Issuer and the Dutch Guarantors are incorporated under Dutch law and have their registered seat in the
Netherlands. None of the directors of the Issuer or the Dutch Guarantors reside in the United States and a
substantial amount of the Issuer’s assets, and a substantial amount of the assets of the Dutch Guarantors are
located outside of the United States. Civil liabilities based on the securities laws of the United States may not
be enforceable in the Netherlands, either in an original action or in an action to enforce a judgment obtained
in U.S. courts.

The United States and the Netherlands currently do not have a treaty providing for the reciprocal recognition
and enforcement of judgments, other than arbitration awards, in civil and commercial matters. Consequently,
a final judgment for payment given by any court in the United States, whether or not predicated solely upon
U.S. securities laws, would not be enforceable in the Netherlands. In order to obtain a judgment which is
enforceable in the Netherlands, the claim must be re litigated before a competent Dutch court. A Dutch court
will, under current practice, generally confirm a final, conclusive and enforceable U.S. judgement without
substantive re-examination or re litigation on the merits if (a) that judgment results from proceedings
compatible with the Dutch concept of due process, (b) that judgment does not contravene public policy
(openbare orde) of the Netherlands, (c) the jurisdiction of the court has been based on an internationally
acceptable ground,(d) the judgment by the court is not incompatible with a judgment rendered between the
same parties by a Dutch court, or with an earlier judgment rendered between the same parties by a non-Dutch
court in a dispute that concerns the same subject and is based on the same cause, provided that the earlier
judgment qualifies for recognition in the Netherlands and (e) the judgment is—according to the laws of the
country of origin—formally capable of being enforced (e.g. is readily enforceable, has not been annulled in
appeal or its enforceability has not been subjected to a certain timeframe).

Subject to the foregoing and provided that service of process occurs in accordance with applicable treaties,
investors may be able to enforce in the Netherlands, judgments in civil and commercial matters obtained from
U.S. federal or state courts. However, no assurance can be given that such judgments will be enforceable. In
addition, it is doubtful whether a Dutch court would accept jurisdiction and impose civil liability in an original
action commenced in the Netherlands and predicated solely upon U.S. federal securities laws.

Any enforcement of agreements governed by foreign law and any foreign judgments in the Netherlands will be
subject to the rules of Dutch civil procedure. Judgments may be rendered in a foreign currency but
enforcement is executed in EUR at the applicable rate of exchange. Enforcement of obligations in the
Netherlands will be subject to the nature of the remedies available in the courts of the Netherlands. Under
certain circumstances, a Dutch court has the power to stay proceedings (aanhouden) or to declare that it has
no jurisdiction, if concurrent proceedings are being brought elsewhere.

A Dutch court may reduce the amount of damages granted by a U.S. court and recognize damages only to the
extent that they are necessary to compensate actual losses and damages.

**Slovenia**

The United States and Slovenia are not currently party to a treaty for the reciprocal recognition and
enforcement of judgments, other than arbitral awards rendered in accordance with the New York Convention.
Therefore, an enforceable judgment for the payment of monies rendered by a U.S. federal or state court based
on civil liability would not be directly enforceable in Slovenia. However, a valid and legally binding judgment
from a court of competent jurisdiction in the United States may be recognized and enforced by a court of


-----

competent jurisdiction in Slovenia, subject to compliance with the enforcement procedures set forth in
Articles 94 et seq. of the Slovenian Private International Law and Procedure Act (Zakon o mednarodnem
_zasebnem pravu in postopku). Following such recognition, judgments of non-Slovenian courts have the same_
status and legal effect as those issued by Slovenian courts.

The Slovenian courts will recognize a U.S. judgment if the judgment is legally binding in the United States
and provided that all of the following conditions are met:

- the matter does not fall within the exclusive jurisdiction of a Slovenian court;

- the jurisdiction of the U.S. court was not based solely on the citizenship of the plaintiff, the property of the
defendant in the United States or personal service of the claim to the defendant;

- the U.S. court did not ignore the parties’ agreement on jurisdiction of Slovenian court;

- a Slovenian court has not issued a legally binding decision on the same matter and no other foreign court
decision has been recognized in Slovenia (res iudicata) (and in case of lis pendens the recognition process is
on hold);

- the recognition of the U.S. judgment would not contravene the public policy of Slovenia (ordre public);

- reciprocity is established (reciprocity is presumed unless proven otherwise; additionally, absence of
reciprocity is irrelevant when recognition or enforcement of a decision by a foreign court is sought by a
Slovenian citizen); and

- there were no procedural irregularities in the proceedings before the U.S. court that prevented the party
against which the judgment was issued to take part in the procedure (no breach of due process rights).

Subject to the above conditions, Slovenian courts will not review the merits of the foreign judgment. Slovenian
courts also do not review whether the foreign court has acted in accordance with its own procedural laws—
any such issues have to be resolved through an appeal process in that foreign jurisdiction.

The request for recognition of a U.S. judgment must include the original judgment or a certified copy, a
certificate of finality of the judgment, and a certified translation of the judgment.

If, upon recognition of a U.S. judgment in Slovenia, an opposing party does not pay its debt voluntarily, a
request for enforcement of the judgment must be made. This request must include a certificate of enforceability
of the judgment under the applicable U.S. law.

The international competence of courts and the recognition and enforcement of judgments of competent
courts of a EU Member State (other than Slovenia) are governed by Council Regulation (EC) No. 1215/2012
of 12 December 2012 on jurisdiction and the recognition and enforcement of judgments in civil and
commercial matters. In accordance with this regulation, if a court or competent authority so requires in
connection with the recognition and the enforcement of a foreign judgment, a translation of the relevant
documents must be produced and the translation must be certified by a person qualified to do so in one of the
member states. A judgment may not be recognized if its recognition is manifestly contrary to public policy in
the Member State in which recognition is sought; where it was given in default of appearance, if the defendant
was not served with the document which instituted the proceedings or with an equivalent document in
sufficient time and in such a way as to enable him to arrange for his defense, unless the defendant failed to
commence proceedings to challenge the judgment when it was possible for him to do so; if it is irreconcilable
with a judgment given in a dispute between the same parties in the Member State in which recognition is
sought; if it is irreconcilable with an earlier judgment given in another Member State or in a third state
involving the same cause of action and between the same parties, provided that the earlier judgment fulfills
the conditions necessary for its recognition in the Member State addressed; or if it conflicts with Section 6 of
Chapter II of the regulation dealing with exclusive jurisdiction of the courts of Member States. Under no
circumstances may a foreign judgment be reviewed as to its substance.

In the event of any proceedings being brought in a Slovenian court in respect of a monetary obligation
expressed to be payable in a currency other than euro, a Slovenian court would have power to give judgment
expressed as an order to pay a currency other than euro. However, enforcement of the judgment against any
party in Slovenia would generally be available only in euro and for such purposes all claims or debts would be
converted into euro.

**Serbia**

Under the general conflict of laws rules, judgments of non-Serbian courts can be enforced in Serbia only if
they are recognized by a Serbian court.


-----

Recognition of a foreign judgment may be refused if:

- the respondent proves that it was not able to participate in the proceedings, particularly if it could not have
participated in the proceedings because there was no personal service of process;

- the court of Serbia, by virtue of Serbian Law, has exclusive jurisdiction in the relevant subject matter;

- a Serbian court or other official body has already passed or recognized a decision on the same subject
matter;

- the foreign judgment is found by the Serbian court to be contrary to the “foundations of social and political
order as determined in the Constitution” (i.e. public order);

- if a Serbian court establishes that there is no reciprocity in the matter of recognition and enforcement of
judgments rendered in commercial matters between Serbia and the home country of the judgment; and

- if the judgment is not final and conclusive (i.e. there are further appeals or revocation procedures or similar
actions have been commenced or are allowed).

From a procedural perspective, a foreign court judgment may be recognized (and further enforced) in Serbia
as part of a separate recognition procedure or as a preliminary question in the regular enforcement
proceedings.

Reciprocity is presumed until proven otherwise, and de facto reciprocity is sufficient. However, enforceability
of judgments of U.S. courts in Serbia cannot be confirmed. Serbia is not a party to any multilateral or bilateral
treaty pursuant to which the judgments of U.S. courts would be recognized and enforced, and it appears that
there are no cases that have established the principle of “factual reciprocity.”

Serbia is not a party to any multilateral or bilateral treaty pursuant to which the judgments of U.K. courts
would be recognized and enforced. However, U.K. court judgments can be recognized and enforced pursuant
to the general rules given above. Factual reciprocity between Serbia and the U.K. has been previously
confirmed by the Ministry of Justice but may be re-examined in a particular case if doubts exist as to its
continuing existence.

The party seeking recognition/enforcement must submit to the court:

- motion for recognition/enforcement;

- a confirmation by the foreign court that the foreign court’s judgment is final (i.e. that the judgment cannot
be appealed anymore) and enforceable between the parties under the law of the home country of the
judgment;

- the original judgment or its verified copy; and

- a verified Serbian translation of the judgment.

**Bosnia and Herzegovina**

Under the general conflict of laws rules, judgments of non-Bosnian courts can be enforced in Bosnia and
Herzegovina (“BiH”) only if they are recognized by a court in BiH.

Recognition of a foreign judgment may be refused if:

- the respondent proves that it was not able to participate in the proceedings due to procedural irregularities,
particularly if it could not have participated in the proceedings because there was no personal service of
process;

- the court of BiH, by virtue of law of BiH, has exclusive jurisdiction in the relevant subject matter;

- a BiH court or other official body has already passed or recognized a decision on the same subject matter;

- the foreign judgment is found by the BiH court to be contrary to the constitution or public policy of BiH;

- a BiH court establishes that there is no reciprocity in the matter of recognition and enforcement of
judgments passed in commercial matters between BiH and the foreign country in which the pertinent
judgment was passed; and

- if the decision is not final and conclusive (i.e. there are further appeals or revocation procedures or similar
actions have been commenced or are allowed).


-----

Reciprocity is presumed until proven otherwise. However, enforceability of judgments of U.S. or UK courts
in BiH cannot be confirmed. BiH is not a party to any multilateral or bilateral treaty pursuant to which the
judgments of U.S. or UK courts would be recognized and enforced, and it appears that there are no cases that
have established the principle of “factual reciprocity.”

**Luxembourg**

Each Luxembourg Guarantor is incorporated under the laws of Luxembourg and all of the managers and
executive officers of the Guarantors incorporated under the laws of Luxembourg are non-residents of the
United States. Furthermore, a substantial portion of the assets of each of the Guarantors incorporated under
the laws of Luxembourg is located outside the United States. As a result, it may not be possible for investors
to effect service of process within the United States upon the relevant Guarantors, or to enforce against any of
them judgments of U.S. courts predicated upon the civil liability provisions of U.S. federal or state securities
laws.

We have been advised by our Luxembourg counsel that the United States and Luxembourg are not currently
bound by a treaty providing for reciprocal recognition and enforcement of judgments, other than arbitral
awards rendered in civil and commercial matters. According to such counsel, an enforceable judgment for the
payment of monies rendered by any U.S. Federal or state court based on civil liability, whether or not
predicated solely upon the U.S. securities laws, would not directly be enforceable in Luxembourg. However, a
party who received such favorable judgment in a U.S. court may initiate enforcement proceedings in
Luxembourg (exequatur) by requesting enforcement of the U.S. judgment by the District Court (Tribunal
_d’Arrondissement) pursuant to Section 678 of the New Luxembourg Code of Civil Procedure. The District_
Court will authorize the enforcement in Luxembourg of the U.S. judgment if it is satisfied that all of the
following conditions are met:

- the U.S. judgment is final and enforceable (“exécutoire”) in the United States;

- the U.S. court awarding the judgment must have had jurisdiction to adjudicate the respective matter both
under applicable U.S. Federal or state jurisdictions rules, and under applicable Luxembourg international
private law conflict of jurisdiction rules and local law;

- the U.S. court has applied the substantive law as designated by Luxembourg conflict of laws rules, or at
least, the order must not contravene the principles underlying those rules;

- the U.S. judgment does not contravene international public policy or order as understood under the laws of
Luxembourg or has not been given in proceedings of a tax, penal or criminal nature (which would include
awards of damages made under civil liabilities provisions of the U.S. federal securities laws, or other laws, to
the extent that the same would be classified by Luxembourg courts as being of a penal or punitive nature
(for example, fines or punitive damages)). Ordinarily an award of monetary damages would not be
considered as a penalty, but if the monetary damages include punitive damages, such punitive damages
may be considered as a penalty;

- the U.S. court has acted in accordance with its own procedural laws;

- the judgment rendered by the U.S. court submitted to Luxembourg exequatur proceedings does not
contradict a judgment which has been rendered in the forum of the Luxembourg courts;

- the principles of fair trial and due process have been complied with and in particular the U.S. judgment was
granted following proceedings where the counterparty had the opportunity to appear, and if it appeared, to
present a defense; and

- the U.S. judgment was not granted pursuant to an evasion of Luxembourg law (“fraude à la loi
_luxembourgeoise”)._

Subject to the above conditions, Luxembourg courts tend not to review the merits of a foreign judgment,
although there is no statutory prohibition.

We have also been advised by our Luxembourg counsel that if an original action is brought in Luxembourg,
Luxembourg courts may refuse to apply the designated law (i) if the choice of such law was not made bona
fide and (ii) if its application contravenes Luxembourg public policy or is manifestly incompatible with
Luxembourg international policy rules. In an action brought in Luxembourg on the basis of U.S. federal or
state securities laws, Luxembourg courts may not have the requisite power to grant the remedies sought. Also,
an exequatur may be refused in respect of punitive damages.


-----

Further, in the event of any proceedings being brought in a Luxembourg court in respect of a monetary
obligation expressed to be payable in a currency other than Euro, a Luxembourg court would have power to
give judgment expressed as an order to pay a currency other than Euro. However, enforcement of the judgment
against any party in Luxembourg would be available only in Euro and for such purposes all claims or debts
would be converted into Euro.

**Bulgaria**

The United States and Bulgaria are not currently party to a treaty for the reciprocal recognition and
enforcement of judgments, other than arbitral awards rendered in accordance with the New York Convention.
However, a valid and legally binding judgment from a New York court may arguably be recognized and
enforced by a Bulgarian court under the general recognition and enforcement rules of the Bulgarian Private
International Law Code.

The rules under the Bulgarian Private International Law Code verbatim do not restrict the choice of court
arrangements to those of EU member states so it is arguable that choice of the courts of non-EU member
states are covered. However, an exclusive jurisdiction clause in favor of New York courts may be unenforceable
in Bulgaria due to art. 4, par. 1 of the Brussels Regulation (Recast) which provides that “subject to this
Regulation, persons domiciled in a Member State shall, whatever their nationality, be sued in the courts of
that Member State.” This rule may be interpreted as not permitting choice of courts arrangements different
from those under the Brussels Regulation (Recast) as EU Regulations are deemed to override any EU member
state national laws. We are not aware of any Bulgarian case law or case law of the Court of Justice of the
European Union that sheds light on how choice of New York courts arrangements should be treated. If and
as soon as the Hague Convention of 30 June 2005 on Choice of Court Agreements (which has been ratified by
the EU) will have been ratified by the United States (which is a signatory of this convention), this may change.

Subject to the above qualification, if it is accepted that the Brussels Regulation (Recast) is not an obstacle to
the application of the Bulgarian Private International Law Code, a New York court judgement may be
recognized and enforced if the following conditions are met:

(i) the New York court had jurisdiction according to the provisions of Bulgarian law, but not if the only
ground for the jurisdiction of the New York court over the dispute was the incorporation (nationality) of
the plaintiff in the jurisdiction of the seized court;

(ii) a copy of the statement of claim was served on the defendant, the parties were duly summonsed, and the
fundamental procedural principles of Bulgarian law, related to their defense have not been violated;

(iii) there is no Bulgarian court judgment in force based on the same facts, involving the same cause of action
and between the same parties;

(iv) there are no pending proceedings based on the same facts, involving the same cause of action and between
the same parties before a Bulgarian court, which has been brought earlier than the case instituted before
the New York court on which there is judgement whose recognition/enforcement is being sought;

(v) the recognition or enforcement is not contrary to Bulgarian public policy.

Regarding the first requirement for recognition/enforcement as listed above, i.e., competence of the New York
court under Bulgarian law, there is an express choice of court rule in the Private International Law Code
(applicable also to a choice of court in favor of non-EU member states) whereby the parties may choose via
agreement in writing a foreign (non-Bulgarian) jurisdiction in relation to proprietary matters provided that
the dispute does not fall within the exclusive jurisdiction of the Bulgarian courts. As the Brussels Regulation
(Recast) takes precedence over Bulgarian domestic private international law, a choice in favor of New Your
courts must furthermore not violate the exclusive jurisdiction of the courts of other member states if the
prerequisites for such exclusive jurisdiction exist under the EU Brussels Regulation (Recast).

The action for enforcement of a New York judgment must be brought before the Sofia City Court. Alongside
the statement of claim (i.e. the request for recognition and enforcement), the following documents must be
presented:

(i) a certified copy of the judgment, authenticated by the New York court, and

(ii) a certificate issued by the New York court, confirming that said judgment has entered into force.


-----

These documents must be certified in accordance with the Hague Convention Abolishing the Requirement of
Legalisation for Foreign Public Documents (i.e. the Apostille Convention) and translated into Bulgarian by a
translator certified by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Republic of Bulgaria.

The Sofia City Court must of its own motion establish the existence of the conditions for recognition/
enforcement listed above. The defendant in the proceedings for recognition or enforcement of a New York
judgement may not invoke violations of item (ii) of the list above if the defendant could have raised challenges
to such conditions before the New York court but failed to do so. In the recognition/enforcement proceedings,
the Bulgarian court would not examine the merits of the dispute as decided by the New York court.

The debtor may in the recognition/enforcement proceedings raise the defense that the obligation has been
extinguished on the basis of circumstances that have occurred after the New York judgement entered into
force. The debtor however may not raise the defense that the obligation has been extinguished as per the
preceding sentence if the Bulgarian judgment admitting enforcement has entered into force.

The judgment of the Sofia City Court in relation to the recognition of a New York court judgment is subject
to appeal before the Sofia Court of Appeals. The decision of the Sofia Court of Appeals is subject to appeal
before the Supreme Court of Cassation. The cassation procedure is conditional on the prior admission for
appeal and the party challenging the appellate judgment should provide evidence that the statutory grounds
for cassation are satisfied. The Supreme Court of Cassation grants the appellant a leave to appeal before
considering the cassation appeal on its merits. The cassation appeal to the Supreme Court of Cassation does
not suspend execution of the judgment of the appellate court. Thus, the judgment of the Sofia Court of
Appeals shall be enforceable and a party may initiate enforcement proceedings immediately after the judgment
of the appellate court.

**INDEPENDENT AUDITOR’S REPORT ON THE CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED INTERIM**
**FINANCIAL STATEMENTS**

### Report on Review of Condensed Consolidated Interim Financial Statements 

 to the Shareholders of Adria Midco B.V.

_Introduction_

We have reviewed the accompanying condensed consolidated interim statement of financial position
of Adria Midco B.V. and its subsidiaries (the ‘Group’) as of 31 March 2021 and the related condensed
consolidated interim statements of profit or loss and other comprehensive income for the three-month
ended 31 March 2021, changes in equity and cash flows for the three-month period ended 31 March
2021 and notes, comprising a summary of significant accounting policies and other explanatory notes.
Management is responsible for the preparation and presentation of this condensed consolidated
interim financial information in accordance with International Accounting Standard 34 – ‘Interim
_financial reporting’ as adopted by the European Union. Our responsibility is to express a conclusion_
on this condensed consolidated interim financial information based on our review.

_Scope of Review_

We conducted our review in accordance with International Standard on Review Engagements 2410,
‘Review of Interim Financial Information Performed by the Independent Auditor of the Entity’. A
review of interim financial information consists of making inquiries, primarily of persons responsible
for financial and accounting matters, and applying analytical and other review procedures. A review is
substantially less in scope than an audit conducted in accordance with International Standards on
Auditing and consequently does not enable us to obtain assurance that we would become aware of all
significant matters that might be identified in an audit. Accordingly, we do not express an audit
opinion.

_Conclusion_

Based on our review, nothing has come to our attention that causes us to believe that the
accompanying condensed consolidated interim financial statements are not prepared, in all material
respects, in accordance with International Accounting Standard 34 – ‘Interim financial reporting’ as
adopted by the European Union.

_Emphasis of Matter_

We draw attention to the note 2.1 which describes that these condensed consolidated financial
statements have been reissued for a reason of correction of disclosure in the note 3.2. Our conclusion
is not modified in respect of this matter.

**FINANCIAL STATEMENTS**

**In thousands of EUR unless otherwise stated**

**1.** **General information**

Adria Midco B.V. (the Company) is a company domiciled in Netherlands, registered on 3 October 2013.

The condensed consolidated interim financial statements of the Company for the period ended 31 March 2021
comprise the Company and its subsidiaries (together referred to as the “Group”). List of subsidiaries is
presented in the note 37.

The Group is one of the largest telecommunication operators in South East Europe providing video, data,
voice and mobile telephone services to residential and business subscribers. The Group has media activities
which fall into following categories: content production, distribution, advertising and digital. The Group’s
activities are mainly based in Serbia, Slovenia, Montenegro, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Macedonia, Croatia,
Bulgaria and Greece.

On 4 March 2019 Summer Bidco B.V., an entity controlled by Funds advised by BC Partners completed the
acquisition of majority ownership of the Group following the receipt of all necessary regulatory approvals.

**2.** **Basis of preparation**

**2.1.** **Statement of compliance**

These condensed consolidated interim financial statements for the three months period ended 31 March 2021
have been prepared in accordance with International Accounting Standard IAS 34 Interim Financial
Reporting as adopted by EU and should be read in conjunction with the Group’s last annual consolidated
financial statements as at 31 December 2020. They do not include all of the information for a full set of IFRS
financial statements. However, the selected explanatory notes are included to explain events and transactions
that are significant to an understanding of the changes in the Group’s financial position and performance
since the last annual financial statements. These consolidated interim financial statements are not statutory
consolidated financial statements and they are prepared for the purpose of providing information to owners
and providers of financing to the Group.

IFRS requires the management to adopt accounting policies that are the most appropriate to the Group’s
circumstances. These have been applied consistently to all the years presented, unless otherwise stated.

These condensed consolidated interim financial statements are reissued due to the correction of an error in
the disclosure of maturity of the Other financial liabilities—bonds, in the Note 3.2 in the condensed
consolidated interim financial statements dated on 21 May 2021. The condensed consolidated interim financial
statements were authorized for issue by the Board of Directors on 25 June 2021.

**2.2.** **Basis of measurement**

The condensed consolidated interim financial statements of the Group for the period ended 31 March 2021
have been prepared under the historical cost convention except for certain financial instruments, investment
property and assets held for sale.

**2.3.** **Going concern**

The Group has reported a net loss for the three-month period ended 31 March 2021 in the amount of
EUR 9,920 thousand (three-month period ended 31 March 2020: EUR 13,378 thousand) which is mainly
attributable to increase in finance cost due to additional bonds issued during 2020 and 2021 which were used
for the acquisition of VIVACOM Group, repay a portion of the amounts drawn under the Revolving Credit
Facility that were used to fund the purchase price for the Nova Broadcasting Group Acquisition and to pay
transaction costs associated with the bond offering (note 31).

The Group has reported a net loss for the three-month period ended 31 March 2020 in the amount of
EUR 13,378 thousand which was influenced by mainly by higher finance costs caused by issuing new bonds
(note 31).

**ADRIA MIDCO B.V. GROUP**

**NOTES TO THE CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED INTERIM**
**FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (continued)**

**In thousands of EUR unless otherwise stated**

**2.** **Basis of preparation (continued)**

The expansion of the Group is based on a leveraged buyout strategy resulting in an increased finance debt
and the associated net finance expenses. The Group’s key performance indicators are Adjusted Earnings
Before Interest, Tax, Depreciation and Amortization (Adjusted EBITDA) (see note 5 for definition). Adjusted
EBITDA for the three-month period ended 31 March 2021 has increased by 129% comparing to the same
period for the 2020. Significant increase in Adjusted EBITDA mainly is result of acquired companies
(notes 15, 21).

The Group regularly (daily and monthly) analyses liquidity projections, internal financial reports, availability
of financial assets and ability to repay its liabilities through daily and/or monthly review of budgeted and
actual cash flows and monitoring of maturity of the Group’s receivables and liabilities.

Primary sources of the Group’s liquidity and funds for capital expenditures, acquisitions and other
investments have been operating cash flows, revolving credit facilities, ancillary lending facilities and leases.
The Group has reported net cash inflow from operating activities in the amount of EUR 94,018 thousand for
the three-month period ended 31 March 2021. The Group was able to repay its obligations when they fell due
in the normal course of business with no defaults in repayment of debt, the associated financial interest
expenses nor any other liabilities. As at 31 March 2021, the Group has outstanding loans in the amount of
EUR 82,903 thousand and bond liabilities (including interest) in the amount of EUR 3,288,932 thousand
which matures from 2024 to 2028. In February 2020, the Group issued bonds in the amount of
EUR 1,675,000 thousand for the purpose of acquisition of BTC Group as well as early repayment of one
bond tranche and repayment part of the RCF. These bonds issuance is with maturity date in 2026 and 2028
(note 31). In November 2020, additional bonds were issued in the amount of EUR 400 million with maturity
in 2027 and in January 2021 additional EUR 150 million with the same maturity.

As at 31 March 2021 the Group has an undrawn revolving credit line in the amount of EUR 283,488 thousand
(31 December 2020: EUR 353,422 thousand) (note 31).

According to the Group’s business plan for 2021, the Group will continue to grow and expects increase in
Adjusted EBITDA, which will provide sufficient ground for financing debt, capital expenditures and working
capital.

The following further forms the basis of management’s use of going concern:

- The Group has grown its share of the telco and media market in the region.

- The Group maintains a high level of business ethics and regulatory compliance and there is no indication of
any foreseeable material adverse change in the regulatory landscape.

- The Group is complied with the covenants related to the listed bonds and senior credit facilities as at
31 March 2021 and expects to remain compliant with these covenants over the duration of the forecast
period (being for at least twelve months after the date of signing of the financial statements). See notes 4
and 31 for further details of the covenants.

Based on the Group’s going concern assessment, the condensed consolidated interim financial statements of
the Group for the period ended 31 March 2021 are, therefore, prepared on a going concern basis, as
management have a reasonable expectation that the Group has adequate resources to continue in operational
existence for the foreseeable future.

**2.4.** **COVID-19**

The existence of novel coronavirus (COVID-19) was confirmed in early 2020 and has spread rapidly from
mainland China across the globe, causing disruptions to businesses and economic activity and it continued to
shape its course in 2021.

Economic development over the coming months will depend on the spread of infection. Vaccines against
COVID-19 became available in December 2020 which substantially reduce the probability of infection.

The impact of this outbreak on macroeconomic forecasts and markets are incorporated into the Group’s
estimates of expected credit loss provisions for financial assets and other impairments assessments in 2021,
including but not limited to: Goodwill, Property, plant and equipment, Intangible assets and Programming
rights.

Management has reasonable expectations that the Group has adequate resources to continue in operational
existence for the foreseeable future. The results of management review of the Group’s market, operations and
financials in the past year and a forecast for at least twelve months after the date of signing of the financial
statements provides a sound basis for the appropriateness of using the going concern assumption in the
preparation of the Group’s financial statements for the period ended 31 March 2021, though the existence of
Coronavirus (COVID-19) means there is generally a level of uncertainty in the wider macro market.

Management concluded that the range of possible outcomes considered at arriving at this judgment does not
give rise to material uncertainties related to events or conditions that may cast significant doubt on the Group’s
ability to continue as a going concern for at least twelve months from the date of authorization of the financial
statements for issue.

**2.4.1.** **Revenues and Adjusted EBITDA**

There is positive impact to organic consolidated revenues in 2021 amounts of 1% comparing the same period
last year. The Group recorded decrease of 4% in organic Adjusted EBITDA comparing to the same period
2020 mainly as a negative impact of COVID-19 to its Media segment.

The Group’s telco segments have continued to meet customers’ expectations on service level and network
operating centre has maintained normal service levels. No significant change in customer database is
experienced during reporting period ended 31 March 2021. Negative effect of increase in bad debt and decline
in revenue from sale of handsets and roaming was mainly offset with decline in churn rate due to limitation in
direct sale to customers. At the same time, the Group has implemented cost savings measures such as: decrease
in travelling, representation and consulting costs.

In its Media segment (organic), external revenue decreased by 11% comparing to the same period previous
year as certain contract for carriage fee were not prolonged (expired as Covid-19 crisis has begun) and
currently are under further negotiations with customers, dominantly in Slovenia. This is the main reason for
decline in Adjusted EBITDA comparing to three months period ended 31 March 2021. Revenues streams of
media business which were mostly affected with the lockdown and state of emergency across the region, are
expected to be at pre-COVID19 level by the end of 2021 and to continuous growth is expected afterwards.

**2.4.2.** **Financing and liquidity**

The Group have sufficient cash reserves and cash generated for the forecast period to meet its financing
obligations. Net working capital is regularly monitored at each component level. During 2021 further measures
were applied by governments however, cash flow was stable during three months period ended 31 March 2021.
As at the date of this report, there is no adverse impact on cash flow.

Efforts have been made to keep collection of receivables at highest possible level which resulted in increased
net impairment of trade receivables in comparison to the same period previous year 52%
(e.g EUR 1.1 million), although the Group increased its revenue by 127% (e.g EUR 245 million) comparing to
same period 2021.

In February 2020 the Group issued bonds for the purpose of acquisition of VIVACOM Group and
refinancing part of existing debt by which interest rates decreased and maturity was extended until 2028. In
November 2020 and January 2021 issued bonds were issued for the purpose of repayment part of RCF as well
as acquisition of Nova Broadcasting Group (see note 31).

Currently available credit lines amount to EUR 283 million with extended maturity to 2025 (see note 31).

**2.5.** **Use of estimates and judgments**

The condensed consolidated interim financial statements of the Group for the period ended 31 March 2021
require management to make judgments, estimates and assumptions that affect the application of accounting
policies and the Group’s reported financial position, results or cash flows and disclosure of contingent assets
or liabilities during the reporting period. Actual outcomes could differ from those estimates.

Estimates and judgments are based on historical experience and other factors, including industry practices
and expectations of future events that are believed to be reasonable under the circumstances.

Estimates and underlying assumptions are reviewed on an on-going basis. Revisions to accounting estimates
are recognized in the period in which the estimates are revised and in any future periods affected.

The accounting estimates and judgements applied in these condensed consolidated interim financial
statements are the same as those applied in the Group’s consolidated financial statements as at and for the
year ended 31 December 2020.

**2.6.** **Functional and presentation currency**

These condensed consolidated interim financial statements are presented in Euros, which is the Company’s
functional currency. Items included in the financial statements of each of the Group’s entities are measured
using the currency of the primary economic environment in which the entity operates (“the functional
currency”).

Transactions in foreign currencies are translated to the respective functional currencies of Group entities at
exchange rates at the dates of the transactions. Monetary assets and liabilities denominated in foreign
currencies at the reporting date are translated to the functional currency at the exchange rate at that date.
Non-monetary assets and liabilities that are measured at fair value in a foreign currency are translated to the
functional currency at the exchange rate when the fair value was determined. Foreign currency differences are
recognized in consolidated statement of profit and loss and other comprehensive income. Non-monetary
items that are measured based on historical cost in a foreign currency are not translated.

Foreign exchange gains and losses resulting from the settlement of such transactions and from the translation
at year-end exchange rates of monetary assets and liabilities denominated in foreign currencies are recognized
in profit or loss and presented within finance costs.

**Foreign operations**

The results and financial position of all Group entities that have a functional currency different from the
presentation currency are translated into the presentation currency as follows:

- assets and liabilities are translated at the closing rate at the reporting date,

- income and expenses for each statement of profit or loss are translated at average exchange rates (unless
this average is not a reasonable approximation of the cumulative effect of the rates prevailing on the
transaction dates, in which case income and expenses are translated at the rate on the dates of transactions)
and,

- the translation adjustment resulting from the use of these different rates is included in other comprehensive
income

Goodwill and fair value adjustments arising on the acquisition of a foreign operation are treated as assets and
liabilities of the foreign operation and translated accordingly.

**2.7.** **Current or non-current classification**

Assets are classified as current in the condensed consolidated interim financial statements where recovery is
expected within 12 months of the reporting date. All assets where recovery is expected more than 12 months
from the reporting date and all deferred tax assets, goodwill and intangible assets, property, plant and
equipment and investments in associates and joint ventures are reported as non-current.

Liabilities are classified as current unless the Group has an unconditional right to defer settlement of the
liability for at least 12 months after the reporting date. For provisions, where the timing of settlement is
uncertain, amounts are classified as non-current where settlement is expected more than 12 months from the
reporting date. In addition, deferred tax liabilities and employment benefits are reported as non-current.

**2.8.** **New standards, amendments and interpretations to existing standards mandatory for the first time for the**
**financial year beginning on 1 January 2021**

The Group has applied the following standards and amendments for the first time for their annual reporting
period commencing 1 January 2021:

- Interest rate benchmark (IBOR) reform—phase 2 amendments to IFRS 9, IAS 39, IFRS 7, IFRS 4 and
IFRS 16,

- Amendments to IFRS 4 Insurance Contracts—deferral of IFRS19 (issued on 25 June 2020).

The amendments listed above did not have any impact on the amounts recognised in prior periods and are not
expected to significantly affect the current or future periods.

**2.9.** **Standards issued but not yet effective**

**2.10.** **Seasonality**

The Group operates in stable environment in all segments, except for Media segment, which has seasonality

- content operations of terrestrial TV stations, higher revenues and operating profits are usually expected in

these quarters.

**3.** **Financial risk management**

This note presents information about the Group’s objectives, policies and processes for measuring and
managing credit, liquidity and market risk. Also presents the exposure and sensitivity of the Group to these
risks.

There is no change of financial risk and financial risk management compared to consolidated financial
statements as at 31 December 2020.

The Group’s managing board has overall responsibility for the establishment and oversight of the Group’s
risk management framework, and development and monitoring of the Group’s risk management policies.

The Group’s risk management policies are established to identify and analyse the risks faced by the Group, to
set appropriate risk limits and controls, and to monitor risks and adherence to limits. Risk management
policies and systems are reviewed regularly to reflect changes in market conditions and the Group’s activities.
The Group, through its training and management standards and procedures, aims to maintain a disciplined
and constructive control environment in which all employees understand their roles and obligations.

The finance function monitors compliance with the Group’s risk management policies and procedures, and
provides top management with feedback regarding the performance of the framework in relation to the risk
faced by the Group.

**3.1.** **Credit risk**

Credit risk is the risk of financial loss to the Group if a customer or counterparty to a financial instrument
fails to meet its contractual obligations, and arises principally from the Group’s receivables from customers,
contract assets, cash and cash equivalents held at banks, loans and financial guarantees issued by the Group
and the indemnification asset.

**3.1.5.** **Cash and cash equivalents**

The Group holds cash in a number of banks in order to avoid concentration risk. A loss allowance in relation
to cash and cash equivalents is determined individually for each balance with a given financial institution. In
order to assess credit risk, external credit ratings and publicly available information on default rates for a
given rating of Standard & Poor’s rating agency were used. As all cash balances have a low credit risk as at the
reporting date and comparative period, the Group applied the practical expedient available under IFRS 9 and
determined the loss allowances based on 12-month expected credit losses. The calculation of the loss
allowances resulted in an immaterial amount.

The Group held cash and cash equivalents of EUR 166,041 thousand as 31 March 2021 (31 December 2020:
EUR 285,405 thousand) with reputable local commercial banks, which represents its maximum credit
exposure on these assets.

Management actively monitors credit risk exposure and given that the Group only has invested in bank
deposits management does not expect any counterparty to fail to meet its obligations.

**3.2.** **Liquidity risk**

Liquidity risk is the risk that the Group will encounter difficulty in meeting the obligations associated with its
financial liabilities that are settled by delivering cash or another financial asset. The Group’s approach to
managing liquidity is to ensure, as far as possible, that it will always have sufficient liquidity to meet its
liabilities when due, under both normal and stressed conditions, without incurring unacceptable losses or
risking damage to the Group’s reputation.

The Group’s policy on liquidity is to maintain sufficient liquid resources to meet its obligations as they fall
due, which has been achieved through appropriate bank arrangements (note 31). Typically, the Group seeks
to ensure that it has sufficient cash on demand to meet expected current liabilities as they fall due, including
the servicing of financial obligations; this excludes the potential impact of extreme circumstances that cannot
reasonably be predicted, such as natural disasters.

The Group has covenants relating to Revolving Credit Facility and bonds. Covenants relating to bonds are
active only when the Group decides to issue new bonds or refinance old one. Covenants relating to RCF are
monitored regularly (note 31).
