**7.** **Operating segments (continued)**

The following summary describes the operations in each of the Group’s reportable segments.

- Serbia Group includes cable operations in Serbia and DTH (satellite TV) operations in Macedonia. Satellite
operations in Macedonia account for minor part of the overall operations of Serbia Group segment,

- Bulgaria Group includes telecom operations in Bulgaria,

- Slovenia Group includes cable and DTH operations and mobile telephony services in Slovenia (note 23),

- Greece Group includes telecom and media operations in Greece (note 23),

- Bosnia Group includes cable and DTH operations in Bosnia and Herzegovina,

- Montenegro Group includes cable and DTH operations in Montenegro,

- Croatia Group includes mobile telephony services in Croatia (note 23),

- Media Group includes media (including advertising) and content operations in the region. This segment
includes the results of our media and content business in the former Yugoslav region including the results
of N1 Info, Grand Production, Orlando Kids, Nova TV, Nova M and Nova BH, as well as Direct Media.

- Other segments include our other operating business, such as Solford, Shoppster and non-operating holding
companies (United Group B.V., Adria Cable B.V., Adria Serbia Holdco B.V., Slovenia Broadband
S.A.R.L.). Revenue reported in other is mainly generated by Solford and Shoppster.

In 2020, the Group completed following acquisitions which represent separate segments:

- Telemach Hrvatska d.o.o., mobile operator in Croatia which represents separate segment Croatia Group.

- VIVACOM Group, telco operator in Bulgaria which represents Bulgaria Group.

- Forthnet Group, telco and media operator in Greece which represents Greece Group.

There were no changes in relation to composition of segments and measurement of segment profit/loss
comparing to consolidated financial statements for 2019.

Information regarding the results of each reportable segment is included below. Performance is measured
based on segment earnings before net finance cost, tax, depreciation and amortization (EBITDA) and
Adjusted EBITDA, as included in the internal management reports that are reviewed by the Group’s
management.

EBITDA is a supplemental measure of financial performance that is not required by, or presented in
accordance with IFRS. “EBITDA” is defined by the Group as Profit/(Loss) for the period plus income tax
(benefit)/expense, depreciation, amortization of intangible assets and net finance costs and share of profit/
loss of equity-accounted investee.

Adjusted EBITDA represents EBITDA adjusted for shareholder-related costs, legal and advisory—M&A
related costs, group restructuring costs, income from the disposal of companies, impairment charges for
obsolete equipment in Slovenia, other management-related costs, specific penalties, additional impact of
application of new standards (just for transitory period) and other non-core operating expenses, which Group
views as non-operating and not recurring to the operations of the Group (note 17).

Segment Adjusted EBITDA and Adjusted EBITDA (note 17) is used to measure performance as management
believes that such information is the most relevant in evaluating the results of certain segments relative to
other entities that operate within these industries.

**7.1. Description of products and services from which each reportable segment derives its revenue**

The Group’s main activities are providing of Video, Data, Voice and Mobile services to subscribers in the
countries of South-East Europe. The Group operates in Serbia, Greece, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Montenegro
and North Macedonia providing Video, Data and Voice services. In Slovenia and Bulgaria in addition to
Video, Data and Voice provides mobile phone services. In Croatia providing mobile phone services.

**NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (continued)**

**7.** **Operating segments (continued)**

Video service include provision of TV channel mix and IP Video streaming services, which is marketed into
basic, extended and premium packages. TV mix range from 60 to over 100 TV channels.

Data service comprise internet packages for residential and business customers, as well as various
supplementary services for business customers (connectivity and managed services, data centre and cloud
services).

Voice service relates to fixed line services to residential and business customers.

Mobile phone services relate to post-paid, prepaid, roaming and wholesale services provided to customers.

United Media is the leading media company in South East Europe, broadcasting more than 30 channels
available for terrestrial, cable, DTH, OTT and IPTV platforms. Content operations are driven by carriage fee
revenues which are coming from sales of pay-tv channel to cable operators across Adriatic region and
advertising revenue from both terrestrial TV stations and pay-TV stations. The Group is the owner of pay-tv
channels including flagship brands like “Sport Klub”, regional news channel ‘N1’, general entertainment
channel Nova S, movie channel “Cinemania”, children channels “Pikaboo” and “Vavoom” and music
channels “Grand” and “IDJ”, as well as terrestrial TV stations Nova TV and Doma TV in Croatia, Nova M
in Montenegro and Nova BH in Bosnia and Herzegovina. Recently, United Media started to invest heavily in
its digital portfolio, out of which the most prominent web portals are dnevnik.hr (number 1 portal in Croatia),
n1info.com and nova.rs. In addition to this, Direct Media group, a leading media-buying agency, provides
advertising and media services to companies in the region.

**7.2. Factors that management used to identify the reportable segments**

Most of the Group’s business segments are mainly based on the Group’s geographic regions, Serbia, Bulgaria,
Slovenia, Greece, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Croatia and Montenegro, and the other business segment is
broadly based on product distribution. They are managed separately because each business unit requires
different marketing strategies and service level.

**7.3. Measurement of operating segment profit or loss**

The CODM reviews financial information prepared based on IFRS adjusted to meet the requirements of
internal reporting. Such financial information differs in certain aspects from IFRS:

- Management consolidation adjustments can differ from the ones required by IFRS;

- non-IFRS profit measures (such as earnings before income tax, depreciation and amortization—EBITDA,
Adjusted EBITDA and Adjusted Capital Expenditure (Adjusted CAPEX)) are also included in the segment
report. Adjusted CAPEX represents purchases of tangible and intangible assets, consisting primarily of set
top box purchases and other customer capital expenditure, installations (including capitalized labour costs),
cable and mobile network build out, upgrades, maintenance and other investments, computer hardware
and software and content rights.

CODM evaluates performance of each segment based on revenue, Adjusted EBITDA, EBITDA and other
key performance indicators (e.g. average revenue per user, CAPEX) and does not regularly review assets and
liabilities of the segments.

**8.** **Revenue**

**Accounting policies**

The Group’s process for revenue recognition from multi-element contracts (e.g. mobile service and handset)
consists of:

     - assessment of all goods and services provided to the subscriber under the contract and identifying separate
performance obligations in that contract,

     - determining and allocating the transaction prices to separate performance obligations in the contract; the
allocation is based on the reference to their relative standalone selling prices that could be obtained if the
promised goods and services were sold individually in a separate transaction.

In determining the transaction price, the Group shall adjust the promised amount of consideration for the
effects of the time value of money if the timing of payments agreed to by the parties to the contract (either
explicitly or implicitly) provides the customer or the entity with a significant benefit of financing the transfer
of goods or services to the customer. In those circumstances, the contract contains a significant financing
component. However, based on the management analysis and considered factors noted in IFRS 15.61, at
present, the financing component is considered to be immaterial of handset and would not materially change
the amount of revenue that should be recognized in relation to a contract with a customer and thus, there is
no need to determine the present value of future cash flows from handset to calculate the initial value of the
contract asset. The Group will continue to monitor contract offerings and mobile business models.

**8.1. Subscription fee revenues**

Revenue from subscription services consists primarily of monthly fees paid by subscribers for provision of
telecommunication service. These revenues are recognized within the profit or loss in proportion to the length
service provided (subscription fee) over time in the period when related services are rendered.

The Group generates following main subscription-based service revenue streams which are recognized in the
period when the service is provided: Cable TV (CATV), Digital TV (D3), cable and fibre Internet service,
satellite TV (Direct to Home—DTH) and mobile telephony service.

Revenues from the rendered services relate to mobile services containing amounts charged to post-paid plan
customers for monthly service fees, which includes: voice, data and SMS.

Based on IFRS 15, revenue should follow performance and not timing of payment, as the Group has
obligation to provide service to the customer. The revenue is recognized over time and only to the extent of
provided service, and remaining of the consideration received is deferred. Mobile phone service is a “stand
ready obligation” and the obligation is satisfied by passage of time so the fixed monthly fee is spread straight
line over the time of the contract. The fee charged additionally for telephone conversation and SMS is a
variable consideration which is recognized as revenue when the even usage giving rise to such fee occurs.

Handsets subsidized represents a distinct performance obligation and realization of revenues to each
performance obligation on a relative stand-alone selling price basis is required. The subsidy of the hardware
leads to the recognition of a contract asset under IFRS 15. The total consideration allocated to this
performance obligation based on the relative stand- alone selling prices of performance obligations within
this contract and amount accrued at this point is recognised as contract asset. The IFRS 15 adjustment results
in revenue recognition from the sale of hardware at the contract inception and the recognition of contract
asset in the balance sheet. During the minimum contract duration (e.g. two years) contract asset is settled
from the monthly service fee paid by the customer.

The Group uses the practical expedient under IFRS 15 and recognizes fee from voice, data and SMS in the
amount to which the Group has a right to invoice.

**8.2. Carriage fees**

Carriage fee revenue relates to sales of pay-tv channel to other cable operators. The Group is the owner of
pay-tv channels including brands like “Sport Klub”, regional news channel ‘N1’, general entertainment
channel Nova S, movie channel “Cinemania”, children channels “Pikaboo” and “Vavoom” and music
channels “Grand” and “IDJ”, as well as terrestrial TV stations Nova TV and Doma TV in Croatia, Nova M
in Montenegro and Nova BH in Bosnia and Herzegovina.

Revenue is recognized over the time, depending on a contract, either on straight-line basis over the sales
contract period when the fixed fee is contracted or number of subscribers multiplied by agreed price per user.

**8.3. Advertising revenue**

Advertising revenue is derived primarily from broadcasting of advertising content and is recognized over the
time when the advertising is broadcast. Revenue is recognized in profit or loss in the amount due from

**8.4. Media selling**

Media selling revenue relates to selling of advertising space in any communication platform, such as
newspapers, magazines, outdoor billboards and screens, event sponsorship, commercial radio or television,
business information/data and online/digital. The Group acts as principal in media selling (note 6). Media
selling revenue is recognized over the time of providing the service. Please refer to note 6.1 for information on
critical estimates and judgements.

**8.5. Revenue from sale of end user equipment**

Revenue from sale of end user equipment is recognized at point in time when the control is transferred to the
buyer which usually is the moment when the customer obtains the end user equipment. End user equipment
mainly relates to handsets.

**8.6. Other revenue**

Other revenue mainly arises from lease of cable network and represents lease component accounted for under
IFRS 16, revenue from digital distribution, other media related service and other services from customers.

not directly attributable to the acquisition, construction or production of a qualifying asset are recognized in
profit or loss using the effective interest method.

**16. Income tax**

Income tax expense comprises current and deferred tax. It is recognized in profit or loss except to the extent
that it relates to items recognized directly in equity or in other comprehensive income.

Current tax is the expected tax payable or receivable on the taxable income or loss for the year, using tax rates
enacted or substantively enacted at the reporting date, and any adjustment to tax payable in respect of
previous years. Current tax payable also includes any tax liability arising from the declaration of dividends.

The Group applies IFRIC 23 in assessment of uncertain tax position. The Group determines whether to
consider each uncertain tax treatment separately or together with one or more other uncertain tax treatments
based on which approach better predicts the resolution of the uncertainty. In determining the approach that
better predicts the resolution of the uncertainty, an entity might consider, for example, (a) how it prepares its
income tax filings and supports tax treatments; or (b) how the entity expects the taxation authority to make its
examination and resolve issues that might arise from that examination.

In assessing whether and how an uncertain tax treatment affects the determination of taxable profit (tax loss),
tax bases, unused tax losses, unused tax credits and tax rates, the Group assumes that a taxation authority will
examine amounts it has a right to examine and have full knowledge of all related information when making
those examinations. When the Group concludes it is probable that the taxation authority will accept an

uncertain tax treatment, the entity shall determine the taxable profit (tax loss), tax bases, unused tax losses,

When the Group concludes it is not probable that the taxation authority will accept an uncertain tax
treatment, the Group reflects the effect of uncertainty in determining the related taxable profit (tax loss), tax
bases, unused tax losses, unused tax credits or tax rates. The Group reflects the effect of uncertainty for each
uncertain tax treatment by using either of the following methods, depending on which method the entity
expects to better predict the resolution of the uncertainty:

- the most likely amount—the single most likely amount in a range of possible outcomes. The most likely
amount may better predict the resolution of the uncertainty if the possible outcomes are binary or are
concentrated on one value.

- the expected value—the sum of the probability-weighted amounts in a range of possible outcomes. The
expected value may better predict the resolution of the uncertainty if there is a range of possible outcomes
that are neither binary nor concentrated on one value.

When uncertain tax treatment affects current tax and deferred tax (for example, if it affects both taxable
profit used to determine current tax and tax bases used to determine deferred tax), the Group makes consistent
judgements and estimates for both current tax and deferred tax.

SBB is eligible for investment incentives (tax holiday) according to Article 50a to 50i Serbian Corporate
Income Tax (CIT). For SBB this is a second use of this type of investment tax credit. The company met

applied for ten years. Start of investment in fixed assets for the second investment tax credit is 1 January 2016.
Each year the proportion for this investment needs to be calculated. Calculation of this percentage represent
the ratio of investment in fixed assets that meet requirements from Serbian CIT art 50a to 50i (certain assets

during the cumulative period) and total investment in fix assets (for period from 1 January 2016—according

**18. Property, plant and equipment**

**Accounting policies**

Property, plant and equipment comprise mainly cable network (coaxial and optical primary and secondary
network and backbone) and customer premise equipment (CPE—receivers and modems). Items of property,
plant and equipment are measured at cost less accumulated depreciation and accumulated impairment losses.

Cost includes expenditure that is directly attributable to the acquisition of the asset. The cost of selfconstructed assets includes the cost of materials and direct labour, any other costs directly attributable to
bringing the assets to a working condition for their intended use, the costs of dismantling and removing the
items and restoring the site on which they are located and capitalized borrowing costs. Purchased software
that is integral to the functionality of the related equipment is capitalized as part of that equipment.

When parts of an item of property, plant and equipment have different useful lives, they are accounted for as
separate items (major components) of property, plant and equipment.

The gain or loss on disposal of an item of property, plant and equipment is determined by comparing the
proceeds from disposal with the carrying amount of the property, plant and equipment, and is recognized net
within other income or other operating expenses in profit or loss.

**18. Property, plant and equipment (continued)**

**18.1.** **Subsequent costs**

Subsequent costs are included in the asset’s carrying amount or recognized as a separate asset, as appropriate,
only when it is probable that future economic benefits associated with the item will flow to the Group and the
cost of the item can be measured reliably. Cost of replacing major parts or components of property, plant and
equipment items are capitalised and depreciated over shorter of remaining useful life of an asset or period
until major part are replaced again. Cost of the replaced part is retired. All other repairs and maintenance are
recognized in profit or loss during the financial period in which they are incurred.

**18.2.** **Depreciation**

Depreciation is based on the depreciable amount of an asset. Significant components of individual assets are
assessed and if a component has a useful life that is different from the remainder of that asset, that component
is depreciated separately.

Depreciation is recognized in profit or loss on a straight-line basis over the estimated useful lives of each
component of an item of property, plant and equipment. The estimated useful lives for the current and
comparative periods are as follows:

**18.3.** **Impairment of property plant and equipment**

Property, plant and equipment are reviewed for impairment whenever events or changes in circumstances
indicate that the carrying amount may not be recoverable.

The impairment losses recognized in respect of property, plant and equipment may be reversed in a later
period if the recoverable amount becomes greater than the carrying value, within the limit of impairment
losses previously recognized. Impairment losses are recognized in the statement of profit or loss. Assets that
suffered impairment, are reviewed for possible reversal of the impairment at each reporting date.

**19. Goodwill**

**Accounting policies**

Goodwill represents the excess of the cost of an acquisition (as defined in the note 23) over the fair value of
the identifiable net assets of the acquired subsidiary at the date of acquisition. Goodwill is measured at cost
less accumulated impairment losses.

An impairment loss is recognized for the amount by which the asset’s or CGU’s carrying amount exceeds its
recoverable amount. The recoverable amount is the higher of an asset’s fair value less costs to sell and value in


-----

**ADRIA MIDCO B.V. GROUP**

**NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (continued)**

**In thousands of EUR unless otherwise stated**

**19. Goodwill (continued)**

use. This impairment test is performed to compare the recoverable amount of each Cash Generating Unit
(CGU) or, if necessary in cases of goodwill, CGU to the carrying value of the CGU (including goodwill, if
goodwill has been allocated to CGU or group of CGUs). A CGU is the smallest identifiable group of assets
that generates cash inflows that are largely independent of the cash inflows from other assets or groups of
assets.

The value in use of each asset or group of assets is determined as the discounted value of future cash flows
(Discounted Cash Flow method (DCF)) by using cash flow projections consistent with the budget of the
following year, the most recent forecasts prepared by the operating segments and long-term projections.

Applied discount rates are determined by reference to available external sources of information, usually based
on financial institutions’ benchmarks, and reflect the current assessment by the Group of the time value of
money and risks specific to each asset or group of assets. Perpetual growth rates used for the evaluation of
CGUs are those used to prepare budgets for each CGU or group of CGUs, and beyond the period covered,
are consistent with growth rates estimated by the business by extrapolating growth rates used in the budgets,
without exceeding the long-term average growth rate for the markets in which the group operates. The fair
value (less costs to sell) is the price that would be received from the sale of an asset or group of assets in an
orderly transaction between market participants at the measurement date, less costs to sell. These values are
generally determined on the basis of market data (stock market prices or comparison with similar listed
companies, with the value attributed to similar assets or companies in recent transactions) or, in the absence
of such data, on the basis of discontinued cash flows. If the recoverable amount is lower than the carrying
value of an asset or group of assets, an impairment loss equal to the difference is recognized in statement of
profit and loss. In the case of a group of assets, this impairment loss is first recorded against goodwill.
Impairment losses recognized in respect of goodwill cannot be reversed at a later date.

CGUs are independently defined at each business level, corresponding to the group operating segments. An
impairment test of goodwill is performed by the Group for each CGU or group of CGUs, depending on the
level at which management measures return on operations.

**Impairment testing for goodwill**

In 2021, the Group tested the value of goodwill allocated to its CGUs or groups of CGUs applying valuation
methods consistent with previous years. Results of an impairment test show that the recoverable amount of
CGU or groups of CGUs tested exceeded their carrying value (including goodwill), except for the Montenegro
Group where the impairment of EUR 890 was recognised. The recoverable amount is determined as the
higher of the value in use determined by the discounted value of future cash flows (Discounted Cash Flow
method (DCF)) and the fair value (less costs to sell), determined on the basis of market data (stock market
prices, comparable listed companies, comparison with the value attributed to similar assets or companies in
recent acquisition transactions).

(1) Weighted average cost of capital, calculated on post-tax basis

WACC is calculated as weighted average of post-tax cost of equity and post-tax cost of debt, using peer
groups’ capital structure as weights, betas used are post-tax and based on industry reports as of
31 December 2020 and leveraged by the debt margin taken from comparable companies. Assumptions used
for value-in-use calculations (refer to the above table) changed to reflect current business environment as more
information became available to the Group.

The cash flow projections included specific estimates for five years and a terminal growth rate thereafter,
except for Forthnet Group where extended period was included in order to normalize cash flows in years 2026
to 2030 to converge to profitability of the market participant within 5 years. The terminal growth rate was
determined based on management’s estimate of the long-term compound annual Adjusted EBITDA growth
rate, consistent with the assumptions that a market participant would make.

Budgeted Adjusted EBITDA was estimated considering past experience, adjusted as follows:

- Revenue growth was projected considering the growth levels over the past three years and market research
for the relevant markets, competitive environment and management strategy for the next five years.

- Corporate costs not included in individual CGU. Therefore, it shows the cash outflows from the continuing
use of the assets.

**Sensitivity analysis**

The management has identified that there are no reasonably possible changes in a key business and valuation
assumptions in Bulgaria Group, Serbia Group, Slovenia Group and Croatia Group which could cause the
carrying amount to exceed the recoverable amount.

For Greece Group, if WACC would increase for 1.5% carrying amount would exceed the recoverable amount
by EUR 11,447 thousand.

For Bosnia Group, if WACC would increase for 2% carrying amount would exceed the recoverable amount
by EUR 3,998 thousand.

For Media Group, if WACC would increase for 1.5% carrying amount would exceed the recoverable amount
by EUR 1,660 thousand.

**Accounting policies**

Intangible assets that are acquired by the Group and have finite useful lives are measured at cost less
accumulated amortization and accumulated impairment losses.

**20. Intangible assets (continued)**

Subsequent expenditure is capitalized only when satisfy the conditions for recognition as an asset. All other
expenditure, including expenditure on internally generated goodwill and brands, is recognized in profit or loss
as incurred.

**Trademarks**

Trademarks are acquired in a business combination, recognized at fair value at the acquisition date.
Trademarks are amortized over their useful lives.

Trademarks include following trade names: “SBB”, “Total TV”, “Telemach”, “Sport Klub”, “Nova TV”,
“Direct Media”, Vivacom and Nova (Greece).

**Customer relationships**

Customer relationships acquired in a business combination are recognized at fair value at the acquisition date.
The customer relations have a finite useful life and are carried at cost less accumulated amortization and
accumulated impairment losses.

**Radio frequency rights**

Property rights relates to rights to radio frequencies for mobile services. The company uses the cost model and
thus manages intangible assets at their purchase values less depreciation adjustments following the straightline amortization method. Any intangible assets that meet the conditions for recognition are valued at cost
upon initial recognition. Property rights are amortized in a period of 2–10 years.

Subsequent expenditure is capitalized only when satisfy the conditions for recognition as an asset. All other
expenditure, including expenditure on internally generated goodwill and brands, is recognized in profit or loss
as incurred.

**Computer software**

Costs associated with maintaining computer software are recognized as an expense as incurred. Software is
recognized at cost less accumulated amortization and accumulated impairment. Cost includes expenditure to
acquire software and directly attributable costs to prepare it for its intended use.

Development costs that are directly attributable to the design and testing of identifiable and unique software
products controlled by the Group are recognized as intangible assets when the relevant criteria are satisfied:

- the technical feasibility of completing the software so that it will be available for use or sale.

- its intention to complete the software and use or sell it.

- its ability to use or sell the software.

- how the software will generate probable future economic benefits

- the availability of adequate technical, financial and other resources to complete the development and to use
or sell the software.

- its ability to measure reliably the expenditure attributable to the software during its development.

Directly attributable costs, capitalized as part of the software product, includes software development
employee cost and appropriate portion of relevant overheads. Other development expenditures that do not
meet these criteria are recognized as an expense as incurred. Development costs previously recognized as an
expense are not recognized as an asset in a subsequent period. Computer software development costs
recognized as assets are amortized over their estimated useful lives.

**20. Intangible assets (continued)**

**Subscriber acquisition cost**

Subscriber acquisition costs include additional costs associated with entering into sales contracts with new
customers, for example commissions paid to internal or external sales personnel. Subscriber acquisition costs
are recognized only for costs that are incremental to obtaining the contract.

**Programming rights**

When entering into contracts for the acquisition of film, series, shows or sports events, the rights acquired are
classified as contractual commitments. The Group assesses each license agreement which span over period
longer than one year whether it meets definition of an intangible asset and recognition criteria. They are
recorded in the statement of financial position and classified as programming rights as follows:

- Programming rights for films and television series are recognized at cost when the program is available for
screening and are expensed over their broadcasting period.

- Sports rights are recognized at cost at the opening of the broadcasting period of the related sports season
start or contract date if season start is not defined in the contract itself. If the licence agreement spans over
more than one year, the Group will recognize programming rights only to the level of assets available for
broadcasting (e.g. one season).

- Own-produced programming rights are capitalized on the balance sheet at cost which are directly related to
the project being developed such as direct external development costs, allocated costs of employees and
development overhead pool directly attributable to preparing the asset for use and will be amortized based
on program viewership forecast method

Advance payments for acquired programming assets, prior to licence begin date, are recognized as
prepayments for programming assets.

Signed and binding contracts for purchase of programming, which do not meet recognition criteria for
programming assets are not recognized in the balance sheet and are instead disclosed as contractual
commitments in the amount of the outstanding contract liability at the reporting date.

**Amortization**

Amortization is based on the depreciable amount of an asset and is calculated using straight-line method
(except for own-produced programming rights, see below) to allocate their cost over their estimated useful
lives.

The amortization charge for programming rights for each period are recognized in profit or loss statement as

**Impairment of intangible assets**

Intangible assets are reviewed for impairment whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that the
carrying amount may not be recoverable.

The impairment losses recognized in respect of intangible assets may be reversed in a later period if the
recoverable amount becomes greater than the carrying value, within the limit of impairment losses previously
recognized. Impairment losses are recognized in the statement of profit or loss. Assets that suffered
impairment, are reviewed for possible reversal of the impairment at each reporting date.

**22. Right of use and lease liability**

The Group recognises new assets and liabilities for its operating leases of satellite, office facilities, part of
infrastructure, as well base stations and the right of use of a water and land surface.

**Accounting policies**

A contract is, or contains, a lease if the contract conveys a right to control the use of an identified asset for a
period of time in exchange of consideration.

Leases are recorded as a right-of-use asset and a corresponding liability at the date at which the leased asset is
available for use by the Group.

Assets and liabilities arising from a lease are initially measured on a present value basis.

Lease liabilities include the net present value of the following lease payments for the right of use the underlying
asset during the lease term:

- Fixed payments (including in-substance fixed payments), less any lease incentive receivable;

- Variable lease payment that are based on an index or a rate;

- Amounts expected to be payable by the lessee under residual value guarantees;

- The exercise price of a purchase option if the lessee is reasonably certain to exercise that option;

- Payment of penalties for terminating the lease, if the lease term reflects the lessee exercising that option.

The lease payments are discounted using the interest rate implicit in the lease, if that rate can be determined,
otherwise the Group’s incremental borrowing rate is applied. Weighted average incremental borrowing rates
used in 2020 was 5.2%.

There are recognition exemptions for short-term leases and leases of low-value items available on the voluntary
basis. The Group has elected to apply those exemption therefore the payments associated with all short-term
leases and leases of a low-value assets are recognised on a straight-line basis as an expense in profit or loss.
Short term leases are leases with a lease term of 12 months or less. Low-value assets comprise IT-equipment,
computers, mobile phones etc.

Right-of-use assets are measured initially comprising the following:

- The amount of the initial measurement of lease liability,

- Any lease payments made at or before the commencement date less any lease incentive received,

- Any initial direct costs,

- Restoration costs.

Subsequently, the right-of-use asset measured at cost less accumulated depreciation and accumulated
impairment losses, and adjusted for reassessment of the lease liability due to reassessment or lease
modifications. The right-of-use asset is depreciated over the shorter of the asset’s useful life and the lease term
on a straight-line basis.

**23. Business combinations**

**Accounting policies**

Business combinations are accounted for using the acquisition method. The cost of the business combination
is measured as the fair value of the aggregate consideration transferred, measured at acquisition date fair
value, fair value of any previously held interest and the amount of any non-controlling interest in the acquired
entity. For each business combination, any non-controlling interest in the acquired entity is measured either at
their proportionate share of the acquired entity’s identifiable net assets at the acquisition date or fair value.
Consideration transferred includes any contingent consideration measured at its acquisition date fair value.
The consideration transferred does not include amounts related to the settlement of pre-existing relationships.
Such amounts are generally recognized in the statement of comprehensive income.

Subsequent changes to the fair value of the contingent consideration which is deemed to be an asset or liability
will be recognized in accordance with IFRS 9 either in profit or loss or as a change to other comprehensive
income. Contingent consideration that qualifies for classification as equity is not re-measured until it is finally
settled. Acquisition costs incurred are expensed.

Any excess of the cost of the acquisition over the identifiable net assets acquired is recognized as goodwill in
the consolidated statement of financial position. If the cost is lower than the identifiable net assets acquired,
the difference is recognized in profit or loss.

**24. Inventories**

Inventories mainly comprise of mobile handsets, CPEs (Customer Premise Equipment—mainly modems and
receivers) designated for sale and television programming rights.

**Accounting policies**

Inventories are measured at the lower of cost and net realizable value. The cost of inventories includes the cost
of purchase, transport and expenses (including direct labour costs) incurred in bringing the inventory to its

**27. Contract assets and liabilities**

The contract assets arise mainly from:

- the sales of the subsidised handsets—the revenue is recognised when the customer obtains the handset
whereas the payment is obtained over the period for which the customer has committed the mobile services
which usually is two years.

- uneven payments relating to discounts provided to customers, including free services rendered for contract
commitments (e.g. free add-ons given to customers at contract inception for the duration unequal to
minimum contract duration (MCD)). This service is expected to be delivered the customer for the duration
agreed at contract inception and represents a dissimilar separate performance obligation which is not
delivered concurrently with main services throughout the MCD,

- services provided but not billed (accrued revenue at reporting date).The contract assets are transferred to
receivables when the rights become unconditional. This usually occurs when the Group issues an invoice to
the customer.

The contract liability is mainly recognised in relation to advertising, media selling, carriage fee and
subscription due to payments received at the inception of the contract whereas the revenue is recognised over
time.

**Accounting policies**

The Group’s contract assets are classified at amortised cost unless stated otherwise and are measured after
allowances for future expected credit losses (see note 4.1.3 for more information on credit risk).

**32. Provisions**

**Accounting policies**

A provision is a liability recognized in the statement of financial position, when the Group has a present
obligation (legal or constructive) as a result of past events; it is more likely than not that an outflow of
resources will be required to settle the obligation; and the amount can be reliably estimated. Provisions are not
recognized for future operating losses.

Provisions are measured at the managements’best estimate of the expenditure required to settle the obligation
at the reporting date and are discounted to present value where the effect is material. Where the timing of
settlement is uncertain amounts are classified as non-current where settlement is expected more than
12 months from the reporting date.

The main provisions the Group holds are related to decommissioning costs associated with mobile sites,
which include the cost of returning network infrastructure sites to their original condition at the end of the
lease and claims for legal and regulatory matter.

**32.1.** **Decommissioning**

A provision has been recognised for decommissioning costs associated with mobile sites. The provision has
been capitalized to the cost of the sites with the amount of the present value of the expected decommissioning
obligation after ceasing operation. The discount rates used for 2020 and 2019 were between 0.6% and 1.1%.
The associated cash outflows are substantially expected to occur at the dates of decommissioning of the
assets to which they relate, and are long term in nature.

**32.2.** **Legal and regulatory**

The Group is involved in a number of legal and other disputes, including notifications of possible claims. The
management, after taking legal advice, have established provisions after taking into accounts the facts of each
case. For a discussion of certain legal issues potentially affecting the Group see note 38.

**33. Borrowings and bonds**

**Accounting policies**

Loans and borrowings are recognised initially at fair value, net of transaction costs incurred, and are
subsequently carried at amortized cost using the effective interest method.

Transaction costs are incremental costs that are directly attributable to the acquisition, issue or disposal of a
financial instrument. An incremental cost is one that would not have been incurred if the transaction had not
taken place. Transaction costs include fees and commissions paid to agents (including employees acting as
selling agents), advisors, brokers and dealers, levies by regulatory agencies and securities exchanges, and
transfer taxes and duties. Transaction costs do not include debt premiums or discounts, financing costs or
internal administrative or holding costs.

The effective interest method is a method of allocating interest income or interest expense over the relevant
period, so as to achieve a constant periodic rate of interest (effective interest rate) on the carrying amount.


-----

**ADRIA MIDCO B.V. GROUP**

**NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (continued)**

**In thousands of EUR unless otherwise stated**

**33. Borrowings and bonds (continued)**

The effective interest rate is the rate that exactly discounts estimated future cash payments or receipts
(excluding future credit losses) through the expected life of the financial instrument or a shorter period, if
appropriate, to the gross carrying amount of the financial instrument. The effective interest rate discounts
cash flows of variable interest instruments to the next interest repricing date, except for the premium or
discount which reflects the credit spread over the floating rate specified in the instrument, or other variables
that are not reset to market rates. Such premiums or discounts are amortised over the whole expected life of
the instrument. The present value calculation includes all fees paid or received between parties to the contract
that are an integral part of the effective interest rate. For assets that are purchased or originated credit impaired
(“POCI”) at initial recognition, the effective interest rate is adjusted for credit risk, i.e. it is calculated based on
the expected cash flows on initial recognition instead of contractual payments.

Upon origination of the bonds and RCF, transaction costs were included in the financial liabilities recognized.
Interest expense recorded includes amortization of these transaction costs deferred at initial recognition to
maturity amount using the effective interest method. Amortized transaction costs are not presented separately
and is included in the carrying values of the borrowings (as a reducing item).

The Group does not have qualifying asset for capitalised borrowing costs, therefore no borrowing costs were
capitalized to the value of property, plant and equipment as at 31 December 2020.

33.1.1. Bonds

Bonds are rated by Moody’s forward view rated B2 and S&P Global rated B.

On 27 July 2017 the Group issued bonds in the nominal amount of EUR 1,350,000 thousand. Bonds were
issued in three tranches:

- First tranche in the nominal amount of EUR 575,000 thousand, bears interest rate of 4.375% p.a. and
matures on 1 July 2022. Interest is payable semi-annually on each 15 January and 15 July. Effective interest
rate of 4.778% is used for calculation of carrying values of bonds. This tranche was fully repaid on
6 February 2020. Due to early redemption option exercised in the February 2020, total amount of
EUR 12,587 thousand was recognized as finance expense in period ended 31 December 2019 (note 15).

- Second tranche in the nominal amount of EUR 325,000 thousand, bears interest rate of 4.875% p.a. and
matures on 1 July 2024. Interest is payable semi-annually on each 15 January and 15 July. Effective interest
rate of 5.224% is used for calculation of carrying values of bonds.

- Third tranche in the amount of EUR 450,000 thousand, bears floating rate of 3M Euribor+ 4.375% and
matures on 1 July 2023. Interest is payable quarterly on each 15 October, 15 January, 15 April and 15 July.
Third tranche was early repaid on 17 May 2019 with no impact on profit or loss.

**33.3.** **Loan covenants**

Based on the agreement for revolving credit facility, the Group is required to comply with a leverage ratio to
consolidated Adjusted EBITDA for the period most recent four consecutive financial quarters ending prior
to the date of determination of the ratio. Leverage ratio is calculated as aggregate outstanding indebtedness
of the Group and should not exceed ratio 9:1. Indebtedness is calculated as total financial liabilities decreased
by level of cash and cash equivalents as at reporting date. Satisfaction of the covenant is tested quarterly. The
Group has been in compliance with the above requirements as at and for the year ended 31 December 2020
and 31 December 2019, and to the date of issuance of this report.

**34. Deferred operating lease income**

**Accounting policies**

Deferred operating lease income refers mainly to network operating lease arrangements with mobile operators.

Deferred operating lease income is income for following periods that is received or cash received before services
are rendered.

Deferred operating lease income is income for which the customer is invoiced in advance of receiving the
service.

The amount earned within the next 12 months is classified as current, the amount earned after 12 months is
classified as long-term.

Income is recognized in profit and loss account when it has been earned.

**35. Deferred tax assets and liabilities**

**Accounting policies**

Deferred tax is recognized in respect of temporary differences between the carrying amounts of assets and
liabilities for financial reporting purposes and the amounts used for taxation purposes. Deferred tax is not
recognized for:

- temporary differences on the initial recognition of assets and liabilities in a transaction that is not a business
combination and that affects neither accounting nor taxable profit or loss,

- temporary differences related to investments in subsidiaries, associates and joint arrangements to the extent
that the Group is able to control the timing of the reversal of the temporary differences and it is probable
that they will not reverse in the foreseeable future; and


-----

**ADRIA MIDCO B.V. GROUP**

**NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (continued)**

**In thousands of EUR unless otherwise stated**

**35. Deferred tax assets and liabilities (continued)**

- taxable temporary differences arising on the initial recognition of goodwill.

Deferred tax assets are recognized for unused tax losses, unused tax credits and deductible temporary
differences to the extent that it is probable that future taxable profits will be available against which they can
be utilized. Deferred tax assets are reviewed at each reporting date and are reduced to the extent that it is no
longer probable that the related tax benefit will be realized.

Deferred tax is measured at the tax rates that are expected to be applied to temporary differences when they
reverse, based on the laws that have been enacted or substantively enacted by the reporting date.

Deferred tax assets and liabilities are offset if there is a legally enforceable right to offset current tax liabilities
and assets, and they relate to income taxes levied by the same tax authority on the same taxable entity, or on
different tax entities, but they intend to settle current tax liabilities and assets on a net basis or their tax assets
and liabilities will be realized simultaneously.

**37.5.** **Long Term Incentive Scheme**

On 16 May 2018, the shareholders of ultimate holding company, Adria Luxco S.a r.l. (Adria Luxco), entered
into a Long-Term Incentive Scheme (the “LTIS Agreement”) pursuant to which certain members of
management will be compensated in an amount determined by reference to the performance of the
shareholders of Adria Luxco in the event of any exit of their investment in Adria Luxco or Group by those
shareholders. The Agreement provided a platform for a reasonable expectation of the management to be
awarded based on the performance of the shareholders in the event of any exit of their investment in Adria
Luxco or the Group by those shareholders.

General Terms and Conditions of the LTIS Agreement included:

- an obligation of the shareholders of Adria Luxco, conditioned upon a predetermined accumulated return
on invested capital (measured by money-multiple and internal rate of return tests) in the event of any exit of
their investment in Adria Luxco or Group, to award a bonus payment to existing management of the
Group;

- the amount of the bonus payment calculated as a percentage of the proceeds received by the shareholders
of Adria Luxco and based on above mentioned accumulated return on invested capital achieved by such
shareholders;

- the payment of exit proceeds earmarked for the bonus payment is to be made by each shareholder to an

including the ultimate holding company Adria Luxco; no stock options or other derivative financial
instruments are part of the LTIS Agreement;

- no company in the Group, including the ultimate holding company Adria Luxco, has any obligation under
the LTIS Agreement to settle the bonus payment to the management. The LTIS is funded/settled in its
entirety by the Group’s external shareholders.

On 27 September 2018, Summer Bidco B.V., an entity controlled by Funds advised by BC Partners, entered
into a share purchase agreement (“SPA”) to acquire the entire share capital (excluding treasury shares) of
Adria Topco BV (the “Target”) from Adria Luxco S.a.r.l. (the “Seller”). The consummation of the Group
Acquisition pursuant to the Group Share Purchase Agreement which was subject to the satisfaction of certain
conditions, including clearance by competition authorities concluded on 4 March 2019. The consummation
of the Group acquisition represented an Exit under the LTIS Agreement.

The Group has recognized the effects of the LTIS Agreement in its consolidated financial statements for the
period ending 31 December 2019, as equity-settled Group Share-based payment transaction under IFRS 2—
Share-based payment—as LTIS Agreement is structured in a Group context where multiple Group entities
receive services from employees. It also provides the responsibility of shareholders to settle the bonus (sharebased payment) to employees who are providing services to several group companies.

The bonus amount under the LTIS Agreement at closing amounted to EUR 54,468 thousand, which relates
to the period of services provided from the LTIS Agreement signing to the grant date when all parties will
have shared understanding of key conditions pertaining LTIS Agreement. The service period ended
31 August 2019. The Group recognized in its consolidated financial statements for the period ending
30 September 2019 and 31 December 2019 related expense in the amount of EUR 21,659 thousand and
EUR 21,659 thousand, retrospectively which corresponds to the eligible managers’ period of service from
LTIS Agreement signing to the end of the reporting period.

From the perspective of the Group financial performance for the periods ending 30 September 2019 and
31 December 2019, the recognition of the transaction resulted in a lower reported net profit of the Group, in
the amount of EUR 21,659 thousand and EUR 21,659 thousand, retrospectively. The same amounts of
EUR 21,659 thousand and EUR 21,659 thousand, retrospectively, as guided by IFRS 2, the Group recognized
an increase in equity (Contribution from shareholder). The transaction is a non-cash, no recourse transaction
without an impact on the financial position of the Group.

**37.6.** **Additional payment**

In addition to the LTIS Agreement, the shareholders of Adria Luxco and management have agreed an
additional payment for 2019 in the amount of 49,9 million EUR. The amount of the additional payment was
not directly related to the value of the Company’s equity, or that of its ultimate parent, and was not paid in
securities, but was determined as a result of negotiations as a discretionary lump sum amount paid in cash to
the management at closing.

The Group believes that this additional payment could be regarded as a short-term employee benefit under
IAS 19, however, it is the Group’s accounting policy, where external shareholders have the obligation of
settling the payment for such benefits, without recourse from the Group, and absent an IFRS requirement,
not to attribute related expense to the consolidated financial statements.

**38.2.** **Legal cases in Serbia**

**Dispute with BS Group d.o.o., Brus in Regard to Producer’s Rights**

In 2016, BS GROUP DOO BRUS (“BS”) initiated legal proceedings against the Serbia Broadband—Srpske
kablovske mreže d.o.o. (SBB) before the Commercial Court in Serbia, claiming damages in the amount of
approximately EUR 25 million. BS claims that SBB violated BS’s producer rights in respect of certain of its
television series and films by broadcasting them outside of Serbia. SBB has responded to the claims.
Subsequently, a court expert report dated as of December 6, 2019, concluded that broadcasts had occurred
outside of Serbia. SBB submitted comments made by its own expert challenging the court expert’s report. The
Group assessed that it is not probable that this proceeding will result in a negative outcome that would
adversely impact on its financial position, therefore no provision has been recognised.

**Legal cases in Serbia—Beogradske Elektrane**

In September 2019, JKP Beogradske elektrane raised legal case against SBB. Subject of the dispute is
indemnity for using their infrastructure. Total value of dispute amounts to EUR 10,000 thousand. Plaintiff
also seek to impose an obligation on SBB Serbia to remove the network or to pay the Beogradske elektrane a
fee in the amount of EUR 100 million, which represents an amount designated by the Beogradske eletrane
and, as such, should not be directly enforceable against SBB as the payment thereof represents only an
alternative option for SBB Serbia to be allowed to maintain the network in case the court rules that the
network should be removed. The Group assessed that it is not probable that this proceeding will result in a
negative outcome that would adversely impact on its financial position, therefore no provision has been
recognised.

**38. Contingent liabilities (continued)**

**Unfair competition claims by Telekom Srbija**

In December 2020 and early 2021, Telekom Srbija started proceedings before the Belgrade Commercial Court
and Zurich Commercial Court against several entities belonging to the Group in relation to the alleged acts of
unfair competition against the plaintiff. In both proceedings Telekom Srbija argues that it suffered prejudice
as a result of defamatory statements allegedly made by the defendants in relation to Telekom Srbija’s business
operations.

In its proceedings before the Belgrade Commercial Court Telekom Srbija is suing SBB d.o.o., United Media
Digital d.o.o., Adria News S.à.r.l. and United Group B.V. and is claiming damages of approximately
EUR 80 million. In its proceedings before the Zurich Commercial Court the plaintiff is suing United Media
Network AG; United Group B.V., United Media S.à.r.l., and Adria News S.à.r.l. and is claiming damages of
approximately CHF 1.35 million.

The Group considers that both courts do not have jurisdiction to review these claims and that, in any event,
these claims are without merits and are not supported by any evidence. The proceedings before both courts
are ongoing.

**Investigation of Tax Authority in Serbia**

In investigation of Tax Authority in Serbia, which resulted in decision issued in March 2019 claiming that
recharacterized interest payments made by SBB Serbia under an intragroup loan agreement (and certain
other transactions) as dividends, which would have been subject to a 5% withholding tax. Ministry of Finance
accepted appeal and annulled the Tax Administration’s decision requiring SBB to pay approximately
EUR 21 million in additional taxes for the years 2012-2016. iThe decision now instructs the Tax
Administration to repeat the procedure taking into account SBBs arguments. No provision for this uncertain
tax position has been recognised as management has assessed that it is probable that it will sustain the tax
treatment applied by the Group.

**38.3.** **Legal cases in Slovenia**

**Administrative matters**

The award of 5 MHz on 2100 MHz spectrum frequency within its 3G licenses in 2008 to Tušmobil (now
Telemach Slovenia) is currently subject of judicial review before the Administrative Court against the decision
issued by the Slovenian Agency for Communication Networks and Services (“Agency”). In court, Telemach
Slovenia is challenging Agency’s decision of May 2019, by which the Agency in the renewed frequencies
allotment procedure has rejected Tušmobil’s request for allocation of said radiofrequencies and reversed its
allotment decision of 2008, coming into the effect as of 31 December 2019. Based on Telemach Slovenia’s
proposal, in June 2019, the Administrative Court issued an interim injunction and therewith stayed the
Agency’s decision of May 2019 until the court reaches a final decision on Telemach’s lawsuit against Agency’s
decision of May 2019. The procedure before the Administrative Court concerning the Telemach Slovenia’s
lawsuit is pending. Loss of the described frequency licence would lead to capacity reduction, which might
cause decrease in quality of service in certain areas. However, additional frequencies granted in 2016 (and
currently used by Telemach Slovenia) would support the Group to mitigate the impact of any potential loss of
3G frequencies due to a renewal of the licence allocation procedure or other revocation or impairment of the
3G license that was granted in 2008. In a spectrum auction that took place in April 2021, Telemach Slovenia
successfully bid for frequency bands.

**Disputes with SAZAS Relating to Infringement of Copyrights**

From 2012 onwards, the Slovenian Association of Composers and Authors (“SAZAS”) commenced many
legal proceedings against all cable operators in Slovenia (including Telemach Slovenia) claiming infringement
of copyrights and damages for the cable retransmission of musical works. SAZAS initiated numerous legal
proceedings against Telemach Slovenia claiming copyright remuneration for cable retransmission of music
works.

**38. Contingent liabilities (continued)**

The proceedings are in different stages, as the proceedings that began in 2012 are currently considered by the
Constitutional Court, while the proceedings that were initiated in 2020 are pending before either the first
instance court or the Higher Court. In all these cases, the Group filed legal means against the courts’decisions.
The procedures are pending.

On 4 March 2021, the Copyright Board issued its decision setting a tariff for the use of music works at
EUR 0.24 per subscriber per month for retransmission of up to 100 television and 60 radio channels, and
EUR 0.27 per subscriber per month for retransmission of more than 100 television and 60 radio channels.
The Group challenged the Copyright Board decision in court.

**Sport Klub Divestiture Ruling and Investigation of Alleged Abuse of Dominant Position**

In September 2018, the Slovenian Competition Protection Agency ruled that the Group’s acquisition of
United Media Distribution (then IKO Balkan) in 2012 is incompatible with competition rules. The Slovenian
Competition Protection Agency (hereinafter—the Agency) ordered the Group to divest the activity of
broadcasting Sport Klub (SK) TV channels within nine months and imposed a ban prohibiting the Group
from broadcasting sports TV channels in Slovenia for three years from the date of divestment (with the
exception of the existing Fight Channel).

In October 2018, the Slovenian Supreme Court issued our proposed interim injunction and stayed the
implementation of the Agency’s divestment decision until a final decision on the merits of this case has been
issued. The lawsuit against the divestment decision is pending. In addition, in a separate misdemeanour
proceeding a fine of up to a legal maximum of 10% of annual revenue of the Group could be imposed for each
of the next two breaches: (i) filing of concentration notification to the Agency with delay and (ii) breaching of
the stand still obligation.

In May 2019, the Agency issued decision on misdemeanour procedure by which financial fine in the amount
of EUR 3.7 million was imposed. The Group appealed against the decision and seek to annul or change
decision in order to abolish the financial fine or at least lower it. In January 2021, the Administrative court
ruled the fine in the amount of EUR 1.56 million. The Group appealed this ruling and requested a further
reduction in the amount of the fine.

In February 2015, the Slovenian Competition Protection Agency initiated a proceeding regarding the abuse
of dominant market position by United Media Limited, IKO Balkan (now United Media Distribution) and
its Slovenian subsidiary IKO Media PRO d.o.o. (former subsidiary of the IKO Balkan—liquidated in 2016) in
the wholesale market for the supply of pay TV sports channels in Slovenia for a period beginning around
August 2012. This proceeding is currently still in its initial stages as no statement of objections has been issued
by the Slovenian Competition Protection Agency. If the Agency in this procedure ruled that the dominant
position existed and was abused a fine of up to the legal maximum of 10% of annual revenue of the previously
described companies involved in the procedure could be imposed. The Group management, supported by its
legal advisors, at this point assessed that it is likely that fine could be imposed and that level of fine would not
have material adverse impact on its financial position.

**38.4.** **Legal cases in Bosnia**

**Minority shareholders of Kablovska Televizija HS d.o.o., HKB-net d.o.o.**

As a result of acquisition of subsidiaries in Bosnia, the Group assumed significant number of ongoing court
disputes. The disputes are initiated by the minority owners of companies Kablovska Televizija HS d.o.o. and
HKB-net d.o.o. which claimed compensation for damages and cancellation of a share purchase transaction.
The cases have been filed against majority owners of Kablovska Televizija HS d.o.o. and HKB-net d.o.o. for
breaching minority shareholders’ rights. The provisional quantum of indemnity sought by the minority
shareholders is up to EUR 12,200 thousand (including penalty interest rates and costs of the proceedings),
which is determined, according to the Group legal advisors, solely by plaintiffs. Based on the advice from legal
advisors, the Group management has set aside funds in escrow account for the purpose of settlement of cases.

**40. Subsequent events**

**40.1.** **Bonds issues**

On 26 January 2021, the Group issued additional notes in the aggregate amount of EUR 150,000 thousand
which matures on 15 November 2027, bears interest rate of 4%. These additional notes have the same
conditions as notes issued in November 2020. Interest is payable semi-annually on each 15 May and
15 November. Proceeds were used to repay a portion of the amounts drawn under the Revolving Credit
Facility that were used to fund the purchase price for the Nova Broadcasting Group Acquisition and to pay
transaction costs associated with the bond offering.

**40.2.** **Acquisition of Nova Broadcasting Group**

On 24 December 2020, the Group signed agreement to acquire 100% of stake in Bulgaria’s largest multiplatform media company Nova Broadcasting Group from Advance Media Group for consideration of
EUR 290,620 thousand. Nova Broadcasting Group comprises 10 TV channels, including national NOVA TV,
and the country’s largest online platform NetInfo, which reach on average 80% of the Bulgarian population
every month. It also operates four radio stations. The strong fit between Nova Broadcasting Group and the
Group’s other media operations gives the Group the opportunity to capture synergies and create scale that
will enable Group to further invest in local content that will delight customers.

The transaction was subject to customary regulatory approvals by the local competition authorities and was
closed on 22 January 2021.

Goodwill and all assets and liabilities has been measured provisionally, pending completion of an independent
valuation. As the result of the recognition of those intangible assets, the provisional amount of goodwill will
be significantly reduced. Goodwill on acquisition date will be allocated to the Media segment which represents
the lowest level at which it will be managed and monitored.

Significant part of goodwill will be allocated to brand name and property. Provisional goodwill on acquisition
date amount to EUR 1,226 thousand.

The acquisition related costs amount to EUR 97 thousand recognized in profit or loss in the line item Other
operating expense.

**40.4.** **Acquisition of minority interest in Forthnet Group**

On 27 January 2021 Hellenic Capital Market Commission (HCMC) approved Mandatory Tender Offer
(MTO). After expiration of defined term, the Group exercised its squeeze-out right to acquire the remaining
shares at MTO price. HCMC approved squeeze-out application of the Group. As of date of issuance of this
report, the Group has 99.4% of ownership in Forthnet.

**40.5.** **Other acquisitions**

On 17 February 2021 the Group concluded agreement to acquire remaining 49% of Grand Production d.o.o.
for the cash consideration of EUR 21,452 thousand. The transactions completed on 2 March 2021.

On 27 January 2021 the Group concluded agreement to acquire 100% of share capital of Bulgaria’s Vestnik
Telegraf EOOD newspaper business for cash consideration of EUR 6.8 million. The transaction closed on
23 March 2021.

In February 2021 BTC concluded agreement to acquire 100% of share capital of local internet and TV
operators Net 1 EOOD, ComNet Sofia EAD and Digital Cable Television OOD (N3). The transactions are
subject to relevant regulatory approvals, duly initiated and received on 15 April 2021. The deals are pending
finalization in the second quarter of 2021.

On 29 March 2021 the Group concluded agreement to acquire 100% of the share capital of the Serbian
transportation company D Express. This transaction, which is subject to all necessary approvals from the
relevant regulatory authorities, will provide infrastructure for further development of E-commerce business
as well as synergies through logistics. It is expected to close in the second quarter of 2021.

Considering the finalisation of the acquisition the disclosures required by IFRS 3 are not presented due to the
fact that the acquisition has not yet reached the stage when management can reliably disclose the details.

On 10 March 2021 the Group increased its stake in Multiplex Service BH d.o.o. to EUR 51 thousand
representing 50% of ownership.

The Group’s management holds that they are not aware of any other significant post balance sheet events that
could affect the consolidated financial statements for 31 December 2020 or require separate disclosure.

**Accounting policies**

A subsidiary is an entity controlled by the company. Control is achieved where the Company has existing
rights that give it the current ability to direct the activities that affect the Company’s returns and exposure or
rights to variable returns from the entity. The results of subsidiaries acquired or disposed of during the year
are included in the consolidated income statement from the effective date of acquisition or up to the effective
date of disposal, as appropriate. Where necessary, adjustments are made to the financial statements of
subsidiaries to bring their accounting policies into line with those used by the Group. All intra-group
transactions, balances, income and expenses are eliminated on consolidation.

Non-controlling interests in the net assets of consolidated subsidiaries are identified separately from the
Group’s equity therein. Non-controlling interests consist of the amount of those interests at the date of the
original business combination and the non-controlling shareholder’s share of changes in equity since the date
of the combination. Total comprehensive income is attributed to non-controlling interests even if this results
in the non-controlling interests having a deficit balance.

The Group applies the economic entity model to account for transactions with owners of non-controlling
interest in transactions that do not result in a loss of control. Any difference between the purchase
consideration and the carrying amount of non-controlling interest acquired is recorded as a capital transaction
directly in equity. The Group recognises the difference between sales consideration and the carrying amount
of non-controlling interest sold as a capital transaction in the statement of changes in equity.

**Independent Auditor’s Report**

To the Shareholders of Adria Midco BV

**Our opinion**
In our opinion, the consolidated financial statements present fairly, in all material respects, the consolidated
financial position of Adria Midco BV (the “Company”) and its subsidiaries (together—the “Group”) as at
31 December 2019, and its consolidated financial performance and its consolidated cash flows for the year
then ended in accordance with International Financial Reporting Standards as adopted by the European
Union.

**What we have audited**
The Group’s consolidated financial statements comprise:

- the consolidated statement of profit or loss and other comprehensive income for the year ended
31 December 2019;

- the consolidated statement of financial position as at 31 December 2019;

- the consolidated statement of changes in equity for the year then ended;

- the consolidated statement of cash flows for the year then ended; and

- the notes to the consolidated financial statements, which include significant accounting policies and other
explanatory information.

**Basis for opinion**
We conducted our audit in accordance with International Standards on Auditing (ISAs). Our responsibilities
under those standards are further described in the Auditor’s responsibilities for the audit of the consolidated
financial statements section of our report.
We believe that the audit evidence we have obtained is sufficient and appropriate to provide a basis for our
opinion.

**Independence**
We are independent of the Group in accordance with the International Ethics Standards Board for
Accountants’ Code of Ethics for Professional Accountants (IESBA Code). We have fulfilled our other ethical
responsibilities in accordance with the IESBA Code.

**Responsibilities of management and those charged with governance for the consolidated financial statements**
Management is responsible for the preparation and fair presentation of the consolidated financial statements
in accordance with International Financial Reporting Standards as adopted by the European Union, and for
such internal control as management determines is necessary to enable the preparation of consolidated
financial statements that are free from material misstatement, whether due to fraud or error.
In preparing the consolidated financial statements, management is responsible for assessing the Group’s ability
to continue as a going concern, disclosing, as applicable, matters related to going concern and using the going
concern basis of accounting unless management either intends to liquidate the Group or to cease operations,
or has no realistic alternative but to do so.
Those charged with governance are responsible for overseeing the Group’s financial reporting process.

**Auditor’s responsibilities for the audit of the consolidated financial statements**

Our objectives are to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the consolidated financial statements as a
whole are free from material misstatement, whether due to fraud or error, and to issue an auditor’s report that
includes our opinion. Reasonable assurance is a high level of assurance, but is not a guarantee that an audit
conducted in accordance with ISAs will always detect a material misstatement when it exists. Misstatements
can arise from fraud or error and are considered material if, individually or in the aggregate, they could
reasonably be expected to influence the economic decisions of users taken on the basis of these consolidated
financial statements.

As part of an audit in accordance with ISAs, we exercise professional judgment and maintain professional
scepticism throughout the audit. We also:

- Identify and assess the risks of material misstatement of the consolidated financial statements, whether due
to fraud or error, design and perform audit procedures responsive to those risks, and obtain audit evidence
that is sufficient and appropriate to provide a basis for our opinion. The risk of not detecting a material
misstatement resulting from fraud is higher than for one resulting from error, as fraud may involve collusion,
forgery, intentional omissions, misrepresentations, or the override of internal control.

- Obtain an understanding of internal control relevant to the audit in order to design audit procedures that
are appropriate in the circumstances, but not for the purpose of expressing an opinion on the effectiveness
of the Group’s internal control.

- Evaluate the appropriateness of accounting policies used and the reasonableness of accounting estimates
and related disclosures made by management.

- Conclude on the appropriateness of management’s use of the going concern basis of accounting and,
based on the audit evidence obtained, whether a material uncertainty exists related to events or conditions
that may cast significant doubt on the Group’s ability to continue as a going concern. If we conclude that a
material uncertainty exists, we are required to draw attention in our auditor’s report to the related
disclosures in the consolidated financial statements or, if such disclosures are inadequate, to modify our
opinion. Our conclusions are based on the audit evidence obtained up to the date of our auditor’s report.
However, future events or conditions may cause the Group to cease to continue as a going concern.

- Evaluate the overall presentation, structure and content of the consolidated financial statements, including
the disclosures, and whether the consolidated financial statements represent the underlying transactions
and events in a manner that achieves fair presentation.

- Obtain sufficient appropriate audit evidence regarding the financial information of the entities or business
activities within the Group to express an opinion on the consolidated financial statements. We are
responsible for the direction, supervision and performance of the Group audit. We remain solely responsible
for our audit opinion.

We communicate with those charged with governance regarding, among other matters, the planned scope and
timing of the audit and significant audit findings, including any significant deficiencies in internal control
that we identify during our audit.

**1. Reporting entity**

Adria Midco B.V. (the Company) is a company domiciled in Netherlands, registered on 3 October 2013.

The consolidated financial statements of the Company for the year ended 31 December 2019 comprise the
Company and its subsidiaries (together referred to as the “Group”).

The Group is one of the largest telecommunication operators in South East Europe providing video, data,
voice and mobile telephone services to residential and business subscribers. The Group has media activities
which fall into following categories: channel production, distribution, advertising and digital. The Group’s
activities are mainly based in Serbia, Slovenia, Montenegro, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Macedonia and
Croatia.

As at 31 December 2018, the parent company of the Group was Adria Topco B.V. Netherlands controlled by
Adria Luxco S.À.R.L. Luxembourg, private company, domiciled in Luxembourg. Adria Luxco S.À.R.L. is
an investee company owned in the majority by funds advised/managed by US private equity fund Kohlberg
Kravis Roberts & Co. L.P. (together with its affiliates, “KKR”).

On 4 March 2019 Summer Bidco B.V., an entity controlled by Funds advised by BC Partners completed the
acquisition of majority ownership of the Group following the receipt of all necessary regulatory approvals.

During the period the Group acquired 100% of shares in Netlogic d.o.o. Serbia, Skyline kabel d.o.o., FMC
datacenter d.o.o. (note 21). The new subsidiaries in 2019, apart from the acquired ones, are established by the
Group.

**2. Basis of preparation**

**a)** **Statement of compliance**

The consolidated financial statements of the Group have been prepared in accordance with International
Financial Reporting Standards (IFRSs), as adopted by the European Union (EU). The Group applied the
same accounting policies in the preparation of the financial data for the year ended 31 December 2019, except
for the EU-endorsed standards and interpretations which are effective for the reporting periods beginning on
or after 1 January 2019. These consolidated financial statements are not statutory consolidated financial
statements and they are prepared for the purpose of providing information to owners of the Group.

This is the first set of the Group’s consolidated financial statements where IFRS 16 has been applied. Changes
to significant accounting policies are described in note 4.

The consolidated financial statements were authorized for issue by the Board of Directors on 22 April 2020.

**b)** **Basis of measurement**

The consolidated financial statements have been prepared under the historical cost convention except for
derivative financial instruments and certain financial instruments.

**c)** **Going concern**

The Group has reported a net loss for the year ended 31 December 2019 in the amount of
EUR 60,036 thousand (2018: EUR 45,999 thousand) which was influenced by several factors including, but
not limited to: a share-based payment arrangement started in 2018 resulting in additional staff cost in the
amount of EUR 21,659 thousand for 2019 and redemption fee option for early repayment of bond in the
amount of EUR 12,578 thousand.

The Group generated net loss for the year ended 31 December 2018 in the amount of EUR 45,999 thousand
which was influenced by the introduction of new a share-based payment arrangement in 2018 resulting in
additional staff expense in the amount of EUR 32,809 thousand, impairment of goodwill in the amount of
EUR 9,255 thousand and a legal and advisory fees for M&A in the amount of EUR 17,681 thousand.
